**Alternative performance measures (“APMs”)**

This Offering Memorandum contains financial measures that are not defined or recognized under US GAAP including:

**_Adjusted EBITDA: We calculate Adjusted EBITDA by applying adjustments for non-operating or non-recurring_**
items to EBITDA.

**_EBITDA: We calculate EBITDA as net income before provision of income taxes, interest expense, depreciation and_**
amortization.

**_Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA: We calculate Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA by applying adjustments for the benefit_**
of cost savings from operational improvement opportunities that we expect to realize within the next three years.

**_Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin: We calculate Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin_** as Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA divided by net sales.

We present these APMs because we believe that the APMs contribute to a better understanding of our results of
operations by providing additional information on what we consider some of the drivers of our financial performance.
Furthermore, we believe that these APMs are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties
as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity.

In addition, the presentation of these measures is not intended to and does not comply with the reporting requirements
of the SEC; compliance with its requirements would require us to make changes to the presentation of this information.
However, the Company believes that the description of these APMs in this offering memorandum follows and complies with
the European Securities and Markets Authority Guidelines on Alternative Performance Measures (APM) dated October 5,
2015.

APMs should not be considered in isolation and investors should not consider such information as alternatives to
revenue, profit before tax or cash flows from operations calculated in accordance with U.S. GAAP, as indications of operating
performance or as measures of the Company’s profitability or liquidity. Such financial information must be considered only in
addition to, and not as a substitute for or superior to, financial information prepared in accordance with US GAAP included
elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these APMs and are also
advised to review them in conjunction with the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed
Combined Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, the Issuer’s computation of
EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin and other APMs may not
be comparable to similarly-titled measures or ratios used by other companies.

We believe that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
margin are meaningful for investors because they provide an analysis of our operating results, profitability and ability to service
debt and because they are used by our chief operating decision makers to track our business evolution, establish operational
and strategic targets and make important business decisions.

For the reconciliation to an appropriate measure calculated in accordance with US GAAP of the APMs included in
this Offering Memorandum, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—
_Alternative Performance Measures (“APMs”)” and “Summary Financial and Other Information.”_

**Overview**

We are a European leader in the design, manufacture and sale of metal packaging solutions, with number one or
number two market positions across our product groups in the countries we operate in. We are the clear market leader in the
26.7-billion-unit European market for metal food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with an approximate
39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. As the largest European manufacturer of metal food
cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel (based on our estimated consumption of approximately 20% of
total European tinplate production), our business is a critical asset in the European food supply chain.

We have been in the industry for more than 200 years and have an established reputation for the highest quality
products and exceptional customer service. From the founding of our predecessor business in 1799 to our acquisition by Crown
in 1996 and our acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, our business has shown itself to be a leader in European metal packaging time
and time again. Following the Transactions, we will become a leading stand-alone business in Europe.

Our product portfolio consists predominantly of food packaging, with approximately 95% of our sales in the year
ended December 31, 2020 going to food related end markets. Our products are used by hundreds of millions of consumers on
a daily basis across Europe, the Middle East and Africa. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12
billion food cans, approximately 24 billion ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol
cans and approximately 134 million metal promotional packaging containers. Our products are used to package food in a
diverse array of end-markets, including fruits and vegetables, tomatoes, fish, pet food, culinary, infant nutrition and dairy. Each
of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers that are stable and largely uncorrelated with broader
macroeconomic cycles.

**Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020**
1. According to leading global consulting firm
2. According to Management estimates

We sell our products in more than 90 countries with France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany
representing 15%, 14%, 12%, 11% and 7% of our sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020 and other
geographies making up the remaining 41% of sales in the same period. Sales to our top 10 customers represented just 32% of
our total sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having
worked with our top 10 customers for an average of over 25 years.

Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and
negotiated raw material pass-through mechanisms, providing us with margin stability and consistent historical cash flows. We
have demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Moreover,
as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Titan Group’s pass-through was on track for full recovery of raw material price
increases in 2021. Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up


-----

to 40% of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts
stipulate a guaranteed percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract.

We operate 44 strategically located manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be
transferred at the end of the transition period) in 17 countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, which enhance our access
to customer end-markets and support local demand. Our manufacturing scale is complemented by our services and customer
support capabilities including over 20 technical services locations, seven dedicated product design studios, four dedicated
laboratory testing facilities and a world-class research and development facility that have put us at the forefront of the European
tinplate packaging industry.

In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had net sales of $2,241 million, $2,138 million and $2,227
million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $303 million, $247 million and $267 million, respectively. Our net sales and
Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were $2,297 million and $317 million, respectively, for the twelve months ended March 31,
2021. These amounts translate, for convenience purposes only, for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, to net
sales of €1,897 million, €1,910 million and €1,951 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of €256 million, €221 million
and €234 million, respectively, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, to net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
of €1,974 million and €272 million, respectively.

**Strengths**

**_1. Longstanding European market leader and critical asset in the European food packaging supply chain_**

We are the clear leader in the European market for food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with
an approximate 39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. Sales of metal food cans and ends
represented 85% of our total revenue in this period. We also believe that we hold the number one or number two market position
in Europe across the other product categories we serve, namely metal closures, aerosol cans and promotional containers with
market shares of approximately 28%, 12% and 24%, respectively, measured by volume for the year ended December 31, 2020.
We have been in the European market for over 200 years and have a reputation with customers for providing the highest quality
products and superior service.

In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12 billion food cans, approximately 24 billion
ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol cans and approximately 134 million metal
promotional packaging containers. Including intermediate precursor products, our manufacturing assets produce 500 million
products per day on average. We have a well-established manufacturing presence with 44 strategically located manufacturing
facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period) across 17 countries
enhancing access to customers, end markets, local demand and suppliers. We operate 34 food cans & ends manufacturing
facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period), five closures
manufacturing facilities, three aerosol manufacturing facilities and three promotional packaging manufacturing facilities. We
have a well-invested asset base supported by in-house research and development expertise. We believe the investment required
to replicate our facility footprint, in addition to the know-how of operating canmaking assets that we developed over our history
create high barriers to entry.

The European market for food cans and ends is mature and highly consolidated with the top two players, ourselves
and our primary competitor, holding a combined market share of over 65% based on volume in the year ended December 31,
2020. The third largest manufacturer has a market share of 3%. Other competitors consist of mostly regional or local
manufacturers, who lack the ability to serve larger food customers at scale or are limited in their ability to serve customers
across multiple geographies. The European food cans and ends market is relatively insulated from import competition given
the high cost of shipping metal packaging long distances and the short lead times customers demand. Due to the significance
of transportation costs in the food can industry, our regional production capabilities support expedient and cost-efficient
transportation to local customers. Furthermore, there are high barriers to entry due to sizeable capital requirements needed to
add capacity, rigorous qualification requirements demanded by customers, and heightened scrutiny with respect to safety
requirements as a result of serving sensitive food end-markets.

We hold a critical position in the European food packaging supply chain as the largest European manufacturer of metal
food cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel. Our business is the key link between tinplate steel, a
commodity raw material that we purchase and convert to finished packaging for our large and fragmented, primarily European,
customer base of food manufacturers. Can producers are the largest consumers of tinplate steel in Europe, with approximately
90% of tinplate steel in Europe being used in packaging, of which 40 to 50% is for food cans and 10 to 15% is for each of
beverages, general line, aerosols and closures. Moreover, the market is largely stable with no significant shifts expected. We


-----

are Europe’s largest buyer of tinplate, consuming approximately 20% of all tinplate production in Europe in 2020 according to
Management estimates. Tinplate steel suppliers rely on us for a stable source of demand, and our position as the largest
consumer of tinplate steel makes us a critical partner to all of the major suppliers of tinplate steel in the European market. Our
over 1,000 customers rely on us as Europe’s largest supplier of food cans and ends. Because of our scale, we are often the only
supplier that can serve high volume customers on a pan-European basis. Our customers depend on our supply to go to market
and rely on our packaging to ensure their products reach store shelves. We provide their products with the benefit of a long
shelf life that metal food cans offer. Our packaging is an important part of our customers’ brands, and we work closely with
our customers to develop designs that ensure their products are attractive to end-consumers at points of sale.

**_2. Diverse, stable revenue mix with exposure to a range of non-cyclical, food-related end markets_**

We sell essential food packaging products into a highly diverse mix of geographies, customers and end-markets, which
supports revenue stability and resilience. Our products serve over 90 countries consisting of both sales into mature, developed
countries and higher growth, developing countries. No single country represented more than 15% of our sales in the year ended
December 31, 2020, with the largest contributors being France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany at 15%, 14%,
12%, 11% and 7% of sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020.

Our product portfolio consists 95% of food packaging, which has historically experienced stable demand throughout
economic cycles. We serve numerous food-related end-markets, including shelf-stable fruit and vegetables, shelf-stable fish,
culinary (such as baked beans), pet food and infant formula, which represented 24%, 18%, 11%, 8% and 8% of sales,
respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020. Each of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers, such as
population growth, eating at home trends, urbanization, and a growing global middle class, that are stable and largely
uncorrelated with broader macroeconomic cycles, and not subject to significant innovation threats.

**Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020**

Metal cans represent the best barrier material and provide a shelf life of over two years while still retaining the
freshness of the food being packaged. In addition, metal food cans provide a host of other benefits to our customers, including
i) allowing for fast filling speeds with limited loss, ii) having high strength and allowing for ease of handling and iii) being
resistant to corrosion, thereby allowing for high-acid contents (e.g., tomatoes). These qualities make our products highly costeffective solutions for our customers and limit the threat of substitution from other substrates.


-----

The stability of our end-markets is evidenced by their historical and forecast growth rates. According to a leading
global consulting firm market growth for the packaging of shelf stable vegetables, culinary products, infant nutrition products
and shelf stable fish in Europe have each fluctuated by CAGRs of less than +/-1.5% between 2015 and 2020, and are expected
to fluctuate by CAGRs of less than +/-1.5% between 2020 and 2024. Furthermore, between 2015 and 2020 the food can volumes
sold in Iberia grew by a CAGR of 2% and in our other key markets of France, Italy, the UK and Germany food can volumes
fluctuated by a CAGR of less than +/-1.5% over this period.

**_3. Diverse, blue-chip customer base with longstanding, contractual relationships_**

We supply over 1,000 customers across a range of resilient product categories and end markets. No single customer
represented more than 8% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, with our top 10 customers representing 32% of
sales for the same period. Our customers include blue-chip, global food and consumer businesses including Abbott, Bonduelle,
Danone, Nestle and Unilever, large national and regional food companies, as well as many smaller and independent fisheries
and farmers. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having worked with our top 10 customers on
average for over 25 years. We are the sole or main supplier for several of our top customers. We believe that the quality of our
products, our track record of providing reliable supply proven over decades and the significant costs to customers involved in
switching manufacturers creates customer stickiness. Before a manufacturing plant or line can begin manufacturing new can
SKUs for a customer, its products typically must be qualified through a process that can take several months to over a year. In
addition, can manufacturers may face downtime on their lines when running new SKUs, thereby impacting customers’ security
and reliability of supply. Customers who decide to change manufacturers also typically lose the benefit of volume rebates from
former suppliers and face uncertainty regarding the stability, reliability and quality of their new partners.

Customers praise our technological know-how, understanding of their requirements and ability to produce and deliver
large volumes of specialty food cans consistently on time and in full. Our customers incur high costs if their packaging is not
delivered when required. As an example, tomatoes must be sealed in their packaging within six hours of being picked to ensure
their freshness, often requiring our manufacturing facilities to ship dozens of truckloads of food cans per day in a continuous
rotation to certain customer facilities during harvest season. We are recognized as an industry leader in product development
and deliver solutions that offer greater consumer convenience and functionality in response to market demands. Can fillers
require producers who can satisfy their branding, quality and safety needs. We believe we consistently satisfy these needs and
enable our customers to differentiate their brands through packaging and address changing safety requirements ahead of time.

**_4. Sustainability- and consumer-driven tailwinds benefit metal packaging_**

Our metal packaging products are favorably positioned to benefit from the increase in demand for sustainable
packaging given their infinitely recyclable nature. Greater environmental consciousness and strong sustainability trends are
expected to support an increased preference for metal packaging over the long-term. End consumers increasingly view
sustainability as a key purchasing criteria and seek out more environmentally friendly packaging. Food producers – our
customers – are aggressively responding to this demand. For example, several major food conglomerates have announced that
they aim to sell mostly recyclable or reusable materials by 2025. These trends are further reinforced by regulatory
developments. For example, the EU circular economy plan adopted in 2020 has a clear focus on recyclable packaging, which
is likely to put pressure on plastic in favor of other packaging materials. Metal packaging provides excellent options for the
sustainability initiatives of companies and brands, since metal properties do not degrade during use or recycling. Consumers
already recognize metal packaging as a highly recyclable substrate, evidenced by recycling rates of over 80% for steel and 75%
for aluminum in Europe, and food brands increasingly want to position themselves as environmentally friendly.

As a further sustainability benefit, metal packaging’s superior barrier properties make it ideal for food preservation,
which reduces food waste. Metal packaging increases the accessibility of healthy foods in an economical manner and provides
contamination protection, thereby reducing the prevalence of food-borne illnesses.

Within the metal packaging industry, we are a European leader in sustainability awareness as a Co-Founder of the
Metal Packaging Europe Association and an active participant in other major sustainability focused associations, which serve
as conduits for sustainability reform at the regulatory and legislative level.

**_5. Attractive financial profile with flexible cost structure and ability to generate consistent free cash flow_**

We have a strong track-record of robust free cash flow generation and cash conversion as a result of our flexible cost
structure and resilient cash flows. We generated average annual free cash flow of $239 million and an average cash conversion
rate of approximately 88% from 2018 to 2020.


-----

Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and
negotiated pass-through mechanisms, providing us with consistent historical cash flows and supporting our margins. We have
demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Based on
Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up to 40% of total sales secured
on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts stipulate a guaranteed
percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, over 97% of
Titan Group’s pricing for 2021 was already agreed.

We estimate that approximately 87% of our cost base is fully- or semi-variable, consisting mostly of material costs,
labor costs, freight, energy, which represented 61%, 15%, 5% and 3%, respectively, of our total costs for the year ended
December 31, 2020 in addition to other consumables. The semi-variable characteristics of our labor costs come from our ability
to reduce our labor costs through the use of seasonal and temporary employees. Our variable cost structure allows us to quickly
adapt our production capacity to harvest cycles, which can result in modest volume fluctuations from year to year.

Our cash flow stability is bolstered by the non-cyclical end-markets we serve, our ability to pass-through raw material
prices changes, our long-term customer relationships with contracted volumes, and customer stickiness. Our modest capital
expenditure requirements and well-managed, disciplined approach to working capital further strengthen our free cash flow
conversion. We believe our free cash flow profile will enable us to reduce leverage through debt repayment over time.

**_6. Experienced management team supported by a best-in-class financial sponsor_**

We benefit from a talented management team with deep roots in the business and decades of experience. Our
management team has a strong track-record of value creation in the consumer packaging industry and has an average 30 years
of service in the industry.

Our management team has been involved in the preparation of our transition from being a part of Crown to operating
as a stand-alone business, including the development of our stand-alone strategy. We have also moved to reinforce the team in
its new existence as a stand-alone company by announcing the appointment of Tomás López as Chief Executive Officer. Mr
López will bring experience and a track-record of success in managing Mivisa before it was acquired by Crown. See also
“Management.”

KPS Capital Partners (“KPS”) has a strong track-record of realising improvements in manufacturing companies and
over two decades of constructive investing in highly complex corporate carve-outs on a global basis. KPS creates value for its
investors by working constructively with talented management teams to make businesses better, and generates investment
returns by structurally improving the strategic position, competitiveness and profitability of its portfolio companies, rather than
primarily relying on financial leverage. KPS will support management and leverage its core operational improvement expertise.
Furthermore, Crown will retain a 20% equity stake in the stand-alone company, validating its belief in the potential of the
business and allow for a smooth transition of the business to an independent company.

**Strategy**

Our strong cash flow generation has historically been utilized in support of broader goals within the larger Crown
organization. We have a unique position in the European food supply chain as the largest manufacturer of food cans and ends
in Europe and we believe that we are the largest buyer of tinplate steel in Europe. We believe that, despite our market position,
our historic margins have lagged those of key competitors and our own potential as a result of the lack of focus on our business
under our prior owners. Under Crown’s ownership, the business has mainly focused on volumes and cash generation to support
Crown’s other businesses, which presents a significant opportunity for margin improvement. From 2017 to 2020, Titan Group
represented approximately 20% of Crown’s sales but only 8% of its capital expenditures.

As a stand-alone business, we aim to reorient the business towards growth and margin improvement. Capitalizing on
the above strengths as a stand-alone business, we believe we have numerous levers to create additional value, grow volumes,
improve profitability and generate cash flows.

**_1. New Markets and Growth Opportunities_**

The Business has numerous growth opportunities arising from favorable consumption trends, such as a greater focus
on convenience, growth in single serve packaging, increasing premiumization and higher focus on sustainability. Operating as
a stand-alone entity, we will have greater flexibility to pursue opportunities that were not previously considered or prioritized
while integrated within the wider Crown business. In addition, we will have the benefit of a steady capital expenditure program


-----

that is focused on our business, allowing us to pursue multi-year growth projects which we were unable to pursue under prior
ownership. End-markets such as infant nutrition and wet petfood have volume growth opportunities at attractive margins that
we believe we can capture by employing our capabilities and expertise developed in other end-markets. Our metal cans are
well-positioned to benefit from these growth opportunities in light of their favorable barrier properties and the premium
perception and convenience that our products offer. In addition, we are focused on growing our share and penetration in key
emerging markets such as Eastern Europe and Africa, where our existing customers are establishing footprints that we can
readily support with existing technologies and know-how.

**_2. Procurement Optimization_**

Tinplate steel makes up for more than 80% of our raw materials spend and represented 48% of our cost of products
sold in the year ended December 31, 2020. We believe our market position enables us to optimize sourcing and pricing for our
tinplate steel purchases and provides further opportunities for margin expansion. While the Business under Crown’s ownership
mainly focused on ensuring stability of supply and favorable working capital arrangements, as a stand-alone business we will
have the opportunity to manage supply arrangements in support of better margins, including through utilizing a greater share
of raw materials from low cost countries. We have developed optimization initiatives to realize the most favorable pricing with
suppliers for the highest quality tinplate with the shortest supply chain lead times.

There is potential for additional cost savings opportunities in the form of reduced spend on logistics, raw material
specification complexity reductions, indirect cost savings and contract structure improvements. We believe there is an
opportunity to purchase higher volume of fewer SKUs, and also consolidate production of precursor products into fewer
facilities, thereby reducing the number of facilities receiving raw material shipments and to improve the structure of certain of
our contracts. In addition, we believe there are opportunities to optimize indirect and other materials procurement through
targeted sourcing initiatives. In the three months ended March 31, 2021, Titan Group already realized the benefit of improved
procurement practices and commercial efforts, leading to expanding margins for this period.

**_3. Manufacturing Optimization_**

We expect to realize further efficiencies by improving the asset utilization and productivity of our manufacturing
footprint. We intend to employ targeted capital expenditures focused on modernizing the equipment used at several of our key
facilities with a goal of increasing the capacity of those facilities and allowing more efficient and cost-effective production
while reducing the number of facilities in our network.

Our Business grew substantially following the acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, however, we did not fully integrate the
Mivisa and legacy manufacturing footprints and did not achieve the margin targets or synergies forecast at the time. We believe
that there are certain manufacturing function overlaps and duplications as a result of the acquisition and our organic growth.
We intend to replicate the “hub and spoke” operating model, used successfully by Mivisa, whereby certain functions that can
easily and cost-effectively be transported are completed at lower cost plants to improve and optimize asset utilization. For
example, we believe that the manufacturing of ends and certain upstream functions such as metal processing and coating can
be consolidated into facilities that specialize in production of those precursor products. Such products would then be transported
to existing can finishing or assembly plants that are located close to our customers and have a lean operating footprint. This
approach was successfully developed at Mivisa, which operated the largest ends production facility in the world in Murcia,
Spain, producing more than 9 billion ends annually and serviced nearly its entire network using this plant and also serviced a
significant export business of ends. We intend to replicate this model across the Group’s existing manufacturing footprint.

**_4. Commercial Excellence and Continuous Improvement Initiatives_**

In addition to revenue improvement and market share capture, our strategy also has a strong focus on delivering further
cost savings and unlocking further margin improvement potential. We plan to develop a continuous improvement culture and
invest in training across the entire business. KPS and Management have conducted a comprehensive and granular review of
our operating model. We believe that as a stand-alone business, we will be able to realize these cost savings and margin
expansions based on KPS’ proven track record in realising improvements in manufacturing businesses.

We have identified a number of commercial excellence and continuous improvement priorities, including (i) more
focused deployment of capital expenditures, (ii) quality management in the form of manufacturing and operational excellence
initiatives; (iii) maintenance and repair optimization, (iv) using a local sales force to improve engagement between our sales
and operations teams and (v) a focus on customer service, innovation and responsiveness initiatives. As a stand-alone business
focused on the manufacturing of food cans and ends, we will be more readily able to pursue these opportunities rather than
having to compete with the other capital priorities of our former owner.


-----

Our planned capital projects include investments focused on asset productivity, such as tooling upgrades to multi-die
presses and high speed printing and coating lines capable of delivering up to 300% improvements in productivity. Our planned
capital projects typically have a payback of approximately two to three years. We also believe there is an opportunity to improve
the effectiveness of our commercial function by streamlining our financial reporting structure, providing greater visibility to
our local sales teams and enabling them to optimize the margin profile of products they are selling. We believe our customers
derive significant value from our product offering and we intend to capture additional margin for the superior service and
capabilities that we offer.

**The Transactions**

The Transactions consist of the following:

    - the consummation of the Financing;

     - the consummation of the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement; and

     - the payment of costs, fees and expenses in connection with the foregoing transactions, including the fees and
expenses to be incurred in connection with the Transactions.

For descriptions of our anticipated indebtedness following the Transactions, see “Description of Certain Financing
_and Guarantee Arrangements” and “Capitalization.”_

**_The Acquisition_**

On April 8, 2021, Bidco and Crown entered into the Acquisition Agreement, pursuant to which Bidco will acquire the
Titan Group conducting the Business. Through the Acquisition, KPS, or an affiliate thereof, will indirectly acquire 80% of the
ownership interests in the Titan Group, with the remaining 20% being continued to be held by Crown (excluding ownership of
Titan Group by Senior Management). The purchase price for the Acquisition of the Business will be €2.25 billion, subject to
customary purchase price adjustments to reflect any changes in net debt, net working capital and cash in accordance with the
Acquisition Agreement.

The closing of the Acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions, including receipt of clearance from the EU
competition authority and, pursuant to applicable laws, informing and/or consulting with the relevant employee representatives
in France and the Netherlands. The longstop date for closing under the Acquisition Agreement is October 15, 2021.

KPS, or an affiliate thereof, and Crown will, on or around the Completion Date, enter into a shareholders’ agreement,
setting out Crown’s rights as a minority investor as well as a non-compete covenant undertaken by Crown based on the terms
agreed by the parties in a shareholders’ agreement term sheet at signing. See “Related Party Transactions—Related Party
_Transactions—Shareholders’ Agreement.”_

Crown or one or more of its subsidiaries, on the one hand, and Bidco or one or more of its subsidiaries, on the other
hand, will each provide transition services to the other pursuant to the Transitional Services Agreement to be entered into by
and between the Crown and Bidco at the closing of the Acquisition. See “Related Party Transactions—Related Party
_Transactions—Transitional Services Agreement.”_

**_The Financing_**

The Acquisition will be financed as follows (collectively, the “Financing”):

     - the Issuer will issue the Notes offered hereby in an aggregate principal amount of €375.0 million;


-----

     - Bidco will enter into the Credit Facilities Agreement and borrow €1,175.0 million under the Term Loan B Facility;
and

    - KPS, or an affiliate thereof, and Crown will, subject to variation through, among other things, customary
completion accounts adjustments as set out in the Acquisition Agreement, make an equity contribution in an
aggregate amount of €700 million.

In connection with the Acquisition, on the Completion Date, a Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of up to €275.0
million will be made available to Bidco and certain of its subsidiaries for general corporate and working capital purposes. The
Revolving Credit Facility is currently not expected to be drawn on the Completion Date. See “Capitalization.”

In connection with the Acquisition, certain existing factoring and other similar arrangements of the Titan Group are
envisioned to be rolled over. See “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements.”

The net proceeds from the Financing will be used to:

     - fund the consideration payable for the Acquisition;

     - fund cash on Titan Group’s balance sheet; and

     - pay fees and expenses in connection with the Acquisition and the Financing, including the fees and expenses to
be incurred in connection with the Offering. See “Use of Proceeds.”

**_Escrow Arrangements_**

Concurrently with the closing of the Offering on the Issue Date, the Issuer will deposit the gross proceeds of the
Offering into the Escrow Account, to hold such amounts pending the consummation of the Acquisition. The Escrow Account
will be in the name of the Issuer and will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of
the Trustee for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to the Notes—If the Acquisition is not
_completed, you may not obtain the return that you expect on the Notes.”_

The release of the Escrow Proceeds and the consummation of the Acquisition will be subject to the satisfaction of
certain conditions. If these conditions are not satisfied on the business day following the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the
occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory
redemption price for the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest
and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but not including the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined herein). See “Risk
_Factors—Risks related to the Notes—If the Acquisition is not completed, you may not obtain the return that you expect on the_
_Notes.”_

In the event that the special mandatory redemption price payable upon a special mandatory redemption exceeds the
Escrow Proceeds, the Sponsor will, pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter, be required to make an equity contribution to
the Issuer to pay any funding shortfall to cover the accrued and unpaid interest, and Additional Amounts, if any, owing to the
holders of the Notes and any negative interest charged on the Escrow Account. See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of
_Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”_

Upon release of the proceeds from escrow, the proceeds of the Offering, together with the shareholder contributions
and proceeds from the Credit Facilities Agreement as described above, will be used to finance the Acquisition and pay fees and
expenses in connection with the Transactions as shown in the table above.

Guarantors accounted for approximately 75% of the Titan Group’s net
sales, approximately 65% of the Titan Group’s EBITDA and
approximately 76% of the Titan Group’s total assets (excluding
goodwill).

The Guarantees will be subject to certain contractual and legal
limitations, and may be released without the consent of holders of the
Notes under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—
_Guarantees” and “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the_
_Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law_
_Considerations.”_

Transactions, the Issuer’s subsidiaries that will not Guarantee the Notes
are not expected to have any material indebtedness for borrowed money
outstanding.

**Ranking of the Guarantees .......................** The Guarantee of each Guarantor will:

                     - be a senior subordinated obligation of that Guarantor;

                     - be subordinated in right of payment to all of the Guarantors’
existing and future senior indebtedness, including any indebtedness
under or in respect of the Credit Facilities Agreement and certain
hedging obligations;

                     - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future
senior subordinated indebtedness and other liabilities of that
Guarantor that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to
the Guarantees;

                     - be effectively subordinated to all existing and future secured
Indebtedness and other obligations of such Guarantor that are
secured by assets that do not secure its Guarantee or that are secured
on a first-priority basis over assets that secure the Guarantees on a
second-priority basis (including the Indebtedness Incurred under
the Credit Facilities Agreement and certain Hedging Obligations),
to the extent of the value of the assets securing such Indebtedness
or such other obligations, and to any creditor having a preferred
claim by operation of law, to the extent of the value of such
preferred claim;

                     - be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness
of subsidiaries of such Guarantor that do not Guarantee the Notes,
including obligations to trade creditors; and

                     - be subject to the limitations described under “Limitations on
_Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security_
_Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_

subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes will be secured by
(collectively, the “Collateral”):

Issuer by Topco; (2) a pledge of the receivables in respect of certain
material intercompany loans owed to Topco, if any; and (3) a pledge

Bidco by the Issuer; and (2) a pledge of receivables in respect of
certain material intercompany loans owed to the Issuer by Bidco
(items 1 and 2 collectively, the “Shared Collateral”).

Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations and may also
secure certain future indebtedness. The security interests over the
Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See

offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and
not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer, or any third party making such
a change of control offer in lieu of the Issuer, will have the right, upon
prior notice to the holders, to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding
following such purchase at a price equal to the price paid to each other
holder of Notes in such change of control offer, plus, to the extent not
included in the change of control offer payment, accrued and unpaid
interest and Additional Amounts, if any, thereon, to, but not including,
the redemption date.

(a) This amount represents that portion of the historical costs and expenses of Crown assigned to Titan Group in the Audited Combined Financial
Statements and Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements using an allocation method primarily based on percentage of
sales, including expenses for executive management, finance, legal, information technology, employee benefit administration, treasury and risk
management as well as technology royalties.

(b) This amount represents the costs and expenses required to operate the Group on a standalone basis. These costs cover substantially the same
categories that comprise the amounts under “ Discontinued Corporate Allocations”. Standalone costs are expected to be significantly less than
costs incurred under the Discontinued Corporate Allocations. See “ Risk Factors — Risks Relating to the Acquisition — Titan Group’s ability to
_operate its business effectively may suffer if it is unable to cost-effectively establish its own administrative and other support functions in order_
_to operate as a standalone company after the expiration of the Transitional Services Agreement with the Crown Group.” Standalone costs are_
based on management estimates and assumptions (including the successful implementation of our standalone strategy) and are forward looking
in nature. As such, this information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those
contained in our estimates. Any failure by us to successfully execute on our standalone strategy could materially impact our results. As such,
this information is inherently subject to business, economic and other risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially
from those contained in our estimated standalone costs and expenses. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial impact or
results of these actions and initiatives and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. If one or more of our underlying
assumptions proves to have been incorrect, this could lead to substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be able to realize fully, or
realize in the anticipated time frame, the estimated benefits from our standalone cost-savings. See "Risk Factors — Risks Relating to the
_Acquisition — Titan Group has no operating history as a standalone company and it may not be successful in implementing its strategy as a_
_standalone business."_

(c) Following the Completion Date, the Business will operate on a stand-alone basis independently of its United States parent. Given that none of
the Group’s operations are in the United States, we expect that our reporting currency will shift from the U.S. Dollar to the Euro and we anticipate
preparing our financial statements under IFRS. The amounts in this line item represent the estimated impact of operating lease expenses
recognized under IFRS 16, which introduces a single, on-balance sheet lease accounting model for lessees. The amounts in this line item represent
the U.S. GAAP operating lease expense from the Audited Combined Financial Statements as a proxy for the IFRS 16 lease liabilities. See Annex
A for a discussion of certain differences between U.S. GAAP and IFRS. A lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the
underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligations to make lease payments. There are optional exemptions for short-term leases
and leases of low value items.

(d) This adjustment in the year ended December 31, 2019 primarily relates to a $25 million non-cash goodwill impairment charge, incurred related
primarily to our aerosols and promotional packaging activities, resulting from the outlook for tinplate aerosol packaging having declined and
operating costs in the aerosol and promotional packaging activities having increased, as well as an $8 million restructuring add-back and a $3
million loss on disposal. The adjustment in the year ended December 31, 2020 primarily relates to a $2 million gain on disposal. The Business
has undergone a variety of restructuring efforts, primarily related to plant closures in France and Germany in an effort to reduce overall fixed
headcount and duplicative positions. Restructuring costs included in this adjustment take account of severance and other general cost associated
with implementing the restructuring such as cleaning or stripping plants.

(e) Represents the removal of non-operating costs included in pension expense, in particular amortization of prior year unrealized losses related to
German pensions.

(f) Represents costs associated with discontinued operations in Peru, primarily comprised of VAT expenses and operating losses. The facility in
Peru is not part of the Titan Group going forward.

(g) This amount normalizes the impact of bad debt expense to $1.1 million per annum based on historical bad debt expense accruals, run-rate and
relatively consistent sales year over year over a period of 10 years.

(h) Represents (i) expenses in relation to the implementation of a new information technology system in the year ended December 31, 2018 leading
to more precise methodologies in monitoring inventory, (ii) recoveries of customer claims from suppliers in relation to defective products, (iii)
removal of EBITDA relating to a customer contract which was discontinued in the year ended December 31, 2018, and (iv) normalizing costs
in relation to the Business’ UK pension system due to a change from a defined benefit plan to a defined contribution plan in the year ended
December 31, 2019.

**RISK FACTORS**

_This Offering involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the risks described below as well as other_
_information and data contained in this Offering Memorandum before making an investment decision. If any of the events_
_described in the risk factors below occur, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially_
_adversely affected, which in turn could materially adversely affect our ability to repay the Notes. The risks described below are_
_not the only risks we face. Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or that we currently deem to be_
_immaterial may also materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, operating results or prospects. In any such_
_case, you may lose all or part of your investment in the Notes._

_This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual_
_results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward looking statements as a result of various factors, including_
_the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Risks Relating to Titan Group's Business and Industry

**_Titan Group's business is seasonal and adverse weather conditions could reduce Titan Group's net sales._**

Titan Group manufactures metal packaging primarily for food products. At least 45% of the Group’s revenue is
generated from sales to seasonal food end-markets. These sales can be affected by weather conditions as well as seasonal
availability of the food products. For example, sales are typically greater in the second and third quarters of the year, with
generally lower sales in the first and fourth quarters. Despite the minimum volume clauses in certain of Titan Group’s contracts,
poor weather conditions that reduce crop yields of certain food types, could lead to decrease in customer demand for Titan
Group’s food packaging products (and climate change could increase the frequency of adverse weather extremes). In addition,
demand for Titan Group’s seafood packaging could be affected by variations in the volume of local fish catches. The inherent
volatility of food and seafood production businesses as well as Titan Group’s exposure to fluctuating weather conditions could
have a material adverse effect on Titan Group’s business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Titan Group is subject to the risks associated with maintaining and operating its manufacturing facilities._**

Titan Group is subject to the risks associated with operating, and must incur potentially significant capital and other
expenditures necessary to maintain, its manufacturing facilities, machinery and equipment. Titan Group must maintain its
manufacturing facilities in order to, among other things, keep up with demand for its products, retain sufficient capacity to
manufacture new products and increase its margins. If Titan Group is unable to maintain sufficient manufacturing capacity to
keep up with demand for its products and ensure that its sales and production teams adequately coordinate their planning and
production efforts, Titan Group risks losing potential product sales.

Titan Group’s operations use manufacturing processes, which are conducted at high speeds and involve operating
heavy machinery and equipment, such as cutting, coating and shaping metal into containers. These processes entail various
operational, industrial and environmental risks and hazards, including industrial accidents, leaks and ruptures, explosions, fires,
adverse weather conditions, natural disasters such as floods, tornadoes, hurricanes, ice storms and earthquakes, supply
interruptions, human error, terrorist acts, power outages, mechanical failures and environmental hazards, such as spills, storage
tank leaks, discharges or releases of toxic or hazardous substances and gases. These hazards may cause unplanned business
interruptions, unscheduled downtime, transportation interruptions, personal injury and loss of life, severe damage to or the
destruction of property and equipment, environmental contamination and other environmental damage, civil, criminal and
administrative sanctions and liabilities, and third-party claims, any of which may have a material adverse effect on Titan
Group’s business, financial condition and results of operations. For example, in June 2020, the roof of a storage building at our
site in Laon, France suffered a partial collapse, with reconstruction to be envisioned to begin in 2021. Crown has agreed to
reimburse Titan Group for certain losses suffered in connection with this roof collapse pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement.
The operation of manufacturing facilities also requires Titan Group to hire, train and evaluate large numbers of production
employees, which involves additional labor and employment related risks and uncertainties.

Unscheduled shutdowns may also occur due to technical failure or other reasons. Extended downtime at any of Titan
Group’s major operating facilities, whether the result of a scheduled shutdown or otherwise, could reduce rates of asset
utilization and undermine Titan Group’s ability to maintain high production volumes, which could materially adversely affect
Titan Group’s business, financial condition and results of operations.


-----

As part of the Acquisition, Crown will continue to own and operate the Braunstone site and sell its food cans to Titan
Group at cost during a two to three year transition period. If these arrangements are not implemented as expected or if, once
implemented, they have an unexpected impact on Titan Group’s manufacturing capability, its business, financial condition and
results of operations could be adversely impacted.

**_Titan Group may be affected by manufacturing defects or product liability or recall claims or may otherwise be_**
**_subject to adverse publicity._**

The success of our business depends on the quality and reliability of our products and our customer relations. In the
event that our products materially fail to satisfy our customers’ requirements, our reputation and sales volumes could suffer.
Titan Group may be required to manufacture replacement products at its own expense if they fail to meet its customers’
standards, expectations and/or the applicable health and safety standards of the country in which a product is distributed, and
Titan Group may be subject to product liability claims in connection with the foregoing. We may incur significant expenditures
as a result of product recalls, market withdrawals or other product liability or product-related claims. We may also suffer other
commercial and financial consequences in connection with manufacturing defects or product liability claims, including fines
and payments to customers, their contractors or distributors in respect of destroyed inventory, out of stock penalties and
consumer complaints.

Although Titan Group has control measures and systems in place in an effort to ensure the maximum safety and quality
of its products is maintained, the consequences of not being able to do so, due to accidental or malicious raw material or product
contamination, or due to supply chain contamination caused by human error or faulty equipment, could be severe. Such
consequences may include adverse effects on consumer health, reputation, loss of customers and market share, financial costs
or loss of revenue. If any of its products are found to be defective, Titan Group could be required to recall such products, which
could result in adverse publicity, significant expenses and a disruption in sales and could affect its reputation and that of its
products. Although Titan Group maintains product liability and recall insurance coverage, potential product liability or recall
claims may exceed the amount of insurance coverage or such claims may be excluded under the terms of the applicable policy.
In addition, if any of our competitors or customers supply faulty or contaminated products to the market, or if manufacturers
of the end-products that utilize our products produce faulty or contaminated products, our industry, or our end-products’
industries, could be negatively impacted, which could have adverse effects on our business.

In certain contracts, Titan Group provides warranties in respect of the proper functioning of its products and the
conformity of a product to the specific use defined by the customer. In addition, if one of our customer’s products contained in
packaging manufactured by us is faulty or contaminated, it is possible that the manufacturer of the product may allege that our
packaging is the cause of the fault or contamination, even if the packaging complies with contractual specifications.

In case of the failure of packaging produced by Titan Group to open properly or to preserve the integrity of its contents,
Titan Group could face liability to its customers and to third parties for bodily injury or other tangible or intangible damages
suffered as a result. Such liability, if it were to be established in relation to a sufficient volume of claims or to claims for
sufficiently large amounts, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Any manufacturing defects or product liability claims against us could subject us to adverse publicity. In addition,
Titan Group may be subject to adverse publicity relating to other matters, including, but not limited to, product quality, brand
image, complaints, environmental impact, human rights practices, production facilities and employee relationships. The
widespread use of social media and networking sites by consumers has greatly increased the speed and accessibility of
information dissemination. Adverse publicity may negatively impact our reputation, regardless of whether the allegations are
valid. The negative impact of adverse publicity relating to any of our products, brands or production facilities may extend far
beyond the product, brand or plant involved to affect some or all of our other products, brands and facilities. Any such adverse
publicity may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Although we have not had material claims for damages for defective products in the past, and have not conducted any
substantial product recalls or other material correct action, these events may occur in the future. We utilize quality control and
assurance systems in all of our plants, and maintain general and third-party liability insurance, product liability insurance, and
other insurance coverages Titan Group deems appropriate. When Titan Group receives complaints from customers, it conducts
a technical root cause analysis to determine the reason for the complaint and Titan Group implements steps to prevent a
reoccurrence. We can provide no assurance, however, that such measures will ensure that our products meet our customers’
standards or that such insurance will be adequate to cover all potential claims. See “Business—Properties.”


-----

**_Titan Group's principal markets may be subject to overcapacity and price competition from other metal packaging_**
**_producers, which could reduce Titan Group's net sales and net income._**

Titan Group operates in the food metal packaging sector which is highly competitive and, in recent years (disregarding
the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic which temporarily increased demand for canned foods for at home use), increasingly
characterized by limited growth in demand. Food cans are standardized products, allowing for relatively little differentiation
among competitors. The most competitive aspect of the metal packaging market is the sale of undifferentiated, standardized
food cans. Prices for these products are primarily driven by raw material costs and seasonal capacity. Our principal competitors
include Massilly, Silgan Holdings, Trivium, Auxiliar, DomIberia, Glud Marstrand and Sarten. If capacity growth outpaced the
growth in demand for food cans, this could lead to additional overcapacity and heightened price competition among food can
producers. These could significantly reduce demand for Titan Group’s products or force Titan Group to lower its prices, which,
in turn, could lead to decline in revenue and net income, negatively impacting Titan Group’s margins and increasing its debt
balances. Competitive pricing pressures and overcapacity combined with the failure to develop new product designs and
technologies for products, as well as other factors, such as consolidation among Titan Group's competitors, could cause Titan
Group to lose existing business or opportunities to generate new business and could result in decreased cash flow and net
income, which could have material adverse effect on Titan Group’s business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Intense competition from manufacturers of alternative forms of food packaging products could lead to decreased_**
**_demand in Titan Group’s products resulting in lower profits and reduced cash flows._**

Titan Group is subject to substantial competition from producers of alternative packaging made from glass, paper,
flexible materials and plastic. Changes in preferences for products and packaging by consumers of prepackaged food products
could lead to increase in consumer demand for alternative food products packaging. Titan Group's sales depend heavily on the
volumes of sales by Titan Group's customers in the food markets. Changes in packaging by Titan Group's customers may
require Titan Group to re-tool manufacturing operations, which could require material expenditures. Decreases in the costs of
alternative packaging could negatively affect Titan Group’s sales, resulting in lower profits and reduced cash flows for Titan
Group. For example, increases in the price of aluminum and steel and decreases in the price of plastic resin, which is a
petrochemical product and may fluctuate with prices in the oil and gas market, may increase substitution of plastic food
containers for metal containers or increases in the price of steel may increase substitution of aluminum packaging for aerosol
products.

Failure by Titan Group to successfully compete against alternative packaging products producers could results in
decreased demand for its products, which combined with low capacity utilization rates in its operations, could have material
adverse effect on Titan Group’s business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Titan Group's business results depend on its ability to understand its customers' specific preferences and_**
**_requirements based on changing consumer preferences or otherwise, and to develop, manufacture and market products that_**
**_meet customer demand._**

The food packaging industry is greatly affected by evolving customer tastes, preferences, perception and spending
patterns. The popularity of certain food product types for which Titan Group currently supplies packaging, such as fresh or
frozen food content and dry versus wet pet food, may decline in the future due to consumers’ changing lifestyle, nutrition,
health or taxation considerations. In the past, the occurrence of diseases such as bovine spongiform encephalopathy and swine
fever have sometimes led to reduced demand for associated canned products, such as sauces, soups and ready meals, and
publicity about the supposed carcinogenic effect of coatings used on some cans may have affected sales of some canned
products. Any decline in the popularity of any of Titan Group’s customers’ product types as a result of lifestyle, nutrition, health
considerations or consumer taxation could have a significant impact on Titan Group’s customers and could have a material
adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Titan Group's ability to develop new packaging product offerings for a diverse group of international customers with
differing preferences and changing tastes, while maintaining functionality and spurring innovation, is critical to its success.
This requires a thorough understanding of Titan Group's existing and potential customers on an international basis, particularly
in potential high developing markets. The Group must also introduce new products and services to meet changing customer
demands and needs. If Titan Group is unable to regularly implement better production processes or to develop new products
through R&D efforts or licensing of new technology, it may not be able to remain competitive with other manufacturers. Failure
to deliver quality products that meet customer needs ahead of competitors could have a significant adverse effect on Titan
Group's business, financial condition and results of operations.


-----

**_The loss of a major customer and/or customer consolidation could reduce Titan Group's net sales and profitability._**

Titan Group sells its products to a stable base of over 1,000 customers, including several food market leaders. Titan
Group believes that its relationships with its customers are good, but there can be no assurance that Titan Group will be able to
maintain these relationships and that the customers will continue to purchase Titan Group’s products. Although no one customer
accounted for more than 8% of its net sales in the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 or 2018, the loss of any major
customers, a reduction in the purchasing levels of these customers or an adverse change in the terms of supply agreements with
these customers could reduce Titan Group's net sales and net income and have material adverse effect on Titan Group’s
business, financial condition and results of operations.

Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up to 40%
of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Although these arrangements have provided, and Titan Group expects they will
continue to provide, the basis for long-term partnerships with its customers, there can be no assurance that Titan Group’s
customers will not cease purchasing its products due to a switch to one of its competitors, in-sourcing of manufacturing or
otherwise, or that they will not push for more aggressive terms upon contract renewals with Titan Group.

Many of Titan Group's largest customers have acquired companies with similar or complementary product lines. This
consolidation has increased the concentration of Titan Group's business with its largest customers. In many cases, such
consolidation has been accompanied by pressure from customers for lower prices, reflecting the increase in the total volume of
product purchased or the elimination of a price differential between the acquiring customer and the company acquired.
Increased pricing pressures from Titan Group's customers may reduce Titan Group's net sales and net income. The consolidation
of Titan Group’s customers may also lead customers to rely on a reduced number of suppliers of food packaging products, with
a competitor becoming the main supplier to the consolidated companies, which could have material adverse effect on Titan
Group’s business, financial condition or results of operations.

**_Titan Group's financial results could be materially adversely affected if Titan Group is not able to secure sufficient_**
**_quantities of raw materials or if the price of raw materials or energy rises and Titan Group cannot increase the price of its_**
**_products._**

Titan Group uses various raw materials, such as tinplate steel, aluminum, natural gas, electricity as well as materials
derived from crude oil such as lacquer and ink, in its manufacturing operations. Sufficient quantities of these raw materials
may not be available in the future or may be available only at increased prices. The availability of these raw materials and their
prices depends on global and local supply and demand forces, governmental regulations (such as the EU’s Regulation (EU)
2019/159 imposing definitive safeguard measures against imports of certain steel products, including 25% tariff duty if trade
flows exceed certain set levels), level of production, resource availability, industrial actions or strikes by employees of suppliers,
transportation, and other factors, including natural disasters such as floods and earthquakes. In particular, in recent years the
consolidation of steel and aluminum suppliers, shortage of raw materials affecting the production of steel and aluminum and
the increased global demand for these materials, including in China and other developing countries, have contributed to an
overall tighter supply, resulting in increased steel and aluminum prices and, in some cases, special surcharges and allocated cut
backs of products by steel and aluminum suppliers.

If Titan Group is unable to obtain adequate supplies of tinplate, steel, aluminum, resins or other raw materials for a
significant period of time, Titan Group's operations would be disrupted and any such disruption may materially adversely affect
Titan Group's business, financial condition or results of operations.

Titan Group's raw material supply contracts vary as to terms and duration, with tinplate negotiated on an annual basis
with substantially all of supply based on fixed annual pricing, with the small remainder on a spot pricing basis and aluminum
contracts typically multi-year in duration with fluctuating prices based on aluminum prices. The prices of certain raw materials
used by Titan Group, such as tinplate steel, aluminum, resins and processed energy, have historically been subject to volatility.
In the year ended December 31, 2020, tinplate steel represented more than 80% of Titan Group's raw material spend. While
some, but not all, of Titan Group's contracts pass through raw material costs to customers, and Titan Group sets the prices of
its products taking into account the largely fixed annual price for tinplate steel, Titan Group may be unable to increase its prices
to offset increases in raw material costs without suffering reductions in unit volume, revenue and operating income. In addition,
any price increases may take effect after related cost increases, reducing operating income in the near term. Future tinplate steel
supply contracts may also provide for prices that fluctuate or adjust rather than provide a fixed price during a one-year period.
There can be no assurance that, in the future, Titan Group will be able to secure adequate supplies of raw materials from its
current suppliers or other sources on terms as favorable as its current terms, or at all. Moreover, as a result of continuing global
supply and demand pressures, other commodity-related costs affecting Titan Group's business may increase as well, including
natural gas, electricity and freight-related costs. If the future prices of these raw material increase and Titan Group is unable


-----

to offset such increases, Titan Group's operations would be disrupted and any such disruption may materially adversely affect
Titan Group's business, financial condition or results of operations.

Moreover, significant increases in raw material costs may increase Titan Group's working capital requirements, which
may increase Titan Group's average outstanding indebtedness and interest expense and may exceed the amounts available under
Titan Group's credit facilities and other sources of liquidity. In addition, Titan Group hedges raw material costs on behalf of
certain customers and may suffer losses if such customers are unable to satisfy their purchase obligations. This could lead to
liquidity constraints and could, if Titan Group is unable to procure sufficient working capital to cover heightened capital needs,
material adversely Titan Group's financial results.

**_The loss of third-party transportation providers upon whom Titan Group depends or increases in fuel prices could_**
**_increase Titan Group's costs or cause a disruption in Titan Group's operations._**

Titan Group depends generally upon third-party transportation providers for delivery of raw materials to its
manufacturing facilities and delivery of its products to customers. Strikes, slowdowns, transportation disruptions or other
conditions in the transportation industry, including, but not limited to, shortages of truck drivers, disruptions in rail service,
decreases in the availability of vessels or increases in fuel prices, could increase Titan Group's costs and disrupt Company’s
operations and its ability to receive raw materials and service customers on a timely basis.

**_If Titan Group fails to retain key management and personnel, Titan Group may be unable to implement its business_**
**_plan._**

The success of Titan Group’s business strategy depends on its ability to attract, train, retain and motivate skilled
managerial, technical, sales, administration, development and operating personnel. Members of Titan Group's senior
management have extensive industry experience, and it might be difficult to find new personnel with comparable experience.
Because Titan Group's business is highly specialized, Titan Group believes that it would also be difficult to replace its key
technical personnel. Titan Group believes that its future success depends, in large part, on its experienced senior management
team. Losing the services of key members of its management or technical team could limit Titan Group's ability to implement
its business plan.

**_A significant portion of Titan Group's workforce is unionized and labor disruptions, along with other factors_**
**_affecting labor costs, could increase Titan Group's total costs or prevent Titan Group from supplying its customers._**

Titan Group has in the past, and may in the future, experience labor disputes and work stoppages at one or more of its
manufacturing sites due to localized strikes or strikes in the larger retail food industry sector. A significant portion of Titan
Group's workforce is unionized and a prolonged work stoppage or strike at any facility with unionized employees could increase
its costs and prevent Titan Group from supplying its customers. In addition, upon the expiration of existing collective bargaining
agreements, Titan Group may not reach new agreements without union action in certain jurisdictions and any such new
agreements may not be on terms satisfactory to Titan Group. If Titan Group is unable to negotiate acceptable collective
bargaining agreements, it may become subject to union-initiated work stoppages, including strikes. Moreover, additional groups
of currently non-unionized employees may seek union representation in the future.

An increase in labor costs could adversely affect Titan Group's profitability. Most of the factors affecting labor costs
are beyond Titan Group's control and Titan Group may not be able to adjust its pricing to reflect an increase in labor costs. A
shortage of qualified employees, general inflationary pressure on wages or an increase in national minimum wages or industry
or union agreed wages in any of the jurisdictions in which Titan Group operates could increase its labor costs and have a
material adverse effect on its business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We face costs associated with our post-retirement and post-employment obligations to employees which could have_**
**_an adverse effect on our financial condition._**

As of March 31, 2021, on a pro forma basis, our accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation was approximately
$91.9 million. The additional costs associated with these and other benefits to employees could have a material adverse effect
on our financial condition. In addition, in certain jurisdictions, these obligations may rank senior to the Guarantees in a
bankruptcy of the relevant Guarantor as a matter of law.

We operate a number of pension and other post-retirement benefit schemes funded by a range of assets which may
include property, derivatives, equities and/or bonds. The value of these assets is heavily dependent on the performance of
markets which are subject to volatility. The liability structure of the obligations to provide such benefits is also subject to market


-----

volatility in relation to its accounting valuation and management. Additional significant funding of our pension and other postretirement benefit obligations may be required if market underperformance is severe.

**_Titan Group is subject to an investigation by the European Commission relating to potential anti-competitive_**
**_behavior and the outcome of this investigation or future investigations could materially adversely affect Titan Group’s_**
**_business, financial condition and results of operations._**

In March 2015, the Bundeskartellamt, or German Federal Cartel Office (“FCO”), conducted unannounced inspections
of the premises of several metal packaging manufacturers, including one of Titan Group’s German subsidiaries. The local court
order authorizing the inspection cited FCO suspicions of anti-competitive agreements in the market for the supply of metal
packaging products. Titan Group conducted an internal investigation into the matter and discovered instances of inappropriate
conduct by certain employees of German subsidiaries of Titan Group. Titan Group cooperated with the FCO and submitted, in
September and October 2015, a leniency application with the FCO which disclosed the findings of its internal investigation to
date. In April 2018, the FCO discontinued its national investigation and referred the matter to the European Commission (the
“Commission”). Following the referral, Commission officials conducted unannounced inspections of the premises of several
metal packaging manufacturers, including Titan Group’s subsidiaries in Germany, France and the United Kingdom.

The Commission’s investigation is ongoing and, to date, the Commission has not officially charged Titan Group or
any of its subsidiaries with violations of competition law. Titan Group is cooperating with the Commission and submitted a
leniency application in April 2018. This application may lead to the reduction of possible future penalties. At this stage of the
investigation Titan Group believes that a loss is probable but is unable to predict the ultimate outcome of the Commission’s
investigation and is unable to estimate the loss or possible range of losses that could be incurred, and has therefore not recorded
a charge in connection with the actions by the Commission. If the Commission finds that Titan Group or any of its subsidiaries
violated competition law, fines levied by the Commission as well as third party damage claims by private enforcement, class
action or individual claims and any related costs and damages could be material to Titan Group’s operating results and cash
flows for the periods in which they are resolved or become reasonably estimable. In the Acquisition Agreement, Crown has
agreed to indemnify us for certain losses in connection with this investigation. See “The Business––Legal Proceedings.”

Finally, any attempt to expand production may attract additional scrutiny of European and other competition and antitrust regulators, and such an attempt may not succeed. In addition, Titan Group's size and prominence in the tinplate packaging
market may prompt heightened scrutiny by such regulators seeking to restrain anti-competitive market practices. Any additional
competition or anti-trust investigations could require significant legal expenditures and result in liabilities or adverse
governmental orders. Such developments could adversely affect Titan Group's business, financial condition and results of
