operations.

**_Titan Group has received questionnaires as part of an investigation of the French Competition Authority relating_**
**_to potential anticompetitive behavior with respect to the switch to bisphenol-A free cans in France and this investigation_**
**_could materially and adversely affect Titan Group's business, financial conditions and results of operations._**

In March 2018, the French Competition Authority started a preliminary investigation regarding possible
infringements to French competition law with respect to the switch to bisphenol-A free cans in France which implemented
legislation restricting the use of bisphenol-A in all recipients as of 1 January 2015. The French Syndicat National des Fabricants
_de Boîtes, a trade association representing food can suppliers in France of which Titan Group is a member, received a_
questionnaire from the French Competition Authority asking for information regarding the trade association’s activities in
relation to the development of BPA-NI cans. The French Competition Authority opened formal proceedings regarding possible
infringements of competition law in relation to the switch to bisphenol-free cans in France in September 2019. In the context
of the formal proceedings, the French Competition Authority sent, in January and February 2020, two questionnaires to Titan
Group relating to its activities, internal organization and identification of its different entities and their respective turnovers. In
January 2021, Titan Group received a request from the French Competition Authority asking for the permission to declassify
documents previously provided by Titan Group in response to the questionnaires received and Titan Group gave the French
Competition Authority the permission to do so.

The French Competition Authority's investigation is ongoing and, to date, Titan Group has not received any further
requests nor questionnaires from the French Competition Authority. At this stage of the investigation, Titan Group is unable to
predict the ultimate outcome of the French Competition Authority's investigation and is unable to estimate the loss that it could
incur. Should the Board of the French Competition Authority find that Titan Group or any of its subsidiary violated French
competition law, the fine levied by the French Competition Authority (the amount of which is determined on a case-by-case
basis depending notably on the seriousness of the infringement as well as its duration, but capped at 10% of the worldwide
turnover of the undertaking) could be material to Titan's Group's operating results and cash flows for the periods in which they


-----

are resolved or become reasonably estimable, as well as third party damage claims by private enforcement. In the Acquisition
Agreement, Crown has agreed to indemnify Titan Group for certain losses in connection with this investigation.

**_Titan Group is subject to costs and liabilities related to stringent environmental and health and safety standards._**

Laws and regulations relating to environmental protection and health and safety may increase Titan Group’s
operational costs and reduce its profitability. Titan Group's operations are subject to European, U.K. and other laws and
regulations governing the protection of the environment, including those relating to operating permits, treatment, storage and
disposal of waste, the use of chemicals, including regulated materials, in Titan Group's products and manufacturing process,
water supply and use, and discharges into water, emissions into the atmosphere, remediation of soil and groundwater
contamination, noise pollution, asbestos and other deleterious materials and protection of employee health and safety. Such
laws and regulations as subject to constant review by lawmakers and regulators, which may result in future regulations that
impose stricter environmental or employee safety requirements affecting Titan Group's operations.

Such laws and regulations impose additional requirements regarding consumer health and safety, such as potential
restrictions on the use of bisphenol-A, a starting material used to produce internal and external coatings for some food and
aerosol containers and metal closures. In Europe, certain nations, including Denmark, Belgium and France, have implemented
or considered implementing legislation restricting the use of bisphenol-A, including imposing product labeling requirements
or restrictions on the importation and placement in the market of packaging and utensils containing bisphenol-A, and the
European Food Safety Authority has recommended that the tolerable daily intake of bisphenol-A be lowered. Domestic and
international or other regulatory authorities could further restrict or prohibit the use of bisphenol-A in the future. In addition,
recent public reports, litigation and other allegations regarding the potential health hazards of bisphenol-A could contribute to
a perceived safety risk about Titan Group's products and adversely impact sales or otherwise disrupt Titan Group's business.
While Titan Group is exploring various alternatives to the use of bisphenol-A and conversion to alternatives is underway in
some applications, there can be no assurance Titan Group will be completely successful in its efforts or that the alternatives
will not be more costly to Titan Group.

Also, for example, future restrictions in some jurisdictions on air emissions of volatile organic compounds and the use
of certain paint and lacquering ingredients may require Titan Group to employ significant capital investments at some sites in
order to provide additional control equipment or process modifications. Titan Group’s operations and properties must comply
with these laws and regulations. In addition, a number of governmental authorities in Europe have introduced or are
contemplating enacting legal requirements, including emissions limitations, cap and trade systems or mandated changes in
energy consumption, in response to the potential impacts of climate change. Given the wide range of potential future climate
change regulations in the jurisdictions in which Titan Group operates, the potential impact to Titan Group's operations is
uncertain. In addition, the potential impact of climate change on Titan Group's operations is highly uncertain. The impact of
climate change may vary by geographic location and other circumstances, including weather patterns and any impact to natural
resources such as water.

A number of governmental authorities in Europe have enacted, or are considering, legal requirements relating to
product stewardship, including mandating recycling, the use of recycled materials and/or limitations on certain kinds of
packaging materials. Such developments may increase the costs of certain input materials used to manufacture Titan Group's
products.

Sites at which Titan Group has production and manufacturing facilities may have a long history of industrial activities
and may be, or have been in the past, engaged in activities involving the use of materials and processes that could give rise to
contamination and result in potential liability to investigate or remediate, as well as claims for alleged damage to persons,
property or natural resources, even if the activity which caused the contamination was legal at the time it occurred. Liability
may be imposed on us as owners, occupiers or operators of contaminated facilities. These legal requirements may apply to
contamination at sites that Titan Group currently or formerly owned, occupied or operated, or that were formerly, owned,
occupied or operated by companies Titan Group acquired or at sites where Titan Group has sent waste offsite for treatment or
disposal. Our closure of a site may accelerate the need to investigate and remediate any contamination at the site.

Titan Group requires a variety of permits to conduct its operations, including operating permits such as those required
under various laws, including E.U. Industrial Emissions Directive, water and trade effluent discharge permits, water abstraction
permits and waste permits. We are in the process of applying for, or renewing, permits at a number of our sites. Failure to obtain
and maintain the relevant permits could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.


-----

If Titan Group were to violate or fail to comply with applicable environmental laws and regulations or its permits, it
could become subject to criminal, civil and administrative sanctions and liabilities, including substantial fines and orders, or a
partial or total shutdown of its operations. Titan Group strives to mitigate risks related to environmental issues, however, there
can be no assurance that current or future environmental laws or liabilities will not have a material adverse effect on Titan
Group’s financial condition, liquidity or results of operations.

**_Demand for Titan Group's products could be affected by changes in laws and regulations applicable to food._**

Titan Group manufactures and sells metal packaging primarily for the food can market. As a result, many of Titan
Group's products come into direct contact with food. Accordingly, Titan Group's products must comply with various laws and
regulations for food applicable to its customers. Changes in such laws and regulations could negatively impact customers'
demand for Titan Group's products as they comply with such changes and/or require Titan Group to make changes to its
products. Such changes to Titan Group's products could include modifications to the coatings and compounds that Titan Group
uses, possibly resulting in the incurrence of additional costs.

**_We may be subject to losses that might be completely or partially uninsured._**

We maintain insurance policies with respect to certain operating risks, including product liability, damage to property
(including buildings, plants, machinery and stock, including as a result of catastrophic events such as fire, flood, storms and
earthquakes), industrial accidents, third-party liability, directors’ and officers’ liability, and cyber-crime.

There can be no assurance that the level of insurance Titan Group maintains is appropriate for the risks to its business
or adequate to cover all potential claims. Certain types of losses may not be covered by our insurance policies and may be
either completely or partially uninsurable or not insurable on commercially reasonable terms. A completely or partially
uninsured loss suffered by us could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Further, Titan Group may not be able to obtain future insurance coverage at current levels or at all, and its premiums
may increase significantly on the coverage that Titan Group maintains or obtains in the future. We anticipate renewal of its
insurance policies on an annual basis or other periodic basis. The cost of coverage may increase to an extent that Titan Group
may choose to reduce its policy limits, increase its deductibles or retentions, or agree to certain exclusions from its coverage.
Among other factors, the COVID-19 pandemic, adverse political developments, security concerns and natural disasters in any
country in which Titan Group operates may materially adversely affect available insurance coverage and result in increased
premiums for available coverage and additional exclusions from coverage.

**_Titan Group is subject to litigation risks which could negatively impact its operations and net income._**

Titan Group is involved in various litigation matters, and Titan Group anticipates that it will be involved in litigation
matters from time to time in the future. The risks inherent in our business expose us to litigation, including personal injury,
environmental litigation, contractual litigation with customers and suppliers, intellectual property litigation, tax or employment
disputes, insurance related lawsuits and product liability claims. In addition, Titan Group could incur substantial costs and fees
in defending itself or in asserting its rights in these actions. Titan Group is currently unable to determine the total expense or
possible loss, if any, that may ultimately be incurred in the resolution of such legal proceedings. Regardless of the ultimate
outcome of such legal proceedings, they could result in significant diversion of time by Titan Group's management. The results
of Titan Group's pending legal proceedings, including any potential settlements, are uncertain and the outcome of these disputes
may decrease its cash available for operations and investment, restrict its operations or otherwise negatively impact its business,
operating results, financial condition and cash flow. Existing or future material litigation, arbitration or other proceedings could
have adverse reputational and financial consequences for Titan Group and it may not have established adequate provisions for
any potential losses associated with such litigation or other proceedings not otherwise covered by insurance, which could have
a material adverse effect on Titan Group’s business, financial condition or results of operations.

**_The United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union and any future changes within or between the United_**
**_Kingdom and the European Union, respectively, may have a negative effect on Titan Group's financial condition and results_**
**_of operations._**

Approximately 12% of Titan Group's total 2020 revenue was derived from revenues generated in the United Kingdom,
and 5 of its 44 manufacturing facilities are located in the United Kingdom, as of December 31, 2020.

The relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union is governed by a Withdrawal Agreement
entered into at the end of January 2020, and a Trade and Cooperation Agreement, which took effect from January 1, 2021 (the


-----

"Brexit Agreements"). The Brexit Agreements provide for a zero tariff, zero quota arrangement on sales of goods and
agriproducts between the United Kingdom and the European Union. Customs duties on goods originating outside the European
Union or United Kingdom, or in the event that the zero tariff arrangements under the Brexit Agreements are amended or
suspended, might lead to additional costs for products and materials shipped from the United Kingdom to Europe or from
Europe to the United Kingdom, respectively. Further, required changes to Titan Group's business systems and processes in
order to comply with newly introduced customs procedures may lead to additional costs.

More generally, differences in standards or processes or risk aversion may mean that some businesses choose not to
serve other markets on a temporary or permanent basis, causing supplier disruption. Uncertainty remains regarding the impact
of the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union ("Brexit") and the Brexit Agreements on the United
Kingdom and Europe, including among commercial parties in the United Kingdom and the European Union, financial
institutions, suppliers and service providers and their respective customers. Any changes to the trading relationship between
the United Kingdom and the European Union arising from the Brexit Agreements may adversely affect the cost or timing of
imports, including key input materials used to manufacture the Group’s products.

Some of our customers are based in the United Kingdom and export outside the local United Kingdom market. These
customers may experience reduced demand or delays arising from these post-Brexit arrangements. Although Titan Group seeks
to export through channels where delays would be minimized, Titan Group has nonetheless experienced slight delays in the
transport of certain products, consumables and other materials particularly in relation to shipments from the United Kingdom
to the European Union. The impact of these delays, if prolonged, could adversely affect Titan Group’s business, financial
condition and results of operations.

Brexit may also have an adverse impact on Titan Group’s business, employees and customers in the United Kingdom.
In particular, the Brexit Agreements allow for the possibility of future changes in laws and regulations. Such changes could
include import, tax and employment laws and regulations, which could adversely impact the results of operations of Titan
Group’s United Kingdom business. For example, there is uncertainty with regard to the upcoming regulatory regime relating
to environmental permits and permissions, with such environmental permits and permissions currently governed by the EU
Industrial Emissions Directive (Directive 2010/75/EU). More burdensome requirements imposed by the new upcoming
regulatory regime could require that Titan Group commits additional resources to ensure compliance and although Titan Group
will use reasonable efforts to ensure such compliance, the introduction of new regulations increases the risk of non-compliance.

Further, continued political uncertainty as a result of Brexit may result in negative effects on credit markets, and
foreign direct investments in Europe and the United Kingdom. It may also result in volatility in the British pound foreign
exchange markets and interest rates.

Brexit could also lead to legal and regulatory uncertainty and politically divergent national laws and regulations as a
new relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union is defined and the United Kingdom determines which
European Union laws to replace or amend. Volatility in political, regulatory, economic or market conditions could adversely
affect employment rates, increase consumer and commercial bankruptcy filings, negatively impact national and local
economies, and cause other results that negatively affect household incomes.

The economic outlook could be further adversely affected by the risk that one or more European Union member states
could also leave the European Union, the risk of a demand for independence by Scotland or Northern Ireland, or the risk that
the euro as the single currency of any or all of the Eurozone member states could cease to exist. These developments, or the
perception that any of them could occur, may have a material adverse effect on the stability of global financial markets, and
could significantly reduce global market liquidity and restrict the ability of key market participants to operate in certain financial
markets. Asset valuations, currency exchange rates and credit ratings may be especially subject to increased market volatility.
These negative impacts could adversely affect Titan Group’s business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Titan Group is exposed to risks in relation to compliance with anti-corruption laws and regulations and economic_**
**_sanctions programs._**

Titan Group has operations spanning over 14 countries, that are subject to anti-corruption laws and sanctions
regulations concerning both private-sector and public-sector corruption in various jurisdictions where Titan Group does
business (collectively, “Anti-Corruption Laws”). Further, the nature of Company’s manufacturing and other business
operations may bring Titan Group, its employees and third parties acting on its behalf into contact with government officials,
including employees of state-owned business enterprises, who may be considered government officials under applicable AntiCorruption Laws and therefore represent a high risk for public-sector corruption. Although Titan Group has policies and
procedures that require compliance with applicable Anti-Corruption Laws, there can be no assurance that the policies and


-----

procedures will be followed at all times or effectively detect and prevent all violations of the applicable laws by one or more
of its employees, consultants, agents or partners for which Titan Group could be held responsible.

Titan Group is also subject to financial sanctions and export controls (collectively, “Trade Controls”) imposed by the
United Nations, the European Union, the U.S., the U.K., and other authorities with jurisdiction over its operations. These Trade
Controls will from time to time prohibit or restrict our ability to engage in transactions and dealings in certain countries and
with certain designated persons. Titan Group has policies and procedures designed to maintain compliance with Trade Controls,
and it is not aware of instances of non-compliance with United Nations, U.S., European Union, U.K. or other applicable Trade
Controls. Although Titan Group has policies and procedures that require compliance with applicable Trade Controls, there can
be no assurance that the policies and procedures will be followed at all times or effectively detect and prevent all violations of
the Trade Controls by one or more of its employees, consultants, agents or partners for which Titan Group could be held
responsible.

Violations of Anti-Corruption Laws or Trade Controls could subject Titan Group to significant penalties, including
civil or criminal fines and penalties, disgorgement of profits, injunctions, debarment from government contracting (and
termination of existing contracts), and related lawsuits and other remedial measures. Investigations of potential violations of
these laws and regulations can also be costly and divert management’s attention from the business. As such, violations and
potential violations of Anti-Corruption Laws or Trade Controls can have a significant impact on Titan Group’s reputation,
business, results of operation and financial condition.

**_Titan Group is subject to the effects of fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, which may reduce its net sales and_**
**_cash flow._**

Titan Group is exposed to fluctuations in foreign currencies as a significant portion of its consolidated net sales, costs,
assets and liabilities, are denominated in currencies other than US Dollar, including the British Sterling, and Euro. During the
year ended December 31, 2020, substantially all of our net sales were denominated in or linked to currencies other than the US
Dollar. As Titan Group currently prepares its financial statements in its reporting currency, the US Dollar, Titan Group must
currently translate the assets, liabilities, revenue and costs of all of its operations into US Dollar at then applicable exchange
rates. See “Management’s Discussion And Analysis Of Financial Condition And Results Of Operations.”

Going forward Titan Group will prepare its financial statements in Euro as its reporting currency. During the year
ended December 31, 2020, 26% of our net sales were denominated in or linked to currencies other than the Euro.
Correspondingly, Titan Group will translate the assets, liabilities, revenue and costs of all of its operations into Euro at then
applicable exchange rates. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.”

In addition to affecting the presentation of our financial results, volatility in exchange rates may increase the costs of
Titan Group’s products, impair the purchasing power of its customers in different markets, result in significant competitive
benefit to certain of its competitors who incur a material part of their costs in other currencies than it does, and increase its
hedging costs and limit its ability to hedge exchange rate exposure. In the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the
Unaudited Interim Consolidated Condensed Financial Statements, Titan Group translates local currency financial results into
US Dollar based on average exchange rates prevailing during a reporting period. During times of a strengthening US Dollar,
its reported international revenue and earnings have been reduced because the local currency will translate into fewer US
Dollars. Conversely, a weakening US Dollar will effectively increase the Dollar-equivalent of Titan Group's expenses and
liabilities denominated in foreign currencies. Going forward, the same dynamics will apply vis-à-vis the Euro. Although Titan
Group may use financial instruments such as foreign currency forwards from time to time to reduce its exposure to transactional
foreign exchange exposure in some cases, it may not elect or have the ability to implement hedges or, if it does implement
them, there can be no assurance that such agreements will achieve the desired effect.

**_Changes in accounting standards, taxation requirements and other laws could negatively affect Titan Group's_**
**_financial results._**

New accounting standards or pronouncements that may become applicable to Titan Group from time to time, or
changes in the interpretation of existing standards and pronouncements, could have a significant effect on Titan Group's
reported results for the affected periods. Titan Group is also subject to income tax in the numerous jurisdictions in which Titan
Group operates. Increases in income tax rates or other changes to tax laws could reduce Titan Group's after-tax income from
affected jurisdictions or otherwise affect Titan Group's tax liability.


-----

In addition, Titan Group's products are subject to import and excise duties and/or sales or value-added taxes in many
jurisdictions in which it operates. Increases in indirect taxes could affect Titan Group's products' affordability and therefore
reduce demand for its products.

**_Titan Group may have exposure to greater than expected tax liabilities resulting from tax disputes, tax audits,_**
**_adverse decisions by tax authorities or changes in tax treaties, laws, regulations or the interpretations thereof._**

The tax laws and regulations in the numerous jurisdictions in which Titan Group operates may be subject to change
and there may be changes in the content as well as in the interpretation and enforcement of tax law. As a result, Titan Group
may face increases in taxes payable if tax rates increase, or if tax laws and regulations are modified by the competent authorities
in an adverse manner. Any change in local or international tax rules, for example prompted by the implementation of the
OECD’s recommendations on Base Erosion and Profits Shifting (a global initiative to improve the fairness and integrity of tax
systems), or new challenges by tax authorities, may have an adverse effect on Titan Group’s tax positions and its financial
results.

In addition, tax laws and regulations could change and could be subject to changes in their interpretation and in the
application thereof. In particular, in the current macroeconomic environment, governmental authorities could decide to increase
tax rates, to eliminate existing tax exemptions, to expand tax bases, or to introduce new taxes. As a result, Titan Group could
undergo an increase in its tax burden if tax rates rise or if legislation or the interpretation thereof by the administration changes,
which could adversely affect Titan Group’s business, results of operations and financial condition and reduce the cash flow
available to service Titan Group’s indebtedness.

**_Certain tax rules could limit the ability of Titan Group to deduct interest for tax purposes, thus reducing the net_**
**_cash position of Titan Group._**

Certain interest deduction limitation rules applicable in the jurisdictions we operate in, including interest deduction
limitation rules that are based on European directives such as the Council Directive (EU) 2016/1164 of 12 July 2016 and
Council Directive (EU) 2017/952 of May 29, 2017 may limit Titan Group’s ability to deduct interest accrued on Titan Group’s
indebtedness for tax purposes and, as a consequence, may increase Titan Group’s tax burden, which could adversely affect
Titan Group’s business, results of operations and financial condition and reduce the cash flow available to service Titan Group’s
indebtedness.

**_Titan Group has a significant amount of goodwill that, if impaired in the future, would result in lower reported net_**
**_income and a reduction of its net worth._**

Impairment of Titan Group's goodwill would require a write down of goodwill, which would reduce Titan Group's net
income in the period of any such write down. Titan Group is required to evaluate goodwill reflected on its balance sheet at least
annually, or when circumstances indicate a potential impairment. If it determines that the goodwill is impaired, Titan Group
would be required to write off a portion or all of the goodwill.

**_The loss of Titan Group's intellectual property rights may negatively impact its ability to compete._**

If Titan Group is unable to maintain the proprietary nature of its technologies, its competitors may use its technologies
to compete with it. Titan Group has a number of patents covering various aspects of its products, including Orbit, Ecopeel and
Peelfit. Titan Group's patents may not withstand challenge in litigation, and patents do not ensure that competitors will not
develop competing products or infringe upon Titan Group's patents. Moreover, the costs of litigation to defend Titan Group's
patents could be substantial and may outweigh the benefits of enforcing its rights under its patents. Titan Group also relies on
trade secrets, know-how and other unpatented proprietary technology, and others may independently develop the same or
similar technology or otherwise obtain access to Titan Group's unpatented technology.

**_Titan Group’s business operations and financial position could be adversely affected by the coronavirus outbreak._**

The ongoing global outbreak of coronavirus, which was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization on
March 11, 2020 has caused and is continuing to cause business slowdowns and shutdowns and turmoil in the financial markets
both in Europe and abroad. Titan Group is closely monitoring the impact of COVID-19 on all aspects of its business and
geographies, including how it has impacted and will impact Titan Group’s employees, customers, suppliers and distribution
channels. The pandemic, as well as the quarantines and other governmental and non-governmental restrictions which have been
imposed throughout the world in an effort to contain or mitigate it, has created significant volatility, uncertainty and economic
disruption which may materially and adversely affect Titan Group’s results of operations, cash flows and financial position or


-----

Titan Group’s ability to execute its short- and long-term business strategies and initiatives. For example, governmental
authorities in many European countries have ordered, at various times over 2020 and the first half of 2021, the cessation of all
business activity which is deemed non-essential and there is a risk that these shutdown orders will be extended or expanded or
that similar shutdown orders will be implemented in other regions.

The magnitude of COVID-19’s ultimate impact on Titan Group will depend on numerous evolving factors, future
developments and cascading effects of the coronavirus pandemic that Titan Group is not able to predict, including: the severity
of the outbreak and the international actions that are being taken to contain and treat it; the duration of the outbreak and the
myriad of business restrictions being imposed as a result of it; governmental, business and other responses to the outbreak
(including limitations on Titan Group’s operations and/or mandates that Titan Group provide products or services); the extent
and duration of the effect of the outbreak on consumer confidence and spending, customer demand and buying patterns; the
promotion of “social distancing” and the adoption of lock-down orders and restrictions on exports affecting customers’ demand
for Titan Group’s products; the extent to which forced remote working arrangements reduce Titan Group’s ability to effectively
manage its global operations; the impact of the outbreak on Titan Group’s supply chain (including reductions in supply that
may result in an inability to meet customer demand); the impact of the outbreak on internal controls (including those over
financial reporting); the speed and success of vaccination efforts; any impairment in value of Titan Group’s tangible or
intangible assets which could be recorded as a result of a weaker economic conditions; and the effect of the ongoing disruption
in the capital markets on Titan Group’s ability to access capital on favorable terms and continue to meet its liquidity needs.
Moreover, employee absenteeism due to members of Titan Group’s workforce being quarantined or exposed to COVID-19
may impact Titan Group’s ability to meet staffing needs which, compounded with the effects of ongoing office and potential
factory closures, disruptions to ports and other shipping infrastructure, border closures, and other travel or health-related
restrictions, may in turn impair Titan Group in the manufacture, distribution and sale of its products.

In addition, while Titan Group cannot predict the magnitude of the impact that COVID-19 will have on its customers
and suppliers or their financial conditions, any material effect on Titan Group’s customers or suppliers could adversely impact
Titan Group. The impact of COVID-19 may also exacerbate other risk factors discussed, any of which could have a material
effect on Titan Group. For example, significant volatility in the equity markets could have a negative impact on the market
value of Titan Group's pension plan assets which may substantially increase Titan Group's future pension plan funding
requirements and could have a negative impact on Titan Group's results of operations, pension plan funded status and future
cash flows.

The extent of the impact of COVID-19 on Titan Group’s business is highly uncertain and difficult to predict, as
information is rapidly evolving with respect to the duration and severity of the pandemic. At this point, Titan Group cannot
reasonably estimate the duration and severity of the coronavirus outbreak or its overall impact on Titan Group’s business.

**_As Titan Group seeks to expand its business internationally, business and financial results could be materially_**
**_negatively affected by various risks resulting from its broad geographic scope of its operations._**

Titan Group’s sales to developing markets and areas such as Africa and the Middle East generated approximately 12%
of its consolidated net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. In some cases, countries in these regions have greater
political and economic volatility, greater vulnerability to infrastructure and labor disruptions, greater risk of acts of war, terrorist
acts, and civil unrest, greater risks of political interference and differing local customer product preferences and requirements
than Titan Group's other markets. Operating and seeking to expand business in a number of different regions and countries
exposes Titan Group to multiple and potentially conflicting cultural practices, business practices and legal and regulatory
requirements and risks that are subject to change and inconsistent application, including those related to tariffs and trade
barriers, investments, foreign currency exchange, currency devaluation, property ownership rights (including nationalization
or expropriation of privately-owned assets), taxation, repatriation of earnings, and regulation of advanced technologies. Such
expansion efforts may also use capital and other resources of Titan Group that could be invested in other areas. Expanding
business operations globally also increases exposure to currency fluctuations, which can materially affect Titan Group's
financial results. As emerging geographic markets become more important to Titan Group, its competitors are also seeking to
expand their production capacities and sales in these same markets, which may lead to industry overcapacity that could
adversely affect pricing, volumes and financial results in such markets. Although Titan Group is taking measures to adapt to
these changing circumstances and risks, Titan Group's reputation and/or business results could be negatively affected should
these efforts prove unsuccessful. Any of these conditions could have material adverse effect on Titan Group's business,
prospects, financial condition and results of operations.


-----

**_The downturn in certain global economies could have adverse effects on Titan Group._**

The downturn in certain global economies in which Titan Group operates could have significant adverse effects on
Titan Group’s operations, including as a result of any the following:

     - downturns in the business or financial condition of any of Titan Group’s key customers or suppliers, potentially
resulting in customers’ inability to pay Titan Group’s invoices as they become due or at all, or suppliers’ failure
to fulfill their commitments;

     - potential losses associated with hedging activity by Titan Group for the benefit of Titan Group’s customers
including counterparty risk associated with such hedging activity, or costs associated with changing suppliers;

     - a decline in the fair value of Titan Group’s pension assets or a decline in discount rates used to measure Titan
Group’s pension obligations, potentially requiring Titan Group to make significant additional contributions to its
pension plans to meet prescribed funding levels, see also “Risks Relating to Titan Group's Business and Industry
—We face costs associated with our post-retirement and post-employment obligations to employees which could
_have an adverse effect on our financial condition.”;_

     - the deterioration of any of the lending parties under Titan Group’s senior secured revolving credit facilities or the
creditworthiness of the counterparties to Titan Group’s derivative transactions, which could result in such parties’
failure to satisfy their obligations under their arrangements with Titan Group;

     - noncompliance with the covenants under Titan Group’s indebtedness as a result of a weakening of Titan Group’s
financial position or results of operations, see also “Risks Relating to the Notes—Restrictive covenants in the debt
_agreements governing Titan Group’s current or future indebtedness could restrict Titan Group’s operating and_
_financial flexibility.”; and_

     - the lack of currently available funding sources, which could have a negative impact upon the liquidity of Titan
Group as well as that of its customers and suppliers.

**_Titan Group may not be able to manage its anticipated growth, and it may experience constraints or inefficiencies_**
**_caused by unanticipated acceleration and deceleration of customer demand._**

Unanticipated acceleration and deceleration of customer demand for Titan Group's products may result in constraints
or inefficiencies related to Titan Group's manufacturing, sales force, implementation resources and administrative
infrastructure. Such constraints or inefficiencies may adversely affect Titan Group as a result of delays, lost potential product
sales or loss of current or potential customers due to their dissatisfaction. Similarly, over-expansion, including as a result of
overcapacity due to expansion by Titan Group's competitors, or investments in anticipation of growth that does not materialize,
or develops more slowly than Titan Group expects, could harm Titan Group's financial results and result in overcapacity.

To manage Titan Group's anticipated future growth effectively, Titan Group must continue to enhance its
manufacturing capabilities and operations, information technology infrastructure, and financial and accounting systems and
controls. Organizational growth and scale-up of operations could strain its existing managerial, operational, financial and other
resources. Titan Group's growth requires significant capital expenditures and may divert financial resources from other projects,
such as the development of new products or enhancements of existing products or reduction of Titan Group's outstanding
indebtedness. If Titan Group's management is unable to effectively manage Titan Group's growth, its expenses may increase
more than expected, its revenue could grow more slowly than expected and it may not be able to achieve its research and
development and production goals, any of which could have a material effect on its business, operating results or financial
condition.

**_Titan Group’s business requires ongoing capital expenditures, which it may be unable to fund._**

Our business requires ongoing capital expenditures and our growth strategy may require significant capital
expenditures. Titan Group may not be able to make such capital expenditures if it does not generate sufficient cash flow from
operations, have funds available for borrowing under its credit facilities to cover these capital expenditure requirements or if
Titan Group were restricted from incurring additional debt to cover such expenditures or as a result of a combination of these
factors. If Titan Group is unable to meet its capital expenditure plans, Titan Group may not be able to maintain its manufacturing
capacity, which may negatively impact its competitive position and, ultimately, its revenues and profitability.


-----

**_Information technology (“IT”) interruptions, shutdowns, malfunctions, security threats and more sophisticated_**
**_and targeted computer crime could pose a risk to our systems, networks, products, solutions and services. Moreover, the_**
**_establishment of a standalone IT function could exacerbate these risks and lead to increased costs._**

Titan Group’s IT systems, or any third party’s system on which Titan Group relies, could fail on their own accord or
may be vulnerable to a variety of interruptions or shutdowns, including interruptions or shutdowns due to natural disasters,
power outages or telecommunications failures, hacker or terrorist attacks, negligent or malicious activities of employees or
failures during the process of upgrading or replacing software or hardware. Increased global IT security threats and more
sophisticated and targeted computer crime also pose a risk to the security of our systems and networks and the confidentiality,
availability and integrity of our data. We have a number of shared service centers where many of our IT systems are concentrated
and any disruption at such location could impact our business within the operating zones served by the impacted service center.
In addition, we are considering upgrades to our existing global enterprise resource planning (ERP) system, which will face
similar threats and vulnerabilities as traditional IT platforms. In addition, there can be no assurances that we will be successful
in implementing these upgrades or that their implementation will not result in disruption to its business.

While Titan Group attempts to mitigate these risks by employing measures, including employee training,
comprehensive monitoring of its networks and systems, and maintenance of backup and protective systems, its systems,
networks, products, solutions and services and those of its third-party vendors and service providers, are vulnerable to security
incidents including, but not limited to, computer hacking, breaches, acts of vandalism or theft, computer viruses and other
malware, including ransomware or other forms of cyber-attack, misplaced or lost data, programming and/or human errors or
other similar events. A party, whether internal or external, that is able to circumvent our security systems could, among other
things, misappropriate or misuse sensitive or confidential information, personally identifiable information or other proprietary
information, or cause significant interruptions in our operations. Internal or external parties may attempt to circumvent our
security systems, and may in the future experience external attacks on our network such as reconnaissance attacks, denial of
service attempts and malicious software or phishing attacks. Techniques used to circumvent security systems frequently change
and can be highly sophisticated. As a result, detection of such attacks may not be recognized until such an attack has already
been launched against a target. In addition, such attacks may originate from less regulated, remote areas around the world and
Titan Group may be unable to proactively address all possible techniques or implement adequate preventive measures.

Depending on the nature and scope of the incident, such threats could potentially lead to the compromise of
confidential information, improper use of our systems and networks, manipulation and destruction of data, defective products,
harm to individuals or property, contractual or regulatory actions and fines, penalties and potential liabilities, production
downtimes and operational disruptions, which in turn could adversely affect our reputation, competitiveness and results of
operations. Data protection laws are evolving and present compliance challenges, which may increase our costs, affect our
competitiveness and could expose us to substantial fines or other penalties.

Furthermore, in connection with the carve-out from Crown, Titan Group will transition its information technology
landscape from one embedded within Crown’s systems to a new, stand-alone platform. The transition process is expected to
involve material costs and expenditures and could involve or result in delays, malfunctions or other issues as more fully set
forth under the caption “—Risks Relating to the Acquisition—Titan Group’s ability to operate its business effectively may suffer
_if it is unable to cost-effectively establish its own administrative and other support functions in order to operate as a standalone_
_company after the expiration of the Transitional Services Agreement with the Crown Group.” As Titan Group builds its_
information technology infrastructure and transitions its data to its own systems, it may exacerbate any of the aforementioned
risks and incur substantial additional costs and experience temporary business interruptions.

We also face risks associated with security breaches affecting third parties that conduct business with us or our
customers and others who interact with our data. While Titan Group maintains insurance that covers certain security incidents,
it may not carry appropriate insurance or maintain sufficient coverage to compensate for all potential liability. Additionally, the
costs incurred to remediate any data security incident could be substantial.

**_A breach of data protection regulations may result in significant fines and penalties, ban on processing, affect our_**
**_reputation with customers and adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations._**

In the conduct of its business, Titan Group increasingly processes, collects, uses, transmits and stores data in its
technology systems. This data includes confidential information belonging to us, our customers and other business partners, as
well as information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person, including our employees. Consequently, our business
is subject to a number of laws and regulations governing data privacy and security, including with respect to the processing,
collection, storage, use, transmission, sharing, and protection of personal data and other consumer data. Such laws and
regulations may be inconsistent among countries or conflict with other rules.


-----

For example, the European Union has adopted increasingly comprehensive and complex data protection legislation
and there has been a recent trend toward more stringent enforcement of requirements regarding protection and confidentiality
of personal data. The EU’s General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”) imposes strict requirements on controllers and
processors of personal data including, for example, higher standards for obtaining consent from individuals to process their
personal data, more robust disclosures to individuals and a strengthened individual data rights regime, shortened timelines for
data breach notifications. The law is also developing rapidly and in July 2020, the Court of Justice of the European Union
limited how organizations could lawfully transfer personal data from the EU to other jurisdictions. Data protection authorities
and competent courts from the different member states of the European Union may interpret or enforce the legislation
differently, which adds to this complexity, and data protection is a dynamic field where guidance is often revised, sometimes
with limited, if any, regard to legacy equipment or systems in use. Should Titan Group be found to be not in compliance with
data protection rules and regulations across the European Union, including the GDPR, Titan Group could be subject to
substantial monetary forfeitures, a ban on processing data or other penalties. Any unauthorized access to information stored by
us or by a third party, intentionally or accidentally, including failure to detect such access or to notify a supervisory authority
or data subjects in a timely manner, may cause damage to our reputation, constitute infringement of administrative and criminal
law and grant the affected persons a right to damage claims against us. Relatedly, following the departure of the United Kingdom
from the EU after the expiry of the transition period, the United Kingdom will operate a separate but similar regime to the EU
that allows for substantial fines.

In addition, given the global nature of its business, Titan Group is subject to data protection legislation in the countries
in which it operates. New and increasingly restrictive data protection regulations are being implemented globally, and Titan
Group must ensure that it is in compliance with these laws. Though Titan Group seeks to continuously improve its internal
systems to keep up with such changes in law in the countries in which it has operations, Titan Group can provide no assurance
that legislation will be followed at all times or that Titan Group will effectively detect and prevent violations of the applicable
laws by one or more of our employees, consultants, agents or partners and, as a result, Titan Group could be subject to substantial
penalties that could have a material adverse effect on its business, financial condition and results of operations.

Risks Relating to the Acquisition

**_Titan Group has no operating history as a standalone company and it may not be successful in implementing its_**
**_strategy as a standalone business._**

Our ability to successfully execute our growth strategy depends in large part on our ability to realize the anticipated
benefits from the separation from Crown, including (i) new markets and growth opportunities; (ii) procurement optimization;
(iii) manufacturing optimization; and (iv) commercial excellence and continuous improvement initiatives.

There are significant risks associated with the separation and there can be no assurance that Titan Group will be able
to achieve anticipated efficiencies following the separation from Crown. In particular, we may encounter challenges to business
continuity while central functions and delays or overruns in the implementation of the standalone IT systems.

In many respects, Titan Group will be dependent on Crown to manage these risks and operate the Titan Group business
on a transitional basis pursuant to the Transitional Services Agreement. However, there can be no assurance that the services
provided under the Transitional Services Agreement will meet our requirements in a timely and effective manner. It is also
possible that Titan Group may need to operate under the Transitional Services Agreement for longer than expected if Titan
Group is not able to implement current plans to build the relevant stand-alone business functions in a timely manner, as it may
be difficult for Titan Group to replace, or undertake on its own, the services provided under the Transitional Services
Agreement, at reasonable costs or at all.

A failure to implement Titan Group’s cost optimization and growth strategies, in whole or in part, including due to its
inability to realize the anticipated benefits from its separation from Crown and to successfully transition from its dependence
on the Transitional Services Agreement with Crown, may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition
and results of operations.

**_The consent of certain customers of and suppliers to Titan Group is required to transfer their agreements and_**
**_working capital arrangements to the Issuer._**

The consent of certain counterparties to agreements of Titan Group and certain of their respective material customers
and suppliers are required to transfer those agreements to us. If these consents are not obtained, the business conducted by Titan
with these customers and suppliers may be curtailed or the terms under which Titan Group supplies to or buys from these
customers may change, which could have an adverse effect on our revenues and costs following the Acquisition. We also rely


-----

on such counterparties for trade finance to meet our working capital needs, and are in the process of rolling over certain existing
factoring and receivables financings. Therefore, even if such counterparties consent to transfer such agreements to us, if they
do not continue to provide us with the trade finance arrangements Titan Group has historically benefited from, there is a risk
that our working capital could be insufficient for the needs of our business. Additional working capital may not be available to
us on commercially reasonable terms, or at all. The Acquisition Agreement provides that if any of these consents are not
obtained before the Completion Date, Titan Group and Crown will cooperate with each other to put in place arrangements that
will give Titan Group the benefits and burdens of the agreements for which consents have not been obtained before the
Completion Date, but there can be no assurance that these arrangements will provide Titan Group with the same level of benefits
under these agreements as it would receive if these contracts had actually been assigned to Titan Group.

**_We are exposed to risks related to our supplier financing arrangements which may terminate at completion or_**
**_shortly following the Acquisition._**

Titan Group is party to several supply chain financing arrangements, in which a financial institution fulfils our
suppliers’ trade receivables on our behalf and we profit from extended payment terms. To the extent that these arrangements
are terminated in connection with, or following the Acquisition, our financial condition, results of operations, cash flows and
liquidity could be materially adversely affected by shortened payment terms, strains on liquidity and working capital
insufficiency.

**_The Acquisition is subject to receipt of certain regulatory approvals, which may entail delays or restrictions on_**
**_operating the Titan Group going forward that could materially adversely affect the business, financial condition and results_**
**_of operations._**

Before the Acquisition may be consummated, approvals or consents must be obtained from the EU competition
authority under applicable antitrust and competition laws. There can be no assurance that this required approval will be obtained
(or waiting periods will expire or terminate) on a timely basis. While the Acquisition Agreement provides indemnities with
respect to certain antitrust matters, there can be no assurance that such indemnities will be sufficient to compensate the Issuer
or Titan Group for any loss suffered in connection therewith.

In addition, the regulatory approvals may entail restrictions or required remedies to operating the Titan Group going
forward that could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_The Acquisition is subject to successful completion of required works council consultations._**

Completion of the Acquisition is subject to completion of consultations with Titan Group’s works councils in France
and the Netherlands. The works councils have a right of consultation on proposed material actions of certain legal entities
within Titan Group, including certain Post-Completion Guarantors, such as contemplated acquisitions, dispositions, financing
arrangements (including the granting of guarantees or security), joint ventures and dismissals and appointments of directors. In
addition, works councils have a right of consultation on employment-related and labor-related matters. As a result, Titan Group
will need to complete the consultation processes in France and the Netherlands in respect of the local aspects of the Transactions
prior to the completion of the Acquisition. The satisfactory completion of these consultations, the consummation of the
Acquisition and the provision of guarantees by Titan Group entities which do not obtain any required consents from their works
councils, may not occur in a timely manner or at all. Please see “Summary—The Transactions—The Acquisition.”

**_The interests of the Sponsor may conflict with your interests._**

The Sponsor has and will continue to have, directly or indirectly, the power to affect the legal and capital structure as
well as the ability to elect and change the management and to approve other changes to operations and to influence the outcome
of matters requiring action by the Sponsor. The Sponsor’s interests in certain circumstances may conflict with the interests of
the holders of the Notes, particularly if Titan Group encounters financial difficulties or is unable to pay its debts when due. For
example, the Sponsor could vote to cause Titan Group to incur additional indebtedness. The Sponsor is in the business of
making investments in companies and may acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly or indirectly with us.
The Sponsor may also pursue acquisition opportunities that are complementary to Titan Group’s business and, as a result, those
acquisition opportunities may not be available to us. In addition, the Sponsor may hold interests in suppliers or customers of
Titan Group. The Sponsor and their affiliates could also have an interest in pursuing divestitures (including one or more
divestitures of all or part of our business or sales of our shares which would result in changes to our shareholding structure),
financings, dividend distributions or other transactions that, in their judgment, could enhance their equity investments, although
such transactions might involve risks to the holders of the Notes.


-----

**_Crown Group may compete with us in the future, which may have an adverse effect on our financial condition and_**
**_results of operations._**

While the Shareholders Agreement that will be entered into with Crown and Titan Group will restrict the ability of
Crown and its respective subsidiaries from competing with Titan Group’s business, it will not prohibit Crown and its
subsidiaries from engaging and participating in any capacity in the business of developing, manufacturing, marketing or selling
containers for the beverage market. The scope of the non-compete is also limited to the development, manufacture, marketing
or sale of metal food or specialty cans (including aerosol cans), in each case, as developed, manufactured, marketed and sold
by Titan Group on the Completion Date. Lastly, the non-compete is subject to expiration under certain conditions set out in the
Shareholders Agreement, most notably once Crown is no longer a shareholder of Titan Group. If Titan Group experiences
significant competition from Crown in the future, it could have a material adverse effect on its financial condition and results
of operations.

**_Titan Group’s ability to operate its business effectively may suffer if it is unable to cost-effectively establish its own_**
**_administrative and other support functions in order to operate as a standalone company after the expiration of the_**
**_Transitional Services Agreement with the Crown Group._**

We partially rely on administrative and other resources of the Crown Group, including information technology,
accounting, finance, human resources, procurement and legal to operate our business. In connection with the Acquisition, Titan
Group expects to enter into a mutual transitional services agreement with Crown to retain the ability for specified periods to
use these Crown resources. See “Related Party Transactions—Related Party Transactions—Transitional Services Agreement.”
These services may not be provided at the same level as when Titan Group was part of Crown, and Titan Group may not be
able to obtain the same benefits that it received prior to the Acquisition. These services may not be sufficient to meet Titan
Group’s needs, and after its mutual services agreement with Crown expires, Titan Group may not be able to replace these
services at all or obtain these services at prices and on terms as favorable as Titan Group currently has with Crown. We will
need to create our own administrative and other support systems or contract with third parties to replace Crown’s systems. In
addition, Titan Group has received informal support from Crown, which may not be addressed in the mutual Transitional
Services Agreement Titan Group expects to enter into with Crown on the Completion Date, and the level of this informal
support may diminish as Titan Group becomes a more independent company. Any failure or significant downtime in our own
administrative systems or in Crown’s administrative systems during the transitional period could result in unexpected costs,
impact our results and/or prevent us from paying our suppliers or employees and performing other administrative services on
a timely basis.

Because Titan Group has not operated as a stand-alone company in the past, Titan Group may need to acquire assets,
obtain business services and hire employees in addition to those transferred by Crown in connection with the separation.
Moreover, as a smaller company with a different ownership structure than Crown, Titan Group may have difficulty retaining
employees who are transferred pursuant to the separation. We may face difficulty integrating newly acquired assets, newly
contracted services and newly hired employees into the business. In particular, Titan Group has a large number of staffing
vacancies relative to the positions that are expected to be required to be filled once the Transitional Services Agreement
terminates and the separation is fully completed. If Titan Group is unable to retain, recruit, hire and train a sufficient number
of qualified individuals to fill these vacancies, or if Titan Group is only able to do so at higher than expected cost due to
competition or any other reason, its ability to successfully operate as a stand-alone business will be compromised.

**_Following the separation, Titan Group may experience increased costs resulting from a decrease in its purchasing_**
**_power relative to the purchasing power it possessed when it was owned by Crown._**

Historically, Titan Group has been able to take advantage of Crown’s economies of scale and purchasing power in
purchasing raw materials, marketing and distribution services, technology and corporate services, including insurance, legal
and tax services, employee benefit support, finance and treasury functions, and audit services. Following Titan Group’s
separation from Crown pursuant to the Transactions, Titan Group will be a smaller and less diversified company than Crown,
and will not have access to financial and other resources comparable to those of Crown prior to the separation. As a separate,
stand-alone company, Titan Group may be unable to obtain the foregoing goods and services at prices and on terms as favorable
as those available to Titan Group prior to the separation, which could have a material adverse effect on its business, financial
condition and results of operations.


-----

**_Following the separation, Titan Group may need to offer customers increased discounts, lose distribution and_**
**_potentially lose volumes resulting from a decrease in its selling power relative to Titan Group’s selling power when it was_**
**_owned by Crown._**

As a smaller company, Titan Group may have a reduced ability to obtain favorable pricing or trade terms from the
customers who purchase its products. Some customers may take advantage of the fact that Titan Group is a smaller business to
induce Titan Group to offer them additional discounts or other investments.

Additionally, following the separation, Titan Group will not be able to rely on Crown’s diversification, earnings,
assets, cash flow or credit, and will be responsible for obtaining and maintaining sufficient working capital and servicing its
own debt. There is a risk that market fluctuations and other events may adversely impact Titan Group more significantly than
if it were still part of Crown.

**_The Issuer does not control Titan Group until the consummation of the Acquisition._**

The Issuer not currently own Titan Group and the Issuer will not acquire Titan Group until the consummation of the
Acquisition, which is expected to take place in the third quarter of 2021, subject to antitrust clearances and other conditions.
The Issuer cannot assure you that during the interim period the business of Titan Group will be operated in the same way the
Issuer would operate it. Any of the risks associated with the Issuer’s lack of control over Titan Group until the consummation
of the Acquisition could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position or results of operations.

In addition, prior to the Completion Date, Titan Group will not be subject to the covenants described in “Description
_of the Notes.” As such, the Issuer cannot assure you that, prior to such date, Titan Group will not take an action that would_
otherwise have been prohibited had such covenants been applicable to it.

Risks Relating to our Financial Information

**_We have no operating history as a standalone company._**

The Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements
included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum have been prepared specifically for the purpose of facilitating the Offering.
The businesses, operations, assets and liabilities comprising Titan Group have not in the past operated as a separate stand-alone
entity or group, and, therefore, the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined
Financial Statements are not necessarily indicative of future results of those businesses. The Audited Combined Financial
Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements may not necessarily reflect what its results
of operations, financial condition and cash flows would have been had Titan Group operated as a separate, stand-alone company
or reporting segment during the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, the Audited Combined
Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements do not reflect the implementation
of the separation or management’s target operating model, which differs in substantial respects from the manner in which the
business has been operated under Crown.

The historical costs and expenses reflected in Titan Group’s Audited Combined Financial Statements and the
Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements include an allocation for certain corporate functions historically
provided by Crown, including legal, finance, human resources and other administrative functions. These costs benefit multiple
or all of Crown’s businesses, including Titan Group, and are allocated to Titan Group using an allocation methodology primarily
based on a percentage of sales. We believe the costs of these functions on a stand-alone basis will differ substantially from costs
allocated historically.

Moreover, the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial
Statements do not reflect the costs of borrowing funds as a separate entity. The balance sheet information in the Audited
Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements presented in this
Offering Memorandum was derived from Crown’s centralized financial information. It includes items that are directly
attributable and/or separately identifiable to Titan Group’s business together with an allocation of relevant balances from Crown
to Titan Group for those items that were not directly attributable or separately identifiable. A number of estimates, judgements
and assumptions were made for the purpose of allocating those items that were not directly attributable and/or separately
identifiable. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” The balance sheet of the standalone business once the
separation from Crown is complete will differ substantially from the historic allocated balance sheet in many specific areas,
including working capital, debt, equity, intangible assets amongst others.


-----

The Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements
and the other historical financial information included in this Offering Memorandum do not necessarily indicate what Titan
Group’s results of operations, financial condition, cash flows or costs and expenses will be in the future. The adjustments made
to arrive at the pro forma and adjusted financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum reflect, among other
things, changes in Titan Group’s funding, operational model and overheads that are expected to result from its separation from
Crown. However, there can be no assurance that these adjustments will reflect its funding requirements and operating costs as
a separate, stand-alone company.

For a complete description of the accounting principles followed in preparing the Audited Combined Financial
Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements, please see “Notes to Combined Financial
_Statements—Summary of Significant Accounting Policies.”_

**_Our calculation of Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA are based on assumptions that may_**
**_prove to be inaccurate._**

Our calculations of Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA are based on several assumptions that may
prove to be inaccurate.

We calculate Adjusted EBITDA by applying adjustments for non-operating or non-recurring items to EBITDA. We
calculate Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA by adjusting Titan Group’s Adjusted EBITDA to take account of the impact of savings
expected to be realized in connection with the procurement of raw materials, in particular tinplate, through inter alia negotiation
of price discounts in place of long payment terms and intensifying cross-functional cooperation to harmonize specifications of
raw materials.

In anticipation of becoming a stand-alone entity, Titan Group has entered into negotiations with third-party service
providers. We have also engaged several consultants and industry experts to assist us in the analysis of our anticipated cost
structure. Our assessments and estimates underlying our calculations of Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
are based on these expected contracts, meetings and discussions, the advice of such industry experts and consultants,
benchmarking against other companies within our industry and the industry experience of our management team. The expenses
that Titan Group estimates that it will incur through internal operations and with third-party service providers are based on
several assumptions, including assumptions regarding the volumes of services Titan Group will require from such third-party
service providers, the price at which such services will be offered, the number of employees Titan Group will require to operate
as a stand-alone entity and the salaries and benefits Titan Group will be required to pay such employees.

Titan Group cannot assure you that these assumptions will prove to be accurate. Furthermore, given these
uncertainties, Titan Group cannot assure you that the performance improvements reflected in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
will be reached.

Some of our estimates of volumes are based on volumes that are implied from Crown’s historical allocations of
expenses to our business, which may not be accurate or fairly predict future costs and/or volumes. Where Titan Group anticipate
entering into an agreement with a third-party service provider, but do not yet have an executed contract, Titan Group based its
assumptions on both the price at which Titan Group expect such services will be provided, as well as the volumes of services
that Titan Group expects that it will require. Titan Group cannot assure you that its assumptions regarding such expenses will
prove to be accurate.

In calculating Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Titan Group also assumed that, after the expiration of the transition
period, Titan Group will no longer receive services from Crown under the Transition Services Agreement. Titan Group’s ability
to transition from the services Crown will provide to it during the transition period is subject to several risks and uncertainties,
including those described here, and Titan Group cannot assure you that it will not require services from Crown after the
transition period.

**_The Financial Statements are based on U.S. GAAP and there may be differences between our financial position_**
**_and results of operations prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP and IFRS. In addition, should Titan Group decide to_**
**_adopt IFRS as its accounting reporting method, this could potentially result in material changes to certain of its financial_**
**_information from the information presented in this Offering Memorandum._**

The Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements
included in this Offering Memorandum are based on U.S. GAAP, which differs in certain respects from IFRS. We have not
presented a reconciliation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined


-----

Financial Statements to IFRS in this Offering Memorandum. Because there are differences between U.S. GAAP and IFRS,
there could be certain significant differences in our results of operations, cash flows and financial position, including levels of
indebtedness, under IFRS. In addition, Titan Group may adopt IFRS in the near future, which could potentially result in changes
to its results of operations, cash flows and financial position from the amounts presented in this Offering Memorandum. These
changes could result from, among other things, the different possible approaches toward impairment under IFRS and the
requirement to assess our assets and goodwill for impairment as part of the conversion from U.S. GAAP to IFRS. For a
discussion of the certain significant differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP, see Annex A.

Risks Relating to the Notes

**_Investors’ right to receive payments on the Notes and Guarantees is contractually and effectively subordinated to_**
**_certain of Titan Group’s indebtedness and obligations, including borrowings under the Credit Facilities Agreement, possible_**
**_future borrowings as well as indebtedness and obligations of Titan Group’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes._**

The Notes and the Guarantees will be contractually and effectively subordinated to the prior payment in full of Titan
Group’s and the Guarantors’ existing and future indebtedness that is senior in right of payment to the Notes, including its
obligations in respect of the Credit Facilities Agreement, structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the
subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not guarantee the Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors and other obligations
incurred in the ordinary course of business and effectively subordinated to all of the Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness
that is secured by liens that do not secure the Notes or that secure the Notes on a junior basis, to the extent of the value of such
property and assets securing such indebtedness. Because of the liens on the assets securing borrowings under the Credit
Facilities Agreement, in the event of the bankruptcy, winding-up, reorganization, liquidation or dissolution of the borrowers or
any guarantor of such indebtedness, the assets of the borrowers or guarantors would be available to pay obligations under the
Notes offered hereby and other unsecured obligations only after payments had been made on the borrowers’ or the guarantors’
secured indebtedness. Sufficient assets may not remain after these payments have been made to make any payments on the
Notes offered hereby and Titan Group’s other unsecured obligations, including payments of interest when due. Holders of the
Notes offered hereby will participate ratably with all holders of other unsecured obligations that are deemed to be of the same
class as the Notes offered hereby, and potentially with all of Titan Group’s other general creditors, based upon the respective
amounts owed to each holder or creditor, in Titan Group’s remaining assets. As a result, holders of the Notes offered hereby
may receive less ratably than holders of other indebtedness. In addition, all payments on the Notes and the Guarantees will be
prohibited in the event of a payment default on Titan Group’s secured indebtedness (including borrowings under the Credit
Facilities Agreement). See “Description of Certain Financing And Guarantee Arrangements.”

In addition, the Indenture will also provide that, except under very limited circumstances, only the Trustee will have
standing to bring an enforcement action in respect of the Notes and the Guarantees. Moreover, the Intercreditor Agreement and
the Indenture will restrict the rights of holders of the Notes to initiate insolvency proceedings or take legal actions against each
of the Guarantors under the Indenture and by accepting any Note each such holder will be deemed to have agreed to these
restrictions. As a result of these restrictions, holders of the Notes will have limited remedies and recourse in the event of a
default by the Issuer or a Guarantor under the Indenture.

**_The substantial indebtedness of Titan Group could materially adversely affect our business, financial position and_**
**_results of operations and prevent it from fulfilling its obligations under its indebtedness._**

Upon consummation of the Transactions, the Titan Group will have substantial outstanding indebtedness. As a result
of Titan Group’s substantial indebtedness, a significant portion of Titan Group’s cash flow will be required to pay interest and
principal on its outstanding indebtedness, and Titan Group may not generate sufficient cash flow from operations, or have
sufficient future borrowings available to enable it to repay its indebtedness or to fund other liquidity needs. Titan Group’s
indebtedness includes the Credit Facilities Agreement and the Notes.

The substantial indebtedness of Titan Group could:

     - make it more difficult for Titan Group and its subsidiaries to satisfy their obligations with respect to the Notes
and other debt and liabilities;

     - increase Titan Group’s vulnerability to general adverse economic and industry conditions, including rising interest
rates;


-----

     - restrict Titan Group from making strategic acquisitions or exploiting business opportunities, including any
planned expansion in emerging markets;

     - limit Titan Group’s ability to make capital expenditures both domestically and internationally in order to grow
