Finally, there is some uncertainty under the applicable laws of each jurisdiction as to whether obligations to beneficial
owners of the Notes that are not identified as registered holders in, nor are directly parties to, a guarantee (including the
Guarantees) will be validly secured and/or can be enforced. Due to the laws and other jurisprudence governing the creation and
perfection of guarantees and the enforceability of the latter, the Intercreditor Agreement will provide for the creation of “parallel
debt” obligations in favor of the relevant Security Agent (“Parallel Debt”) mirroring the obligations of, inter alia, the relevant
guarantor owed to holders of the Notes under or in connection with the Indenture, as applicable (“Principal Obligations”). All
or part of the guarantees (including the Guarantees) will be granted to the Security Agent as guarantees for the Parallel Debt
and will not directly secure the Principal Obligations, if permitted by local law. Under the provisions of the Intercreditor
Agreement, the Parallel Debt will be at all times in the same amount and payable at the same time as the Principal Obligations
and any payment in respect of the Principal Obligations shall discharge the corresponding Parallel Debt and any payment in
respect of the Parallel Debt shall discharge the corresponding Principal Obligations. In respect of the guarantees granted to
secure the Parallel Debt, the holders of the Notes will not have direct guarantees and will not be entitled to take enforcement
actions in respect of such guarantees except through the Security Agent. Therefore, the holders of the Notes will bear the risk
of insolvency or bankruptcy of the Security Agent. In addition, the Parallel Debt construct in financing transactions, including
credit facilities and bond issuances, has generally not been tested under all each jurisdiction, and to the extent that the guarantees
in the Guarantees created to secure the Parallel Debt construct are not validly granted, are unenforceable or are successfully
challenged by other parties, holders of the Notes will not receive any proceeds from an enforcement of such guarantees.

The liabilities and obligations under the Guarantee granted by any French Guarantor (as defined below) are subject to
(i) certain exceptions, including to the extent of any obligations which would constitute prohibited financial assistance within


-----

the meaning of Article L. 225-216 of the French Commercial Code or infringement of the provisions of Articles L. 241-3, L.
242-6 or L. 244-1 of the French Commercial Code and (ii) French corporate benefit rules.

Under French financial assistance rules, a company is prohibited from guaranteeing indebtedness of another company
that is used, directly or indirectly, for the purpose of its acquisition.

French law requires that, when a French company grants a guarantee on third-party obligations, the guarantee must
be in the corporate purposes and in the corporate interests of the guarantor company. Under French corporate benefit rules, a
guarantor must receive an actual and adequate benefit from the transaction involving the granting by it of the guarantee, taken
as a whole. A court could declare any guarantee unenforceable and, if payment had already been made under the relevant
guarantee, require that the recipient return the payment to the relevant guarantor, if it found that these criteria were not fulfilled.
The existence of a real and adequate benefit to the guarantor and whether the amounts guaranteed are commensurate with the
benefit received are matters of fact as to which French case law provides no clear guidance.

Accordingly, the Guarantee granted by any French Guarantor and the amounts recoverable thereunder will be limited,
at any time, to an amount equal to the aggregate of the proceeds of the Notes to the extent directly or indirectly on-lent by the
Issuer to that French Guarantor or any of its subsidiaries or used to refinance any indebtedness previously directly or indirectly
on-lent to that French Guarantor or any of its subsidiaries, in each case under intercompany loans or similar arrangements, and
outstanding on the date a payment is requested to be made by such French Guarantor under its guarantee. Any payment made
by such French Guarantor under its guarantee in respect of the obligations of any other obligor shall reduce pro tanto the
outstanding amount of the intercompany loans or similar arrangements due by such French Guarantor or its subsidiaries under
the intercompany loan or similar arrangements referred to above. By virtue of this limitation, the amount of the French
Guarantor’s obligations as Guarantor under the Guarantees could be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the
Notes, and the French Guarantor may have effectively no obligation as Guarantor under the Guarantees should the portion of
the proceeds of the Notes made available to such French Guarantor directly or indirectly be equal to zero.

**_The Spanish Guarantees will be limited to a specified amount, and each Spanish Guarantee will be subject to_**
**_certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit its_**
**_validity and enforceability._**

Each Guarantee provides the holders of the Notes with a claim through the Trustee against the relevant Spanish
Guarantor. However, the Indenture will provide that each Guarantee will be limited to the maximum amount that can be
guaranteed by the relevant Spanish Guarantor without rendering the relevant Guarantee, as it relates to that Spanish Guarantor,
voidable or otherwise ineffective or limited under applicable law, and enforcement of each Guarantee would be subject to
certain generally available defenses. In particular, the Guarantors incorporated in Spain as limited liability companies
(sociedades de responsabilidad limitada) will limit their Guarantees by a maximum amount equal to the double of their own
funds (recursos propios). In addition, the Guarantees will not guarantee any obligations which imply a breach of, respectively,
Spanish financial assistance regulations. Enforcement of any of the Guarantees against any Spanish Guarantor will be subject
to certain defenses available to Spanish Guarantors in the relevant jurisdiction. These laws and defenses generally include those
that relate to financial assistance, corporate interest or benefit, fraudulent conveyance or transfer, voidable preference,
insolvency or bankruptcy challenges, claw back in insolvency, preservation of share capital, thin capitalization, capital
maintenance or similar laws, regulations or defenses affecting the rights of creditors generally. If one or more of these laws and
defenses is applicable, a Spanish Guarantor may have no liability or decreased liability under its Guarantee depending on the
amounts of its other obligations and applicable law. Limitations on the enforceability of judgments obtained in New York courts
in such jurisdictions could limit the enforceability of any Guarantee against any Spanish Guarantor. For further information,
see “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law
_Considerations—Spain.”_

**_The Credit Facilities Agreement, the Notes and other indebtedness provide that certain change of control events_**
**_constitute an event of default. In the event of a change of control, Titan Group may not be able to satisfy all of its obligations_**
**_under the senior secured credit facilities or other indebtedness._**

Titan Group may not have sufficient assets or be able to obtain sufficient third-party financing on favorable terms to
satisfy all of its obligations under the Credit Facilities Agreement, the Notes or other indebtedness in the event of a change of
control. If Titan Group experiences a change of control repurchase event, it will be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding
Notes. However, Titan Group's senior secured credit facilities provide that certain change of control events constitute an event
of default or mandatory prepayment event under the senior secured credit facilities. Such an event of default entitles the lenders
thereunder to, among other things, cause all outstanding debt obligations under the senior secured credit facilities to become
due and payable and to proceed against the collateral securing the senior secured credit facilities. Any event of default or


-----

acceleration of the senior secured credit facilities will likely also cause a default under the terms of other indebtedness of Titan
Group.

In addition, the Credit Facilities Agreement contain, and any future credit facilities or other agreements to which Titan
Group becomes a party may contain restrictions on its ability to offer to repurchase the Notes in connection with a change of
control or otherwise. In the event a change of control repurchase event occurs at a time when it is prohibited from offering to
purchase the Notes, Titan Group could seek consent to offer to purchase the Notes or attempt to refinance the borrowings that
contain such a prohibition. If it does not obtain the consent or refinance the borrowings, Titan Group would remain prohibited
from offering to purchase the Notes. In such case, the failure by Titan Group to offer to purchase the Notes would constitute a
default under the Indenture governing the Notes, which, in turn, could result in amounts outstanding under any future credit
facility or other agreement relating to indebtedness being declared due and payable. Any such declaration could have adverse
consequences to Titan Group and the holders of the Notes.

**_The Issuer may not be able to repurchase the Notes upon a change of control. In addition, under certain_**
**_circumstances, the Issuer may have the right to purchase all outstanding Notes in connection with a change of control offer,_**
**_even if certain holders do not consent to the tender._**

If a change of control (as defined in the Indenture) occurs, the Issuer will be required to make an offer to purchase all
the outstanding respective Notes at a price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus any accrued and unpaid interest
and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of purchase. In such a situation, the Issuer may not have enough
funds to pay for all of the Notes that are tendered under any such offer. If a significant principal amount of Notes is tendered,
the Issuer will likely have to obtain financing to pay for the tendered Notes. However, the Issuer may not be able to obtain such
financing on acceptable terms, if at all. Any failure by the Issuer to offer to purchase the Notes upon a change of control would
constitute a default under the Indenture, which would, in turn, constitute a default under the Credit Facilities Agreement.

In addition, the occurrence of certain events that might otherwise constitute a change of control will be deemed not to
be a change of control, provided that upon consummation thereof, a certain consolidated total debt ratio of the Issuer and its
restricted subsidiaries is met.

In addition, in connection with a change of control offer for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate
principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such change of control
offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a change of control offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes
validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the relevant Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the
Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each
other holder of Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

**_Investors in the Notes may not be able to determine when a change of control repurchase event has occurred and_**
**_may not be able to require the Issuer to repurchase the Notes._**

Legal uncertainty regarding what constitutes a change of control repurchase event and the provisions of the indenture
may allow Titan Group to enter into transactions, such as acquisitions, refinancings or recapitalizations, that would not
constitute a change of control repurchase event but may increase Titan Group’s outstanding indebtedness or otherwise affect
Titan Group’s ability to satisfy its obligations under the Notes.

In addition, the definition of “change of control” in the Indenture will include the sale, lease or transfer of “all or
substantially all” of the assets of the Issuer and its subsidiaries taken as a whole, to certain persons. Although there is a limited
body of case law interpreting the phrase “substantially all,” there is no precise established definition of the phrase under
applicable law. Accordingly, an investor’s ability to require the Issuer to repurchase their Notes as a result of a transfer of less
than all of the assets of Titan Group to another person may be uncertain.

**_Holders of the Notes may have adverse tax consequences in the event of an IPO Pushdown._**

Under certain circumstances, the Issuer may undertake an IPO Pushdown (as described in “Description of the Notes—
_IPO Pushdown”), pursuant to which the Issuer is entitled to give notice that the terms of the Indenture and the Intercreditor_
Agreement shall operate (with effect from the date specified in the relevant Pushdown Notice (as defined in “Description of
_the Notes—IPO Pushdown”)) so that, among other things, references to the Issuer and Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined in_
“Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”) (and all related provisions) shall apply only to the IPO Entity (as defined in
“Description of the Notes—IPO Pushdown”) and its Restricted Subsidiaries. In such event, each holding company of the IPO


-----

Entity would be released from its obligations under the Indenture, the Intercreditor Agreement (or any Additional Intercreditor
Agreement) and any security granted by it or any holding company of it.

Such modifications could be treated for U.S. federal income tax purposes as a deemed exchange of (i) the Notes as in
place prior to such modifications for (ii) new Notes as in place after such modifications (the “New Notes”). If such
modifications result in a deemed exchange for U.S. federal income tax purposes, it would generally be treated as a taxable
transaction for U.S. federal income tax purposes in which beneficial owners of the Notes would be required to recognize any
gain or loss. Furthermore, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, the New Notes deemed issued in such a deemed exchange
could be treated as issued with original issue discount. In such event, U.S. Holders (as defined under “Certain Tax
_Considerations— Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations”) would be required to include the original issue discount_
in their income as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash corresponding to such income. In addition, the determination of
whether the New Notes are treated as “contingent payment debt instruments” as a result of the possibility of additional
payments, as further described under “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations—
_Characterization of the Notes,” would be made at the time of the modification. U.S. Holders should consult their own tax_
advisors as to the U.S. federal income tax considerations relating to potential modifications of the Notes in connection with the
IPO Pushdown.

It is also possible that the IPO Pushdown could result in a taxable event for tax purposes other than U.S. federal income
tax purposes.

**_Transfer of the Notes will be restricted, which may adversely affect the value of the Notes._**

The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the US Securities Act or the securities
laws of any state or any other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold in the United States, or to, or
for the account or benefit of, US persons (as defined in Regulation S under the Securities Act) except pursuant to an exemption
from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the US Securities Act and the applicable securities laws
of any state or any other jurisdiction. It is the obligation of investors in the Notes to ensure that all offers and sales of the Notes
in the United States and other countries comply with applicable securities laws. See “Transfer Restrictions.”

**_Certain covenants and events of default will be suspended if the Notes receive investment grade ratings._**

The Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the date of the Indenture, the Notes issued under the Indenture
receive an investment grade rating from at least two of Moody’s, S&P or Fitch and no default or event of default has occurred
and is continuing, then beginning that day and continuing until such time as such Notes are no longer rated investment grade
by either ratings agency, certain covenants will cease to be applicable to such Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Certain
_Covenants— Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.” At any time when these covenants are_
suspended, the Issuer will be able to, among other things, incur additional indebtedness, pay cash dividends and redeem
subordinated indebtedness without restriction, each of which may conflict with the interests of holders of the Notes. There can
be no assurance that the Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating if achieved will be
maintained.

**_The Notes and the Guarantees will be structurally subordinated to the claims of creditors, including trade creditors_**
**_and preferred stockholders (if any), of our non-Guarantor subsidiaries._**

Generally, claims of creditors, including trade creditors and preferred stockholders (if any) of non-Guarantor
subsidiaries of the Issuer, are entitled to payments of their claims from the assets of such subsidiaries before these assets are
made available for distribution to their respective parent entity or the creditors of the Issuer and the Guarantors. Accordingly,
in the event that any non-Guarantor subsidiary of the Issuer becomes insolvent, is liquidated, reorganized or dissolved or is
otherwise wound up other than as part of a solvent transaction:

     - the creditors of the Issuer and the Guarantors (including the holders of the Notes) will have no right to proceed
against the assets of such non-Guarantor subsidiary; and

     - creditors of such non-Guarantor subsidiary, including trade creditors and preferred stockholders (if any) will
generally be entitled to payment in full from the sale or other disposal of the assets of such subsidiary before the
Issuer or any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder (as applicable), will be entitled to receive any
distributions from such subsidiary.


-----

As such, the Notes and the Guarantees will be structurally subordinated to the creditors, including trade creditors and
any preferred stockholders (if any) of the non-Guarantor subsidiaries of the Issuer. In addition, the Indenture will, subject to
certain limitations, permit these non-Guarantor subsidiaries to incur substantial additional indebtedness without such incurrence
constituting a default under the Indenture, and such indebtedness may also be secured. The Indenture will not contain any
limitation on the amount of other liabilities, such as deposits and trade payables, that may be incurred by these subsidiaries. As
of March 31, 2021, after giving effect to the Transactions, our non-guarantor subsidiaries would not have had any external
financial indebtedness outstanding.

**_If an active trading market for the Notes does not develop, the liquidity and value of the Notes could be harmed._**

There is no existing market for the Notes. Titan Group intends to submit an application to list the notes on the Official
List of The International Stock Exchange and to trade the Notes on The International Stock Exchange. Even if Titan Group
submits such an application, it cannot assure that an active trading market will develop for the Notes. If no active trading market
develops, investors in the Notes may not be able to resell their Notes at their fair market value or at all. In addition, there can
be no assurance that the Notes will become or remain listed. If the Issuer cannot maintain the listing on the Exchange and the
admission to dealing on the Official List thereof, or if it becomes unduly burdensome to make or maintain such listing, the
Issuer may cease to make or maintain such listing on the Official List of the Exchange.

Future trading prices of the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among other things, prevailing interest
rates, demand for high yield debt securities generally, general economic conditions, Titan Group’s operating results, financial
performance or prospects or the prospects of the companies in the same industry and the market for similar securities. The
liquidity of a trading market for the Notes may be adversely affected by a general decline in the market for similar securities.
Historically, the market for non-investment grade securities has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial
volatility in the prices of securities similar to the Notes. Any such disruption may have a negative effect on investors, as holders
of Notes, regardless of Titan Group’s prospects and financial performance. The Initial Purchasers have advised Titan Group
that they currently intend to make a market in the Notes after completing the Offering. However, they have no obligation to do
so and may cease their market-making activities at any time without notice. In addition, any such market making activity will
be subject to limitations imposed by the Securities Act and other applicable laws and regulations. As a result, there may not be
an active trading market for the Notes. If no active trading market develops, investors may not be able to resell their Notes at a
fair value, if at all.

**_Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to_**
**_revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time._**

One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the
potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed herein and other factors that may
affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to
revision, suspension or withdrawal by the credit rating agency at any time. No assurances can be given that a credit rating will
remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating
agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the
credit rating assigned to the Notes or any indication from the ratings agencies that the Issuer’s ratings are under review by one
or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of Titan Group’s financings and
could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

**_The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form and, therefore, investors must rely on the procedures and the_**
**_relevant clearing systems to exercise their rights and remedies._**

Unless and until definitive registered notes are issued in exchange for book-entry interests in the Notes (which may
occur only in very limited circumstances), owners of book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of Notes.
Instead, the nominee of the common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the Notes.
Payments of principal, interest, premium and additional amounts, if any, owing on or in respect of the Notes in global form will
be made to the Paying Agent. The Paying Agent will, in turn, make such payments to the common depositary for Euroclear and
Clearstream, which will distribute such payments to participants in accordance with the common depositary’s procedures. After
payment to the common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, the Issuer will have no responsibility or liability for the
payment of principal, interest, premium or additional amounts, if any, to the owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if
investors own a book-entry interest, they must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream, and if investors are not
participants in Euroclear and Clearstream, they must rely on the procedures of the participant through which they own their
interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Notes under the Indenture.


-----

Unlike holders of the Notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon the
Issuer’s solicitations for consents or requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes. Instead, if investors own
book-entry interests, they will be permitted to act only to the extent they have received appropriate proxies to do so from
Euroclear and/or Clearstream or, if applicable, a participant. There can be no assurance that procedures implemented for the
granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable the investors to vote on any requested actions on a timely basis. The lack
of physical certificates could also:

     - result in payment delays on the Notes because the Trustee will be sending payments on the Notes to Euroclear
and Clearstream instead of directly to the investor;

     - make it difficult for the investors to pledge the Notes if physical certificates are required by the party demanding
the pledge; and

     - hinder the investors’ ability to resell their Notes because some investors may be unwilling to buy Notes that are
not in physical form.

Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until definitive registered Notes
are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, if investors own book-entry interests, they will be restricted to acting through
Euroclear and Clearstream. The procedures to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream may not be adequate to
ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Notes. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form.”

**_An investor may be unable to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities laws violations._**

The Issuer and the Guarantors are organized or incorporated outside the United States, and a substantial portion of our
business is conducted outside the United States. The directors and executive officers of the Issuer and the Guarantors are nonresidents of, and substantially all of their assets are located outside of, the United States. Although the Issuer and the Guarantors
will submit to the jurisdiction of certain New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws, you may be
unable to effect service of process within the United States on the directors and executive officers of the Issuer and the
Guarantors. In addition, as a substantial portion of the assets of the Issuer and the Guarantors and their subsidiaries and those
of their directors and executive officers are located outside of the United States, you may be unable to enforce against them
judgments obtained in U.S. courts. Moreover, in light of recent decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court, actions of the Issuer and
the Guarantors may not be subject to the civil liability provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States.

Additionally, there is uncertainty as to whether the courts of foreign jurisdictions would enforce (i) judgments of
United States courts obtained against the Issuer, the Guarantors and the directors and executive officers who are not residents
of the United States predicated upon the civil liability provisions of the United States federal and state securities laws or (ii) in
original actions brought in such foreign jurisdictions against us or such persons predicated upon the United States federal and
state securities laws.

The United States is not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of
judgments, other than arbitral awards, rendered in civil and commercial matters, with certain jurisdictions. For further
information see “Service of Process and Enforcement of Judgment.”

**_Investors in the Notes may face foreign exchange risks or adverse tax consequences._**

The Notes will be denominated and payable in euros. If investors in the Notes measure their investment returns by
reference to a currency other than the Euro, an investment in the Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among
other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the Euro relative to the currency by reference to which the investors
measure the return on their investments because of economic, political and other factors over which Titan Group has no control.
Depreciation of the Euro against the currency by reference to which the investors measure the return on their investments could
cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to the investors
when the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which they measure the return on their investments.
Investment in the Notes may also have important tax consequences as a result of any foreign currency exchange gains or losses.
See “Certain Tax Considerations.”

Titan Group, the Initial Purchasers, the Trustee and the Paying Agent with respect to the Notes will not be obligated
to convert, or to assist any registered owner or beneficial owner of such Notes in converting, payments of principal, interest,


-----

premium or additional amounts, if any, or any redemption price made with respect to such Notes into US Dollars or any other
currency.

**_Trading in the clearing systems is subject to minimum denomination requirements._**

The Notes will be issued only in minimum denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess
thereof. It is possible that the clearing systems may process trades which could result in amounts being held in denominations
smaller than the minimum denominations. If definitive Notes are required to be issued in relation to such Notes in accordance
with the provisions of the relevant global notes, a holder who does not have the minimum denomination or an integral multiple
of €1,000 in excess thereof in its account with the relevant clearing system at the relevant time may not receive all of its
entitlement in the form of definitive notes unless and until such time as its holding satisfies the minimum denomination
requirement.

**_The Indenture will not be qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended._**

The Indenture will not be required to, and will not be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended
(the “TIA”), and will not incorporate nor include, and will not be subject to, any of the provisions of the TIA. Consequently,
the holders of the Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under
a qualified indenture, including those respecting preferential collections by the trustee or conflicting interests of the trustee.

**_The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes._**

The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If the Notes are issued
with original issue discount, in addition to the stated cash interest on the Notes, US Holders (as defined under “Taxation—
_Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations”) will generally be required to include the amounts representing the_
original issue discount in gross income on a constant yield basis in advance of receipt of the cash payments to which such
income is attributable. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations.”

**Overview**

We are a European leader in the design, manufacture and sale of metal packaging solutions, with number one or
number two market positions across our product groups in the countries we operate in. We are the clear market leader in the
26.7-billion-unit European market for metal food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with an approximate
39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. As the largest European manufacturer of metal food
cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel (based on our estimated consumption of approximately 20% of
total European tinplate production), our business is a critical asset in the European food supply chain.

We have been in the industry for more than 200 years and have an established reputation for the highest quality
products and exceptional customer service. From the founding of our predecessor business in 1799 to our acquisition by Crown
in 1996 and our acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, our business has shown itself to be a leader in European metal packaging time
and time again. Following the Transactions, we will become a leading stand-alone business in Europe.

Our product portfolio consists predominantly of food packaging, with approximately 95% of our sales in the year
ended December 31, 2020 going to food related end markets. Our products are used by hundreds of millions of consumers on
a daily basis across Europe, the Middle East and Africa. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12
billion food cans, approximately 24 billion ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol
cans and approximately 134 million metal promotional packaging containers. Our products are used to package food in a
diverse array of end-markets, including fruits and vegetables, tomatoes, fish, pet food, culinary, infant nutrition and dairy. Each
of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers that are stable and largely uncorrelated with broader
macroeconomic cycles.


-----

**Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020**
1. According to leading global consulting firm
2. According to Management estimates

We sell our products in more than 90 countries with France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany
representing 15%, 14%, 12%, 11% and 7% of our sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020 and other
geographies making up the remaining 41% of sales in the same period. Sales to our top 10 customers represented just 32% of
our total sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having
worked with our top 10 customers for an average of over 25 years.

Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and
negotiated raw material pass-through mechanisms, providing us with margin stability and consistent historical cash flows. We
have demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Moreover,
as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Titan Group’s pass-through was on track for full recovery of raw material price
increases in 2021. Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up
to 40% of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts
stipulate a guaranteed percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract.

We operate 44 strategically located manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be
transferred at the end of the transition period) in 17 countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, which enhance our access
to customer end-markets and support local demand. Our manufacturing scale is complemented by our services and customer
support capabilities including over 20 technical services locations, seven dedicated product design studios, four dedicated
laboratory testing facilities and a world-class research and development facility that have put us at the forefront of the European
tinplate packaging industry.

In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had net sales of $2,241 million, $2,138 million and $2,227
million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $303 million, $247 million and $267 million, respectively. Our net sales and
Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were $2,297 million and $317 million, respectively, for the twelve months ended March 31,
2021. These amounts translate, for convenience purposes only, for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, to net
sales of €1,897 million, €1,910 million and €1,951 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of €256 million, €221 million
and €234 million, respectively, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, to net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
of €1,974 million and €272 million, respectively.

**Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations**

The following are a description of the main factors which have affected our financial condition and results of
operations for the three-months period ended March 31, 2020 and 2021 and for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and
2020, as well as certain factors which are expected to impact our financial condition and results of operations in the future.

The businesses, operations, assets and liabilities comprising the Titan Group have historically operated as part and
under the umbrella of the global Crown Group, which provided substantial management and shared services to the business.
Upon completion of the Acquisition, Titan Group will operate on a standalone basis. We have no history operating as a
standalone group, see also “Risk Factors––We have no operating history as a standalone company.” Consequently, our future
results of operations will exclude cost historically allocated to Titan Group by Crown and will include costs and expenses for
us to operate as a standalone business, and we expect these costs and expenses to be materially different than our historical cost
structure. We will also incur a significant amount of debt in connection with the Transactions. Accordingly, our historical results
presented in this Offering Memorandum are not indicative of our future results of operations, financial positions and cash flows.


-----

**_COVID-19 and Macroeconomic Environment_**

In the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021, the impact of the COVID-19
pandemic on production and aggregate demand became apparent in all economies. In leading global economies, authorities
enacted strong expansionary measures to provide income support to households and firms, provide credit to the economy and
bolster market liquidity. The spread of the virus in Europe since the end of February 2020 and the measures adopted to reduce
the rate of infection had significant repercussions on economic activity in the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three
months ended March 31, 2021. In relation to the Group, the COVID-19 pandemic generated a modest increase in canned food
consumption due to more at-home eating, which was partially offset by lower sales of large format cans for the food services
industry. In addition, demand for aerosols packaging declined as personal care habits changed during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Sales of promotional packaging also declined as marketplaces such as airport shops where such packaging is sold were closed.
Overall, we estimate that benefits due to increases in demand for food cans offset losses in volume in our aerosols and
promotional packaging activities and increased expenditures, resulting in a net neutral impact to our financial performance.

Our manufacturing facilities were deemed system relevant in each jurisdiction in which we operate and remained fully
operational throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. Our office workforce experienced no disruption since the outbreak of the
COVID-19 pandemic due to our ability to swiftly switch all platforms and processes to be functional remotely and to promptly
enhance communication channels. Even before the restrictive measures in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic came into effect,
we adopted a series of further, voluntary and increasingly stringent precautionary measures in addition to those required by
law, with a view to ensuring a greater degree of protection for employees. We leveraged the use of smart working arrangements
for those activities that can be carried out remotely, and vacation and paid leave were incentivized. In addition, we took
advantage of social safety-net arrangements as appropriate, in conjunction with the introduction of anti-contagion safety
protocols, use of personal protection equipment and sanitization of business premises.

**_Seasonality_**

Demand for some of our products is seasonal. At least 45% of our revenue is generated from sales to seasonal food
end-markets. The industry enters its busiest period in the third quarter when the majority of seasonal fruits and vegetables are
harvested. Due to the foregoing factors our working capital requirements typically build during the first half of a financial year
and decrease during the second half of a financial year. Inventory levels typically increase in the first half of the year to meet
peak demand in the second and third quarters. Our results of operations, cash flows and liquidity may therefore be impacted by
these seasonal practices.

**_Weather Conditions_**

Weather conditions can reduce crop yields and adversely affect customer demand for fruit and vegetable cans in any
given year. In addition, demand for our seafood packaging is affected by variation in local fish catches. Severe weather
conditions associated with climate change such as droughts, hail, floods or frost, are unpredictable and may potentially impact
agricultural production which in turn may lead to reduced demand for our products in the regions in which we currently operate.
See also “Risk Factors––Titan Group's business is seasonal and adverse weather conditions could reduce Titan Group's net
_sales.”_

**_Raw Material Expenses_**

Raw materials constitute the substantial majority of our production cost and our total costs of raw materials were
$1,196 million, $1,148 million and $1,159 million, or 53.7%, 53.7% and 51.7%, respectively, of our net sales for the year ended
December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. Our key raw material input is steel (both tinplate and tin-free forms), which
constituted 48.5%, 51.2% and 49.2% of the total cost of goods sold for the year ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018,
respectively. We believe we are the largest purchaser of tinplate steel in Europe. Our relationships with domestic European
steel mills are a key strength of our business and represent a critical strategic advantage compared to our competitors. The cost
of steel is affected by a variety of micro and macro factors, primarily based on the supply and demand for steel, market
movements in other base metals and geopolitical factors. Importantly, steel is generally purchased under one-year contracts
with prices that are fixed for each calendar year, minimizing the intra-year volatility of our primary input cost.

We have not experienced any material supply issues related to our key raw materials that impacted our ability to meet
customer demand requirements during the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe that our strong relationships with the leading
European suppliers of steel, including committed volume contracts, have allowed us to source steel consistently through a
variety of market conditions. We also believe that certain of our competitors are experiencing difficulties in purchasing these
raw materials because of a lack of scale. We centrally manage our procurement operations across the Group in order to achieve


-----

economies of scale, seek consistency across our relationships across Europe, the Middle East and Africa and provide more
certainty for production planning.

Changes in the cost of raw materials affect both our net sales and our cost of materials and thus substantially affect
our results of operations. However, the price for steel is not often a substantial factor affecting our underlying business
performance as we typically pass-through any increases in raw material prices to our customers. Through a combination of
contracts which include input cost pass-through provisions and annual price negotiations which also reflect tinplate prices, we
have historically been able to minimize margin volatility due to changes in raw material costs. We pass through changes in raw
material costs relating to the remainder of our business’s revenues through annual pricing negotiations. Since steel prices are
also contracted for on an annual basis, our customer pricing and raw material input cost changes are generally matched. We
have been generally able to successfully pass through raw material price fluctuations and maintain largely consistent margins
throughout much of our operating history. However, in 2019, Titan offered certain price concessions to capture wallet share
and long long-term contracts. This improved revenue certainty at the expense of short short-term margins.

**_Foreign Exchange Transactions_**

During the periods discussed herein, our reporting currency was the U.S. Dollar, however our sales and revenue and
operating costs are realized in other currencies, predominantly the Euro, which represents approximately 74% of our revenue.
As a result, our historical financials are exposed to foreign exchange translation fluctuations between such other currencies and
the U.S. Dollar. The translation of foreign currencies back to the U.S. Dollar may have a significant impact on our revenues
and financial results. Foreign exchange has an unfavorable impact on revenues when the U.S. Dollar is relatively strong as
compared with foreign currencies and a favorable impact on revenues when the U.S. Dollar is relatively weak as compared
with foreign currencies.

Our business has a limited level of transactional currency exposure arising from sales or purchases by operating
activities in currencies other than their functional currencies.

Assets and liabilities of the Group denominated in currencies other than the U.S. Dollar, were translated to U.S. Dollar
using the applicable period-end rates of exchange. To counteract seasonal effects, the income, expense and cash flow items
were translated to U.S. Dollar at average exchange rates prevailing throughout the applicable period. Translation adjustments
are accumulated as a separate component of other comprehensive income (loss).

Following the Completion Date, the Business will no longer be part of the Crown Group and hence will be operated
independently from its United States parent. Given that none of the Group’s operations are in the United States, we expect that
our reporting currency will shift from the U.S. Dollar to the Euro, representing the functional currency in a majority of the
jurisdictions in which we operate. While we will remain subject to limited foreign exchange transaction risk, such shift would
eliminate the risk arising from currency translation to the U.S. Dollar. We expect this change in reporting currency to have a
positive impact on the stability and comparability of our results of operations going forward.

**_Sustainability_**

Steel and aluminum packaging is environmentally sustainable. Not only are steel and aluminum infinitely recyclable,
but they also have the highest recycling rates amongst packaging formats. Additionally, according to the Can Manufacturing
Institute, recycling saves up to 75% of the energy required to produce virgin steel. Greater environmental consciousness and
strong sustainability trends have led to an increased preference for recyclable packaging. Consumers increasingly view
sustainability as a key purchasing criteria and seek out more environmentally friendly packaging, which has been further
reinforced by regulatory developments. Changes in regulations and ability to reuse materials and produce packaging that is
perceived as environmentally friendly can affect both our net sales and our cost of materials and thus substantially affect our
results of operations. Metal packaging’s properties position it to benefit from the increasing backlash against the use of plastic
products.

**Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement**

**_Net Sales_**

Net sales consist of gross sales less sales adjustments related to provisions for customer returns, allowances, rebates,
pass-through taxes and eliminations of intra-group transactions. We disaggregate net sales based on the timing of transfer of
control for goods and services. The transfer of control for goods and services may occur at a point in time or over time; in other


-----

words, sales may be recognized over the course of the underlying contract, or they may occur at a single point in time based
upon the transfer of control.

**_Cost of Products Sold_**

Costs of products sold includes fixed and variable production costs. Such variable costs mainly consist of the costs of
raw materials, realized effective hedges related to commodity hedges, unrealized and realized ineffective hedges related to
commodity hedges, energy, freight, utilities, handling and conversion costs, waste disposal, consumables, attributable
depreciation charges and directly attributable overhead expenses, including wages and salaries and overhead expenses that are
attributable to production. Due to the seasonal demand of our business, we utilize temporary labor to scale production to meet
customer demand. Changes in variable costs relating to raw material prices are generally passed through to customers. Fixed
costs include a portion of overhead labor costs, as well as rent, impairment of inventories, repairs and maintenance.

**_Depreciation and Amortization_**

Depreciation and amortization relates to the depreciation of property, plant and equipment and the amortization of
intangible assets. Depreciation and amortization is accounted for on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the
assets. The Group periodically reviews the estimated useful lives of its plant, property and equipment and, where appropriate,
changes are made prospectively. Definite-lived intangible assets are tested for impairment when facts and circumstances
indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable from their undiscounted cash flows.

**_Selling and Administrative Expenses_**

Selling expenses include all selling costs. During the periods presented herein, Selling costs comprise the sales and
customer service activities of the organization. Administrative expenses typically include advertising costs, insurance costs,
legal and professional fees, office supplies, design and development cost, sales and marketing costs, finance costs, information
technology, human resources and other administrative costs.

As from the Closing Date, certain allocated administrative expenses of our current United States parent will not
continue, while some allocated charges will need to be replicated by costs going forward. Please refer to the reconciliation of
Adjusted EBITDA included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum for further detail. See “Summary Financial and Other
_Information.”_

**_Technology Royalty_**

Technology royalty refers to an intragroup charge to Crown for general research and development and overall business
processes for the periods presented herein. From the Closing Date onwards, this charge to Crown will discontinue.

**_Restructuring and Other_**

Restructuring costs relate to reduction of manufacturing capacity and headcount across the Group. Other relates to
asset impairments and gains on the sale of assets.

**_Goodwill Impairment_**

Goodwill impairment relates to impairment charges where an asset’s carrying amount exceeds the recoverable amount.
Goodwill is carried at cost and reviewed for impairment annually in the fourth quarter of each year or when facts and
circumstances indicate goodwill may be impaired.

**_Interest Expense and Other Expenses_**

Interest expense relates to interest expenses from our intragroup and external financings including bank borrowings,
interest expense associated with accounts receivable factoring and securitization programs, trade bills and other financial
expenses. Other expenses relates to pension and related non-services costs as well as foreign exchange gains or losses.


-----

**_Provision for Income Taxes_**

Income tax expenses consist of current tax expense and deferred tax expense. Deferred taxes represent the future
expected tax consequences of differences between the financial reporting and tax bases of assets and liabilities based upon
enacted tax rates and laws. Valuation allowances are recorded to reduce deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that
a tax benefit will not be realized. Investment tax credits are accounted for using the deferral method. Income tax-related interest
and penalties are reported as income tax expense.

The Group’s effective tax rate (calculated as income taxes divided by income before income taxes) was 27.9% for the
year ended December 31, 2020, 30.7% for the year ended December 31, 2019, and 24.0% for the year ended December 31,
2018. The Group’s effective income tax rate fluctuates based on, among other factors, the geographic mix of earnings. The
higher effective income tax rate in 2019 is related to a $25 million non-deductible impairment charge primarily related to our
aerosols and promotional packaging activities.

**_Net Income Attributable to Noncontrolling Interests_**

We consolidate entities in which we own or control more than fifty percent of voting shares or otherwise have a
controlling financial interest in the entity. We consider ourselves to have a controlling financial interest in the entity if we have
(1) the power to direct the activities of the entity that most significantly impact the entity’s economic performance and (2) the
obligation to absorb losses of the entity that could potentially be significant to the entity or the right to receive benefits from
the entity that could potentially be significant to the entity.

The net income attributable to noncontrolling interests refers to the share of profit belonging to the minority
shareholders of the entity which is controlled by the Group, but for which only a portion of earnings are returned to the Group.
The portion returned reflects the percentage of entity ownership. In this case, the Group’s line item represents the share of
profit belonging to the minority shareholders of the Group.

**Alternative Performance Measures (“APMs”)**

Below is a discussion of certain non-US GAAP financial information. Such financial information is not defined under
US GAAP, and other companies may calculate such financial information differently or may use such measures for different
purposes, limiting the usefulness of such measures as comparative measures. The APMs should not be considered in isolation
and investors should not consider such information as alternative to net income as an indicator of our financial performance,
an alternative to income from operations as an indicator of our operating performance, or an alternative to cash flows from
operating activities as a measure of our liquidity. Such financial information must be considered only in addition to, and not as
a substitute for or superior to, financial information prepared in accordance with US GAAP included elsewhere in this Offering
Memorandum. Investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these APMs and are also advised to review them in
conjunction with the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial
Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

This Offering Memorandum contains financial measures that are not defined or recognized under US GAAP,
including: EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA margin. We present these APMs because we believe that they contribute to a better understanding of our results of
operations by providing additional information on what we consider some of the drivers of our financial performance.
Furthermore, we believe that these APMs are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties
as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity.

In addition, the presentation of these measures is not intended to and does not necessarily comply with the reporting
requirements of the SEC; compliance with its requirements would require us to make changes to the presentation of this
information. We believe that the description of these APMs in this Offering Memorandum follows and complies with the
European Securities and Markets Authority Guidelines on Alternative Performance Measures dated October 5, 2015.

See also “Presentation of Financial Information––Alternative performance measures (“APMs”).”

**_EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA margin_**

We calculate EBITDA as net income before provision of income taxes, interest expense, depreciation and amortization.
EBITDA is not a measurement of performance under US GAAP and investors should not consider EBITDA as an alternative


-----

to income from operations as an indicator of our operating performance, or an alternative to cash flow from operating activities
as a measure of our liquidity.

We calculate Adjusted EBITDA by applying adjustments for non-operating or non-recurring items to EBITDA. We
calculate Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA by applying adjustments for the benefit of cost savings from operational improvement
opportunities that we expect to realize within the next three years. We calculate Adjusted EBITDA margin as Adjusted EBITDA
divided by net sales.

We believe that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA margin are meaningful for investors because they
provide an analysis of our operating results, profitability and ability to service debt and because they are used by our chief
operating decision makers to track our business evolution, establish operational and strategic targets and make important
business decisions. To facilitate the analysis of our operations, EBITDA excludes amortization, impairment and depreciation
expenses from income from operations in order to eliminate the impact of general long term capital investment.

_Net sales_

Our net sales increased by $70 million, or 15.2%, to $530 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from
$460 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to higher sales volume in the seasonal
foods end markets, including fruits and vegetables, with food can volumes increasing 8.5% for the three months ended March
31, 2021 compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020, in light of suppressed volumes for the three months ended
March 31, 2020 during the initial stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, which have normalized for the three months ended March
31, 2021. These trends were offset by lower sales volume in the fish end market for the three months ended March 31, 2021.

_Costs of products sold_

Costs of products sold increased by $38 million, or 9.6%, to $434 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021
from $396 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. Our costs of products sold as a percentage of net sales decreased
by 4.2 percentage points to 81.9% for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from 86.1% for the three months ended March
31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to an inventory pricing headwind in the three months ended March 31, 2020 caused
by a weaker than expected harvest in 2019 which did not repeat in the three months ended March 31, 2021.

_Depreciation and amortization_

Depreciation and amortization increased by $1 million, or 7.1%, to $15 million for the three months ended March 31,
2021 from $14 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely as a result of foreign currency translation, with the
Euro appreciating by 9.4% compared to the same period of the prior year.


-----

_Selling and administrative expenses_

Selling and administrative expenses increased by $1 million, or 3.8%, to $27 million for the three months ended March
31, 2021 from $26 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely due to foreign currency translation. The
underlying selling and administrative expenses in the operating currencies were lower in the three months ended March 31,
2021 than in the same period of the prior year.

_Technology royalty_

Technology royalty increased by $1 million, or 20.0%, to $6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from
$5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely due to the increase in sales and associated increased cost
allocation. These expenses will not continue to be charged from Crown to the Business following the Completion Date.

_Restructuring and other_

We incurred $1 million of restructuring and other costs in the three months ended March 31, 2020 which were
primarily related to a loss on disposal of certain assets. We did not incur any such costs in the three months ended March 31,
2021.

_Income from operations_

Income from operations increased by $30 million, or 166.7%, to $48 million for the three months ended March 31,
2021 from $18 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely due to higher sales, lower cost of products sold,
lower selling and administrative expenses and foreign currency translation impact.

_Interest expense_

Interest expense increased by $1 million, or 100%, to $2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from $1
million for the three months ended March 31, 2020.

_Provision for income taxes_

Provision for income taxes increased by $4 million, or 66.7%, to $10 million for the three months ended March 31,
2021, from $6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely due to higher income from operations.

_Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests_

Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests amounted to $1 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021,
primarily attributable to increased income in our Morocco business due to an increase in volume from a rebound in the fishing
industry, partially offset by foreign exchange impact. We reported no net income attributable to noncontrolling interests for the
three months ended March 31, 2020.

**_Liquidity_**

Before entering into the Financing, the primary sources of liquidity for our business have been cash flow from
operating activities and the existing revolving credit facilities of the Crown Group. Following completion of the Financing, we
expect that our primary source of liquidity will be cash flows from operating activities and the Revolving Credit Facility. It is
expected that, as of the Completion Date, the Revolving Credit Facility will be undrawn except that in the event that freely
available cash on the balance sheet on or about the Completion Date is lower than our estimate or insufficient to support our
working capital requirements due to, among other things, a negative movement in working capital, we may draw down amounts
under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Completion Date or shortly thereafter.

We have used our cash flow to fund operating expenses, working capital, capital expenditures, and capital and interest
payments related to our debt obligations. Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations together with
available borrowings and cash on hand, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs, we cannot
assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be
available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes offered hereby, or to fund
our other liquidity needs.

We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity include:

   - a reduction in operating cash flows due to a lowering of operating profit from our operations, which could be caused
by a downturn in our performance, the industry as a whole or the economy as a whole;

   - the failure or delay of our customers to make payments due to us;

   - the failure to maintain low working capital requirements; and

  - the need to fund expansion and other development capital expenditures.

   - If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Revolving Credit
Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to:

   - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditures;

   - sell our assets;

   - obtain additional debt or equity financing; and/or

   - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity.


-----

We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory
terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of the Notes and any future debt may limit our ability to pursue any of these alternatives.

**Market Risk**

The main risks to which we are exposed in connection with our operations are raw material costs, interest rate risk
and the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates. We limit this exposure through established raw material pass-through
practices, as well as programs that include the use of derivative financial instruments, primarily swaps and forwards.
Counterparties to these contracts are major financial institutions. These instruments are viewed as risk management tools,
involve little complexity and are not used for trading or speculative purposes. The extent to which we use such instruments is
dependent upon our access to them in the financial markets and our use of other methods, such as netting exposures for foreign
exchange risk and establishing sales arrangements that permit the pass-through to customers of changes in commodity prices
and foreign exchange rates.

**_Currency Exchange Risk_**

During the periods discussed in this Offering Memorandum, the Group presented its financial information in U.S.
Dollar. The Group operates in 17 countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa and hence currency exchange risk arises from
commercial transactions and recognized assets and liabilities. As a result of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and
the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements being presented in U.S. Dollar, the results of the Group are
also impacted by fluctuations in the U.S. Dollar exchange rate versus the functional currencies of the Group, including the Euro
(represents approximately 74% of our revenue), the British Sterling and the Moroccan Dirham.

Fluctuations in value of these currencies with respect to the U.S. Dollar may have a significant impact on our financial
condition and results of operations. We believe that a strengthening of the U.S. Dollar exchange rate by 1% against all functional
currencies from the December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 rate, respectively, would decrease invested capital by approximately
$18 million, $17 million and $19 million in the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. On a forward
going basis, the Business will report in Euro, which is consistent with the primary functional currency of our operating units.

We manage foreign currency exposures at the operating unit level. Exposures that cannot be naturally offset within an
operating unit may be hedged with derivative financial instruments where possible and cost effective in our judgment. Foreign
exchange contracts generally mature within twelve months.

From time to time, we may manage our interest rate risk associated with fluctuations in variable interest rates through

**_Commodity Risk_**

We are modestly exposed to the risk of fluctuations in commodity prices. Our primary raw material, tinplate steel, is
not a traded commodity and does not have a commonly accepted index price. Tinplate steel represents approximately 95% of
our metal purchases. Despite this dynamic, the nature of our annual tinplate steel pricing negotiations and subsequent pass

-----

through pricing strategies to customers for the following year provides a natural hedge as input cost changes are matched to
customer price changes.

We also purchase aluminum, which represents approximately 5% of our metal purchases. Aluminum is a traded
commodity that is regularly quoted on the LME. The risk of changes of the price of aluminum is connected with the common
practice of determining the prices in the contracts on the basis of the monthly average sales price of aluminum on the LME.
We endeavor to avoid unnecessary risks and limit the impact of threats related to our business to an acceptable level, which is
achieved primarily through contracts that pass-through raw material costs to customers and by means of hedging transactions.
As of March 31, 2021, the Group had forward commodity contracts to hedge aluminum price fluctuations with a notional value
of $12.3 million and a net gain of $2.9 million. The maturities of the commodity contracts closely correlate to the anticipated
purchases of those commodities.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk arises from cash and deposits with banks and financial institutions, as well as credit exposure to our
customers, including outstanding receivables.

Credit risk has historically been managed by Crown’s central treasury function, who places excess liquid funds with
recognized and reputable financial institutions. The credit ratings of banks and financial institutions are monitored and the risk
of default is controlled by limiting the amount of credit exposure to any one bank or institution.

It is our policy to extend credit to customers in good standing. Credit risk is managed on an ongoing basis and we
periodically assess the financial reliability of customers, taking into account their financial position, past experience and other
factors. Provisions are made where deemed necessary and the utilization of credit limits is regularly monitored. We do not
expect any significant counterparty to fail to meet its payment obligations towards us. There is no recent history of material
non-payment default with any of our major customers.
