**INDUSTRY OVERVIEW**

**Market Overview**

The global packaging industry is a large, consumer-driven industry with stable growth characteristics. We operate in
the metal container sectors and our primary operating regions are Europe, the Middle East and Africa, although we serve the
global market with certain of our products.

Metal packaging is becoming increasingly attractive to brands as their strength and rigidity allows them to be filled at
high speeds and easily transported, while their shelf-stable nature means that refrigeration is not required, thereby resulting in
further energy savings in the supply chain. The ability to customize and differentiate products supplied in metal containers,
through innovative design, shaping and printing, also appeals to our customers. Metal offers performance and convenience for
brands compared to alternatives. It acts as a superior barrier to oxygen and light and is resilient, as it can be durable, tamperproof and fire and temperature resistant. Moreover, it is convenient, and can be light and robust, with portable characteristics
and easy open and recloseable solutions. When used in the food market, metal has the advantage of retaining nutritional value,
without the requirement for preservatives. From a supply chain perspective, metal packaging allows for efficient transportation
and storage and is suited to processing on installed high-speed filling lines and retort processes.

Despite competition from other formats and materials, metal cans remain a key food packaging format, owing to their
attractive value proposition. The use of metal cans as a food packaging format is expected to have modest but stable growth of
0.6% per annum in the Group’s key markets of Western Europe, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa, between 2020
and 2025, principally driven by macroeconomic growth, as forecasted by Smithers.

Metal packaging is also increasingly attractive to both brands and end-consumers who are increasingly focused on
sustainability. Metal packaging has significant advantages compared to other packaging substrates. Recycling rates for steel
and aluminum in Europe are 83% and 76%, respectively, according to Metal Packaging Europe, amongst the highest of any
substrate. Moreover, metal’s properties never degrade during use or recycling, as a result, metal is considered a permanent
material and plays a critical role in the circular economy. Additionally, all unused material in the production process can be
recycled back into production, so no metal scrap created in production goes to waste. Beyond recyclability, metal packaging
also aids in sustainability on account of its functionality. Superior barrier properties (as described above) compared to other
substrates make metal packaging ideal for food preservation, reducing food waste, increasing the accessibility of healthy foods
in an economical manner and providing contamination protection, reducing the prevalence of food-borne illnesses.

Metal has gained increasing traction with brand owners who want to meet their own goals and commitments for
sustainability to satisfy their own end-consumers preferences. Companies such as Nestle and Princes Group, both key customers
of Titan Group, have stated that they intend to use 100% recyclable or reusable packaging by 2025, and Nestle has announced
that they will entirely eliminate the use of ten problematic plastics in their packaging by 2024.

Products in the EMEA region’s food can industry are concentrated amongst three food can types: 3-Piece, 2-Piece
Drawn and Wall Ironed (“DWI”) and 2-piece Draw Redraw (“DRD”). 3-Piece is a well-established, lower cost steel can with
flexible sizes that is used for almost all end-markets, including fish, culinary, pet and nutritional. 2-Piece Drawn Wall Ironed is
typically made of steel and has low production costs, high potential for down gauging and fewer can failure modes (with no
side seam or end seam) used mostly for seasonal, culinary and pet food end-markets. 2-Piece Draw Redraw is made from steel
or aluminum. This is used for shallower cans, offering a wide variety of shapes and high-quality printing. This can mostly
serves the fish, culinary and pet food end-markets.

Most of the sales in the EMEA region are concentrated in the 3-Piece steel cans, making up 73% of sales, with 2-Piece
Aluminum, 2-Piece Steel and other can types making up 11%, 15%, and 1% of can sales in the EMEA market, respectively, as
of October 2020, according to Management estimates. Titan Group’s product offering is aligned with the market. 74% of our
sales are 3-Piece Steel, and 2-Piece Aluminum and 2-Piece Steel make up 4% and 22% of our sales in the year ended December
31, 2020, respectively.

Metal packaging manufacturers hold a critical position in the EMEA food packaging supply chain. Tinplate is the
main raw material used in metal packaging production, with approximately 90% of all tinplate produced being used for
packaging products according to a leading global consulting firm. This creates an important dynamic between tin manufacturers
and can producers. Tinplate manufacturers rely on can manufacturers for a stable source of demand. As EU’s largest buyer of
tinplate, consuming 20% of all production in 2019 according to Management estimates, Titan Group represents a critical partner
to all major tinplate suppliers in Europe. On the consumers’ side, food producers and can fillers are highly fragmented and are


-----

dependent on the quality, safety and availability of cans. The critical position of can manufacturers in the value chain between
tinplate producers and food producers and can fillers provides staying power and margin expansion opportunities.

**Market Development and Outlook**

The food can packaging market, which is the second largest metal can packaging category globally after beverage
cans according to Wall Street equity research, has historically experienced stable demand throughout economic cycles. In
Europe, the food cans industry sold approximately 26.7 billion units in 2020 according to a leading global consulting firm,
representing a CAGR of 0.2% since 2015. Specifically, many key food end-markets including fruit & vegetables, shelf stable
fish, culinary (such as baked beans), pet food and infant formula have shown resilience over time. According to a leading global
consulting firm analysis representing trends for European food cans volume sold, market growth of fruits & vegetables, culinary
and pet food have each fluctuated by CAGRs of less than +/-1% between 2015 and 2020. Shelf stable fish, culinary and pet
food are expected to fluctuate by CAGRs of less than +/-1% between 2020 and 2024, with infant nutrition expected to grow by
a CAGR of 1.0% from 2020 to 2023. Fruits & vegetables are expected to decline by a CAGR of 1.4% between 2020 and 2024.

Shelf stable foods represent a consumer diet staple across most cultures and geographies. Metal cans currently
represent the best barrier material and provides over two years of shelf-life, which is critical for managing seasonal harvest
cycles. This shelf-life helps maintain the availability of the underlying food product for consumers, should there be a poor
harvest of the relevant item during this two-year period. In 2020, shelf stable foods experienced additional growth attributed to
an increase in at-home meal consumption and evolving consumer preferences due to the COVID-19 pandemic, although this
benefit was somewhat offset by reduced demand for food cans in food service applications. A majority of the recent demand
increases and underlying trends are forecast to persist according to a leading global consulting firm, with sustainability trends
expected to provide favorable long-term market tailwinds. These developments are supported by recent innovations into
convenient, single-serve packaging offerings. Pet food and infant nutrition represent particular areas of potential growth. The
dog and cat populations in Europe continue to increase and pet owners have demonstrated a willingness to spend considerable
sums on their pets. Furthermore, Europe exports a significant amount of infant nutrition products and over the past 10 years
over $1 billion has been invested in Europe for filling infant nutrition into metal cans.

**_Competitive Landscape_**

The European food cans and ends packaging market is mature and heavily consolidated with the top two players, Titan
Group is a clear leader in the food can market, with 39% market share based on 2019 / 2020 EU food cans volume. Collectively,
the top two participants in the market hold a combined market share of over 65% based on 2019 / 2020 volume, with no other
manufacturer having a market share of greater than 3% according to leading global consulting firm. Other manufacturers consist
of mostly regional or local manufacturers, which are limited in scale and footprint to serve customers on a pan-European basis.

The European food cans and ends packaging market is relatively insulated from imports given the uneconomical cost
of shipping finished metal packaging long distances. In addition, due to the time sensitive nature of customers’ requirements,
customers prefer shorter supply chains, benefiting manufacturers that are located nearby to customers. Furthermore, new
challengers in the markets face significant obstacles in the form of high barriers to entry for numerous reasons. Sizable capital
requirements are needed to add capacity, particularly in the front-end of operations such as coil cutting, printing and lacquering.
Additionally, new entrants find economic benefits of adding capacity limited, especially in mature markets with entrenched
customers. There are also rigorous qualification requirements demanded by sensitive food end-markets. Additionally, many
customers have filling lines which are tuned to work with certain suppliers, resulting in high switching costs and creating a
barrier for new entrants in the market. Lastly, inherent strengths of the metal substrate, including rigidity and corrosion
resistance, provides tinplate with a degree of protection against substitution from other substrates like aluminum or plastics.

**_Additional Product Markets_**

Closures, aerosols and promotional packaging markets represent smaller subsectors of the metal packaging industry.
Metal vacuum closures exist in a variety of shapes, sizes and specifications and help provide easy-open convenience and visual
appeal for packaging across various substrates. Aerosols come in various diameters and finishings, serving mainly the personal
care, food and household end-markets. Promotional and premium containers come in numerous lid and closure variations,
servicing mostly the biscuits, powders, confectionery and syrup end-markets.

Within Closures, Titan Group holds the number two market position with over 25% market share in Europe as of
October 2020 according to Management estimates. The Group’s primary closures competitors include Silgan, Technocap and
Massilly.


-----

Titan Group also holds the number two market position in Aerosol packaging, with over 10% market share in Europe
as of October 2020 according to Management estimates. The Group’s primary competitors in aerosols include Colep, Sarten,
Staehle and Trivium amongst numerous smaller, regional manufacturers. The Group offers tinplate 3-piece aerosol cans for
personal care, food, household and industrial markets.

The Group is also the number one European player for promotional packaging, with over 20% market share in Europe
as of October 2020 according to Management estimates. The Group’s primary competitors for this product segment include
Envases Europe, Klann, smaller, regional manufacturers and various international competitors.

**Overview**

We are a European leader in the design, manufacture and sale of metal packaging solutions, with number one or
number two market positions across our product groups in the countries we operate in. We are the clear market leader in the
26.7-billion-unit European market for metal food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with an approximate
39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. As the largest European manufacturer of metal food
cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel (based on our estimated consumption of approximately 20% of
total European tinplate production), our business is a critical asset in the European food supply chain.

We have been in the industry for more than 200 years and have an established reputation for the highest quality
products and exceptional customer service. From the founding of our predecessor business in 1799 to our acquisition by Crown
in 1996 and our acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, our business has shown itself to be a leader in European metal packaging time
and time again. Following the Transactions, we will become a leading stand-alone business in Europe.

Our product portfolio consists predominantly of food packaging, with approximately 95% of our sales in the year
ended December 31, 2020 going to food related end markets. Our products are used by hundreds of millions of consumers on
a daily basis across Europe, the Middle East and Africa. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12
billion food cans, approximately 24 billion ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol
cans and approximately 134 million metal promotional packaging containers. Our products are used to package food in a
diverse array of end-markets, including fruits and vegetables, tomatoes, fish, pet food, culinary, infant nutrition and dairy. Each
of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers that are stable and largely uncorrelated with broader
macroeconomic cycles.

Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and
negotiated raw material pass-through mechanisms, providing us with margin stability and consistent historical cash flows. We
have demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Moreover,
as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Titan Group’s pass-through was on track for full recovery of raw material price
increases in 2021. Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up
to 40% of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts

We operate 44 strategically located manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be
transferred at the end of the transition period) in 17 countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, which enhance our access
to customer end-markets and support local demand. Our manufacturing scale is complemented by our services and customer
support capabilities including over 20 technical services locations, seven dedicated product design studios, four dedicated
laboratory testing facilities and a world-class research and development facility that have put us at the forefront of the European
tinplate packaging industry.

In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had net sales of $2,241 million, $2,138 million and $2,227

**Strengths**

**_1. Longstanding European market leader and critical asset in the European food packaging supply chain_**

We are the clear leader in the European market for food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with
an approximate 39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. Sales of metal food cans and ends
represented 85% of our total revenue in this period. We also believe that we hold the number one or number two market position
in Europe across the other product categories we serve, namely metal closures, aerosol cans and promotional containers with
market shares of approximately 28%, 12% and 24%, respectively, measured by volume for the year ended December 31, 2020.
We have been in the European market for over 200 years and have a reputation with customers for providing the highest quality
products and superior service.

In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12 billion food cans, approximately 24 billion
ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol cans and approximately 134 million metal
promotional packaging containers. Including intermediate precursor products, our manufacturing assets produce 500 million
products per day on average. We have a well-established manufacturing presence with 44 strategically located manufacturing
facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period) across 17 countries
enhancing access to customers, end markets, local demand and suppliers. We operate 34 food cans & ends manufacturing
facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period), five closures
manufacturing facilities, three aerosol manufacturing facilities and three promotional packaging manufacturing facilities. We
have a well-invested asset base supported by in-house research and development expertise. We believe the investment required
to replicate our facility footprint, in addition to the know-how of operating canmaking assets that we developed over our history
create high barriers to entry.

The European market for food cans and ends is mature and highly consolidated with the top two players, ourselves
and our primary competitor, holding a combined market share of over 65% based on volume in the year ended December 31,
2020. The third largest manufacturer has a market share of 3%. Other competitors consist of mostly regional or local
manufacturers, who lack the ability to serve larger food customers at scale or are limited in their ability to serve customers
across multiple geographies. The European food cans and ends market is relatively insulated from import competition given
the high cost of shipping metal packaging long distances and the short lead times customers demand. Due to the significance
of transportation costs in the food can industry, our regional production capabilities support expedient and cost-efficient
transportation to local customers. Furthermore, there are high barriers to entry due to sizeable capital requirements needed to


-----

add capacity, rigorous qualification requirements demanded by customers, and heightened scrutiny with respect to safety
requirements as a result of serving sensitive food end-markets.

We hold a critical position in the European food packaging supply chain as the largest European manufacturer of metal
food cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel. Our business is the key link between tinplate steel, a
commodity raw material that we purchase and convert to finished packaging for our large and fragmented, primarily European,
customer base of food manufacturers. Can producers are the largest consumers of tinplate steel in Europe, with approximately
90% of tinplate steel in Europe being used in packaging, of which 40 to 50% is for food cans and 10 to 15% is for each of
beverages, general line, aerosols and closures. Moreover, the market is largely stable with no significant shifts expected. We
are Europe’s largest buyer of tinplate, consuming approximately 20% of all tinplate production in Europe in 2020 according to
Management estimates. Tinplate steel suppliers rely on us for a stable source of demand, and our position as the largest
consumer of tinplate steel makes us a critical partner to all of the major suppliers of tinplate steel in the European market. Our
over 1,000 customers rely on us as Europe’s largest supplier of food cans and ends. Because of our scale, we are often the only
supplier that can serve high volume customers on a pan-European basis. Our customers depend on our supply to go to market
and rely on our packaging to ensure their products reach store shelves. We provide their products with the benefit of a long
shelf life that metal food cans offer. Our packaging is an important part of our customers’ brands, and we work closely with
our customers to develop designs that ensure their products are attractive to end-consumers at points of sale.

**_2. Diverse, stable revenue mix with exposure to a range of non-cyclical, food-related end markets_**

We sell essential food packaging products into a highly diverse mix of geographies, customers and end-markets, which
supports revenue stability and resilience. Our products serve over 90 countries consisting of both sales into mature, developed
countries and higher growth, developing countries. No single country represented more than 15% of our sales in the year ended
December 31, 2020, with the largest contributors being France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany at 15%, 14%,
12%, 11% and 7% of sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020.

Our product portfolio consists 95% of food packaging, which has historically experienced stable demand throughout
economic cycles. We serve numerous food-related end-markets, including shelf-stable fruit and vegetables, shelf-stable fish,
culinary (such as baked beans), pet food and infant formula, which represented 24%, 18%, 11%, 8% and 8% of sales,
respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020. Each of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers, such as
population growth, eating at home trends, urbanization, and a growing global middle class, that are stable and largely
uncorrelated with broader macroeconomic cycles, and not subject to significant innovation threats.


-----

**Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020**

Metal cans represent the best barrier material and provide a shelf life of over two years while still retaining the
freshness of the food being packaged. In addition, metal food cans provide a host of other benefits to our customers, including
i) allowing for fast filling speeds with limited loss, ii) having high strength and allowing for ease of handling and iii) being
resistant to corrosion, thereby allowing for high-acid contents (e.g., tomatoes). These qualities make our products highly costeffective solutions for our customers and limit the threat of substitution from other substrates.

The stability of our end-markets is evidenced by their historical and forecast growth rates. According to a leading
global consulting firm market growth for the packaging of shelf stable vegetables, culinary products, infant nutrition products
and shelf stable fish in Europe have each fluctuated by CAGRs of less than +/-1.5% between 2015 and 2020, and are expected
to fluctuate by CAGRs of less than +/-1.5% between 2020 and 2024. Furthermore, between 2015 and 2020 the food can volumes
sold in Iberia grew by a CAGR of 2% and in our other key markets of France, Italy, the UK and Germany food can volumes
fluctuated by a CAGR of less than +/-1.5% over this period.

**_3. Diverse, blue-chip customer base with longstanding, contractual relationships_**

We supply over 1,000 customers across a range of resilient product categories and end markets. No single customer
represented more than 8% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, with our top 10 customers representing 32% of
sales for the same period. Our customers include blue-chip, global food and consumer businesses including Abbott, Bonduelle,
Danone, Nestle and Unilever, large national and regional food companies, as well as many smaller and independent fisheries
and farmers. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having worked with our top 10 customers on
average for over 25 years. We are the sole or main supplier for several of our top customers. We believe that the quality of our
products, our track record of providing reliable supply proven over decades and the significant costs to customers involved in
switching manufacturers creates customer stickiness. Before a manufacturing plant or line can begin manufacturing new can
SKUs for a customer, its products typically must be qualified through a process that can take several months to over a year. In
addition, can manufacturers may face downtime on their lines when running new SKUs, thereby impacting customers’ security
and reliability of supply. Customers who decide to change manufacturers also typically lose the benefit of volume rebates from
former suppliers and face uncertainty regarding the stability, reliability and quality of their new partners.

Customers praise our technological know-how, understanding of their requirements and ability to produce and deliver
large volumes of specialty food cans consistently on time and in full. Our customers incur high costs if their packaging is not
delivered when required. As an example, tomatoes must be sealed in their packaging within six hours of being picked to ensure
their freshness, often requiring our manufacturing facilities to ship dozens of truckloads of food cans per day in a continuous
rotation to certain customer facilities during harvest season. We are recognized as an industry leader in product development
and deliver solutions that offer greater consumer convenience and functionality in response to market demands. Can fillers
require producers who can satisfy their branding, quality and safety needs. We believe we consistently satisfy these needs and
enable our customers to differentiate their brands through packaging and address changing safety requirements ahead of time.

**_4. Sustainability- and consumer-driven tailwinds benefit metal packaging_**

Our metal packaging products are favorably positioned to benefit from the increase in demand for sustainable
packaging given their infinitely recyclable nature. Greater environmental consciousness and strong sustainability trends are
expected to support an increased preference for metal packaging over the long-term. End consumers increasingly view
sustainability as a key purchasing criteria and seek out more environmentally friendly packaging. Food producers – our
customers – are aggressively responding to this demand. For example, several major food conglomerates have announced that
they aim to sell mostly recyclable or reusable materials by 2025. These trends are further reinforced by regulatory
developments. For example, the EU circular economy plan adopted in 2020 has a clear focus on recyclable packaging, which
is likely to put pressure on plastic in favor of other packaging materials. Metal packaging provides excellent options for the
sustainability initiatives of companies and brands, since metal properties do not degrade during use or recycling. Consumers
already recognize metal packaging as a highly recyclable substrate, evidenced by recycling rates of over 80% for steel and 75%
for aluminum in Europe, and food brands increasingly want to position themselves as environmentally friendly.

As a further sustainability benefit, metal packaging’s superior barrier properties make it ideal for food preservation,
which reduces food waste. Metal packaging increases the accessibility of healthy foods in an economical manner and provides
contamination protection, thereby reducing the prevalence of food-borne illnesses.


-----

Within the metal packaging industry, we are a European leader in sustainability awareness as a Co-Founder of the
Metal Packaging Europe Association and an active participant in other major sustainability focused associations, which serve
as conduits for sustainability reform at the regulatory and legislative level.

**_5. Attractive financial profile with flexible cost structure and ability to generate consistent free cash flow_**

We have a strong track-record of robust free cash flow generation and cash conversion as a result of our flexible cost
structure and resilient cash flows. We generated average annual free cash flow of $239 million and an average cash conversion
rate of approximately 88% from 2018 to 2020.

Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and
negotiated pass-through mechanisms, providing us with consistent historical cash flows and supporting our margins. We have
demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Based on
Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up to 40% of total sales secured
on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts stipulate a guaranteed
percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, over 97% of
Titan Group’s pricing for 2021 was already agreed.

We estimate that approximately 87% of our cost base is fully- or semi-variable, consisting mostly of material costs,
labor costs, freight, energy, which represented 61%, 15%, 5% and 3%, respectively, of our total costs for the year ended
December 31, 2020 in addition to other consumables. The semi-variable characteristics of our labor costs come from our ability
to reduce our labor costs through the use of seasonal and temporary employees. Our variable cost structure allows us to quickly
adapt our production capacity to harvest cycles, which can result in modest volume fluctuations from year to year.

Our cash flow stability is bolstered by the non-cyclical end-markets we serve, our ability to pass-through raw material
prices changes, our long-term customer relationships with contracted volumes, and customer stickiness. Our modest capital
expenditure requirements and well-managed, disciplined approach to working capital further strengthen our free cash flow
conversion. We believe our free cash flow profile will enable us to reduce leverage through debt repayment over time.

**_6. Experienced management team supported by a best-in-class financial sponsor_**

We benefit from a talented management team with deep roots in the business and decades of experience. Our
management team has a strong track-record of value creation in the consumer packaging industry and has an average 30 years
of service in the industry.

Our management team has been involved in the preparation of our transition from being a part of Crown to operating
as a stand-alone business, including the development of our stand-alone strategy. We have also moved to reinforce the team in
its new existence as a stand-alone company by announcing the appointment of Tomás López as Chief Executive Officer. Mr
López will bring experience and a track-record of success in managing Mivisa before it was acquired by Crown. See also
“Management.”

KPS Capital Partners (“KPS”) has a strong track-record of realising improvements in manufacturing companies and
over two decades of constructive investing in highly complex corporate carve-outs on a global basis. KPS creates value for its
investors by working constructively with talented management teams to make businesses better, and generates investment
returns by structurally improving the strategic position, competitiveness and profitability of its portfolio companies, rather than
primarily relying on financial leverage. KPS will support management and leverage its core operational improvement expertise.
Furthermore, Crown will retain a 20% equity stake in the stand-alone company, validating its belief in the potential of the
business and allow for a smooth transition of the business to an independent company.

**Strategy**

Our strong cash flow generation has historically been utilized in support of broader goals within the larger Crown
organization. We have a unique position in the European food supply chain as the largest manufacturer of food cans and ends
in Europe and we believe that we are the largest buyer of tinplate steel in Europe. We believe that, despite our market position,
our historic margins have lagged those of key competitors and our own potential as a result of the lack of focus on our business
under our prior owners. Under Crown’s ownership, the business has mainly focused on volumes and cash generation to support
Crown’s other businesses, which presents a significant opportunity for margin improvement. From 2017 to 2020, Titan Group
represented approximately 20% of Crown’s sales but only 8% of its capital expenditures.


-----

As a stand-alone business, we aim to reorient the business towards growth and margin improvement. Capitalizing on
the above strengths as a stand-alone business, we believe we have numerous levers to create additional value, grow volumes,
improve profitability and generate cash flows.

**_1. New Markets and Growth Opportunities_**

The Business has numerous growth opportunities arising from favorable consumption trends, such as a greater focus
on convenience, growth in single serve packaging, increasing premiumization and higher focus on sustainability. Operating as
a stand-alone entity, we will have greater flexibility to pursue opportunities that were not previously considered or prioritized
while integrated within the wider Crown business. In addition, we will have the benefit of a steady capital expenditure program
that is focused on our business, allowing us to pursue multi-year growth projects which we were unable to pursue under prior
ownership. End-markets such as infant nutrition and wet petfood have volume growth opportunities at attractive margins that
we believe we can capture by employing our capabilities and expertise developed in other end-markets. Our metal cans are
well-positioned to benefit from these growth opportunities in light of their favorable barrier properties and the premium
perception and convenience that our products offer. In addition, we are focused on growing our share and penetration in key
emerging markets such as Eastern Europe and Africa, where our existing customers are establishing footprints that we can
readily support with existing technologies and know-how.

**_2. Procurement Optimization_**

Tinplate steel makes up for more than 80% of our raw materials spend and represented 48% of our cost of products
sold in the year ended December 31, 2020. We believe our market position enables us to optimize sourcing and pricing for our
tinplate steel purchases and provides further opportunities for margin expansion. While the Business under Crown’s ownership
mainly focused on ensuring stability of supply and favorable working capital arrangements, as a stand-alone business we will
have the opportunity to manage supply arrangements in support of better margins, including through utilizing a greater share
of raw materials from low cost countries. We have developed optimization initiatives to realize the most favorable pricing with
suppliers for the highest quality tinplate with the shortest supply chain lead times.

There is potential for additional cost savings opportunities in the form of reduced spend on logistics, raw material
specification complexity reductions, indirect cost savings and contract structure improvements. We believe there is an
opportunity to purchase higher volume of fewer SKUs, and also consolidate production of precursor products into fewer
facilities, thereby reducing the number of facilities receiving raw material shipments and to improve the structure of certain of
our contracts. In addition, we believe there are opportunities to optimize indirect and other materials procurement through
targeted sourcing initiatives. In the three months ended March 31, 2021, Titan Group already realized the benefit of improved
procurement practices and commercial efforts, leading to expanding margins for this period.

**_3. Manufacturing Optimization_**

We expect to realize further efficiencies by improving the asset utilization and productivity of our manufacturing
footprint. We intend to employ targeted capital expenditures focused on modernizing the equipment used at several of our key
facilities with a goal of increasing the capacity of those facilities and allowing more efficient and cost-effective production
while reducing the number of facilities in our network.

Our Business grew substantially following the acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, however, we did not fully integrate the
Mivisa and legacy manufacturing footprints and did not achieve the margin targets or synergies forecast at the time. We believe
that there are certain manufacturing function overlaps and duplications as a result of the acquisition and our organic growth.
We intend to replicate the “hub and spoke” operating model, used successfully by Mivisa, whereby certain functions that can
easily and cost-effectively be transported are completed at lower cost plants to improve and optimize asset utilization. For
example, we believe that the manufacturing of ends and certain upstream functions such as metal processing and coating can
be consolidated into facilities that specialize in production of those precursor products. Such products would then be transported
to existing can finishing or assembly plants that are located close to our customers and have a lean operating footprint. This
approach was successfully developed at Mivisa, which operated the largest ends production facility in the world in Murcia,
Spain, producing more than 9 billion ends annually and serviced nearly its entire network using this plant and also serviced a
significant export business of ends. We intend to replicate this model across the Group’s existing manufacturing footprint.

**_4. Commercial Excellence and Continuous Improvement Initiatives_**

In addition to revenue improvement and market share capture, our strategy also has a strong focus on delivering further
cost savings and unlocking further margin improvement potential. We plan to develop a continuous improvement culture and


-----

invest in training across the entire business. KPS and Management have conducted a comprehensive and granular review of
our operating model. We believe that as a stand-alone business, we will be able to realize these cost savings and margin
expansions based on KPS’ proven track record in realising improvements in manufacturing businesses.

We have identified a number of commercial excellence and continuous improvement priorities, including (i) more
focused deployment of capital expenditures, (ii) quality management in the form of manufacturing and operational excellence
initiatives; (iii) maintenance and repair optimization, (iv) using a local sales force to improve engagement between our sales
and operations teams and (v) a focus on customer service, innovation and responsiveness initiatives. As a stand-alone business
focused on the manufacturing of food cans and ends, we will be more readily able to pursue these opportunities rather than
having to compete with the other capital priorities of our former owner.

Our planned capital projects include investments focused on asset productivity, such as tooling upgrades to multi-die
presses and high speed printing and coating lines capable of delivering up to 300% improvements in productivity. Our planned
capital projects typically have a payback of approximately two to three years. We also believe there is an opportunity to improve
the effectiveness of our commercial function by streamlining our financial reporting structure, providing greater visibility to
our local sales teams and enabling them to optimize the margin profile of products they are selling. We believe our customers
derive significant value from our product offering and we intend to capture additional margin for the superior service and
capabilities that we offer.

**Our History**

We have been in the industry for more than 200 years and have an established reputation for the highest quality
products and exceptional customer service. From the founding of our predecessor business in 1799 to our acquisition by Crown
in 1996 and our acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, our business has shown itself to be a leader in European metal packaging time
and time again. Following the Transactions, we will become a leading stand-alone business in Europe.

The businesses, operations, assets and liabilities comprising the Titan Group are currently being operated as part and
under the umbrella of the global Crown Group. On April 8, 2021, Bidco and Crown entered into the Acquisition Agreement
pursuant to which Crown has agreed to sell the Titan Group to Bidco pursuant to the terms and conditions set forth in the
Acquisition Agreement. Upon completion of the Acquisition, Bidco and its direct and indirect shareholders will become the
majority shareholder of our business (with Crown retaining a 20% ownership stake) and Titan Group will operate on a
standalone basis, see also “Risk Factors––We have no operating history as a standalone company.”

The proceeds of the Offering will, upon satisfaction of the conditions to release from the Escrow Account, be used to
fund part of the cash portion of the consideration due to Crown under the Acquisition Agreement. As of the date of this Offering
Memorandum, neither the Issuer, nor Bidco has any material assets or liabilities nor have the Issuer or Bidco engaged in any
activities other than those related to their incorporation and registration and the Acquisition. Unless otherwise required by the
context, this Offering Memorandum presents our business and operations and other information as if the Acquisition has
occurred.

**Our Products**

We supply total packaging solutions, including metal cans, ends and closures, tinplate aerosol cans and promotional
premium metal containers while working closely with customers, retailers and glass and plastic container manufacturers to
develop innovative closure solutions and meet customer requirements. The Group’s commitment to innovation has led to
developments in packaging materials, surface finishes, can shaping, lithography, filling, retorting, sealing and opening
techniques and environmental performance. Through our manufacturing network of 44 facilities in Europe, the Middle East
and Africa (and the Braunstone UK facility, which Crown will transfer to the Titan Group post-closing), we serve our customers
in over 92 countries.

**_Food Cans and Ends_**

The Group manufactures a variety of food cans, including two-piece and three-piece cans in numerous shapes and
sizes, which are being sold to global and regional food producers, independent fisheries and farmers. Some of Titan Group’s
food cans and ends customers include Abbot Laboratories, Bonduelle, C&D Foods, Jealsa, Nestle and Princes Group, among
others. Technologies used to produce food cans include three-piece welded, two-piece drawn and wall-ironed and two-piece
drawn and redrawn.


-----

The Group also manufactures easy open, vacuum and conventional ends for a variety of heat-processed and dry food
products including fruits and vegetables, meat and seafood, soups, ready-made meals, infant formula, coffee and pet food. The
Group owns several trademarks and offers a series of can ends, including its Easylift™ full aperture steel food can ends, and
PeelSeam™ and PeelFit™, flexible aluminum foil laminated food can ends to its customers.

We serve our food cans and ends customers from our 34 metal can and ends manufacturing facilities located in Europe,
the Middle East and Africa.

**_Closures_**

The Group also offers a wide variety of metal vacuum closures and sealing equipment solutions to leading global and
regional food producers including Andros Foods, Danone, Greencore, Neerlands Glorie, Orkla and Unilever, among others.


-----

The Group offers expertise in closure design and decoration, ranging from quality printing of the closure in up to nine colors,
to inside-the-cap printing, which offers customers new promotional possibilities and better product protection through our
trademark Orbit™. We serve our closures customers from five manufacturing facilities located in Europe.

**_Aerosol Cans_**

The Group’s customers for aerosol cans and ends include manufacturers of personal care, food, household and
industrial products, including Friesland Campina, SC Johnson, Unilever and WD-40, among others. The Group offers its
customers a broad range of products including multiple sizes and finishing schemes as well as a full array of design, technical
and market support services. We serve our aerosols customers from three aerosols manufacturing facilities located in Europe.


-----

**_Promotional Packaging_**

The Group’s promotional packaging business is primarily located in Europe. The Group produces a wide variety of
promotional and premium containers with numerous lid and closure variations. The Group offers its customers an extensive
portfolio of packaging designs and printing capabilities that help differentiate its products (and those of its customers) in the
marketplace. The Group was awarded the Can of the Year award in 2020 by The Canmaker magazine for packaging it designed
and produced for Fishers Gin, which serves as an example of the Group’s leading capabilities in promotional packaging. Some
of the Group’s promotional packaging customers include Ferrero, Britvic Nestle and Mondelez, primarily for promotional
activities. We serve our promotional packaging customers from three promotional packaging manufacturing facilities located
in the United Kingdom.

**Sales and Distribution**

Titan Group’s customers qualify suppliers on the basis of their ability to provide consistent service with strong quality
performance, innovative designs and technologies in a cost-effective manner.


-----

The Group markets and sells products to customers through its own sales and marketing staff. Contracts with large
customers are generally centrally negotiated, but products are ordered through and distributed directly by the Group’s local
facilities. The Group’s facilities are generally located in proximity to their respective major customers, particularly for food
cans, as these products do not ship cost-effectively across long distances. The Group works closely with customers to develop
new business and to extend the terms and scope of its existing contracts.

Many customers provide the Group with quarterly or annual estimates of product requirements along with related
quantities pursuant to which periodic commitments are given. Such estimates assist the Group in managing production and
controlling use of working capital. The Group schedules its production to meet customer requirements. Because the production
time for the Group’s products is short, any backlog of customer orders in relation to overall sales is not significant.

**Seasonality**

The food packaging business is seasonal with the first quarter tending to be the slowest period as the autumn packing
period in the Northern Hemisphere has ended and new crops are not yet planted. The industry generally enters its busiest period
in the third quarter when the majority of fruits and vegetables are harvested. Due to this seasonality, inventory levels increase
in the first half of the year to meet peak demand in the second and third quarters. Weather represents a substantial uncertainty
in the yield of food products and is a major factor in determining the demand for food cans in any given year. See also “Risk
_Factors––Titan Group's business is seasonal and adverse weather conditions could reduce Titan Group's net sales.”_

The Group’s other businesses primarily include aerosol and specialty packaging and can making equipment, which
tend not to be as significantly affected by seasonal variations.

**Competition**

Most of the Group’s products are sold in highly competitive markets, primarily based on price, quality, service and
performance. The Business competes with other packaging manufacturers as well as with fillers, food processors and packers,
who, to a limited extent, manufacture containers for their own use and for sale to others. The Group’s competitors include, but
are not limited to, Massilly, Silgan Holdings, Trivium, Auxiliar, DomIberia, Glud Marstrand and Sarten.

**Customers**

The Group’s customers consist of global and regional food producers, consumer products manufacturers and
marketers and independent fisheries and farmers. The Group was the sole or primary supplier for its top ten customers with
whom it had an average relationship of over 25 years. The Group’s top ten customers represented in the aggregate
approximately 32% of its net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. In each of the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019
and 2018, no one customer accounted for more than 7% of the Group’s net sales. See also “Risk Factors––The loss of a major
_customer and/or customer consolidation could reduce Titan Group's net sales and profitability.” The contracts with our_
customers generally provide for the pass-through of metal price fluctuations. In addition, multiyear relationships allow both
parties to work together to streamline the product, service and supply process, potentially leading to cost reductions and
improvements in product and service, with benefits arising to both parties. Wherever possible, we seek to enter into multi-year
supply agreements with our customers. See also below under “––Research and Development.” Titan’s product offerings are
complemented by topline services and customer support. Titan Group has over 20 customer technical services locations, 7
dedicated product design studios and 4 dedicated laboratory testing facilities.

**Research and Development**

The Group’s principal Research, Development & Engineering (“RD&E”) Center is located in Wantage, England. The
Group utilizes its centralized RD&E capabilities to advance and deliver technologies for its international packaging activities
that (1) promote development of value-added metal packaging systems for its customers, (2) design cost-efficient
manufacturing processes, systems and materials that further the sustainability of metal packaging, (3) provide continuous
quality and/or production efficiency improvements in its manufacturing facilities, (4) advance customer and vendor
relationships, and (5) provide value-added engineering services and technical support. These capabilities facilitate (1) the
identification of new and/or expanded market opportunities by working directly with customers to develop new packaging
products or enhance existing packaging products through the application of new technologies that better differentiate our
customers’ products in the retail environment (for example, the creation of new packaging shapes or novel decoration methods)
and/or the incorporation of consumer-valued features (for example, improved openability and ease of use) and (2) the reduction
of manufacturing costs by reducing the material content of the Group‘s products (while retaining necessary performance
characteristics), reducing spoilage, and increasing operating efficiencies in our manufacturing facilities.


-----

The Group maintains a substantial portfolio of patents and other intellectual property (IP) in the field of metal
packaging ends and closures, in particular, and seeks strategic partnerships to extend its IP in existing and emerging markets.

The Group spent $6.9 million, $6.8 million and $7.3 million in the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018,
respectively in its centralized RD&E activities. Certain of these activities are expected to improve and expand the Group’s
product lines in the future. These expenditures include projects within the Group’s RD&E facilities to improve manufacturing
efficiencies, reduce unit costs, and develop new and improved value-added packaging systems. These expenditures do not
include related product and process developments occurring within the Group’s decentralized business units.

**Materials and Suppliers**

The Group uses various raw materials, primarily tinplate steel, in its manufacturing operations. In general, these raw
materials are purchased in highly competitive, price-sensitive markets which have historically exhibited price and demand
cyclicality. These and other materials used in the manufacturing process have historically been available in adequate supply
from multiple sources.

Generally, the Group’s principal raw materials are obtained from the major suppliers in the regions in which it operates
plants. Titan Group estimates that it sources approximately 75-80% of its tinplate from the largest three European suppliers and
up to 25% from European challengers and imports from outside Europe, including China, Japan, Turkey and South Korea.
Some plants in less developed countries, which do not have local mills, obtain raw materials from nearby, more developed
countries. The Group has agreements for what it considers adequate supplies of raw materials. However, sufficient quantities
may not be available in the future due to, among other things, shortages due to excessive demand, weather or other factors,
including disruptions in supply caused by raw material transportation or production delays. From time to time, some of the raw
materials have been in short supply but, to date, these shortages have not had a significant impact on the Group’s operations.
See also “Risk Factors––Titan Group's financial results could be materially adversely affected if Titan Group is not able to
_secure sufficient quantities of raw materials or if the price of raw materials or energy rises and Titan Group cannot increase_
_the price of its products.”_

In the year ended December 31, 2020, consumption of tinplate steel represented approximately 48% of consolidated
cost of products sold, excluding depreciation and amortization. Due to the significance of tinplate steel to overall cost of
products sold, raw material efficiency is a critical cost component of the products manufactured. Supplier consolidations,
changes in ownership, government regulations, political unrest and increased demand for raw materials in the packaging and
other industries, among other risk factors, provide uncertainty as to the availability of and the level of prices at which the Group
might be able to source such raw materials in the future. Moreover, the price of raw materials can be subject to significant
volatility. The Group’s raw material supply contracts vary as to terms and duration, with tinplate steel contracts typically one
year in duration with fixed prices for the year. The Group generally attempts to mitigate its steel price risk by matching its
purchase obligations with its sales agreements; however, there can be no assurance that the Group will be able to fully mitigate
that risk. See also “Risk Factors––Titan Group's financial results could be materially adversely affected if Titan Group is not
_able to secure sufficient quantities of raw materials or if the price of raw materials or energy rises and Titan Group cannot_
_increase the price of its products.”_

There can be no assurance that the Group will be able to fully recover from its customers the impact of raw material
price increases or that the use of derivative instruments will effectively manage the Group’s exposure to price volatility. In
addition, if the Group is unable to purchase raw materials, particularly tinplate steel, for a significant period of time, its
operations would be disrupted and if the Group were unable to fully recover the higher cost of those raw materials, its financial
results may be adversely affected. The Group continues to monitor this situation and the effect on its operations. As a result of
continuing international supply and demand pressures, other commodity-related costs affecting the Group’s business may
increase as well, including natural gas, electricity and freight-related costs. The Group will attempt to increase prices on its
products accordingly in order to recover these costs.

In response to the volatility of raw material prices, ongoing productivity and cost reduction efforts in recent years
have focused on improving raw material cost management.

The Group’s manufacturing facilities are dependent, in varying degrees, upon the availability of water and processed
energy, such as natural gas and electricity. Certain of these may become difficult or impossible to obtain on acceptable terms
due to external factors which could increase the Group’s costs or interrupt its business.

**Sustainability and Environmental, Health and Safety Matters**

The Group’s Credit Facilities Agreement is currently planned to incorporate a sustainability ratchet, whereby the
margin thereunder is subject to adjustment based on the Group’s performance measured against certain key performance
indicators, currently envisioned to be centered around greenhouse gas emissions, product lifecycle management and air quality.
The Group’s operations are subject to numerous laws and regulations governing the protection of the environment, including
notably those relating to treatment, storage and disposal of waste, the use of chemicals in the Group’s products and
manufacturing process, discharges into water, emissions into the atmosphere, remediation of soil and groundwater
contamination and protection of employee health and safety. Future regulations may impose stricter environmental
requirements on the packaging industry and may require additional capital investment. Anticipated future restrictions in some
jurisdictions on the use of certain coatings may require the Group to employ additional control equipment or process
modifications.

The Group has a Corporate Sustainability Policy and a Corporate Environmental Protection Policy. Environmental
awareness is a key component of sustainability. Environmental considerations are among the criteria by which the Group
evaluates projects, products, processes and purchases. The Group is committed to continuous improvement in product design
and manufacturing practices to provide the best outcome for the human and natural environment, both now and in the future.
The Group has annual objectives with an emphasis on spoilage reduction, resource realignments, efficiency improvements and
labor savings. By reducing the per-unit amount of raw materials used in manufacturing its products through “lightweighting”,
the Group can significantly reduce the amount of energy, water and other resources and associated emissions necessary to
manufacture metal containers. The Group aims to continue that process of improvement in its manufacturing process through
investment in machinery upgrades with state-of-the-art, energy-efficient technologies and standardization programs focused on
material and efficiency savings to assure that consumers and the environment are best served through the use of metal
packaging. The Group is also committed to providing a safe work environment for its employees through programs that
emphasize safety awareness and the elimination of injuries and incidents. The Group had no significant incidents in 2020.There
can be no assurance that current or future environmental laws or liabilities will not have a material effect on the Group’s
financial condition, liquidity or results of operations. Discussion of the Group’s environmental matters is contained within
“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations- Environmental Matters” and
“Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements—Credit Facilities Agreement.”

**Insurance**

The Group carries insurance that it believes to be common in the industry and sufficient to cover the principal risks

such as fire, flood, storms and earthquakes), industrial accidents, third-party liability, directors’ and officers’ liability, and
cyber-crime. The Group undertakes periodic risk reviews to assess whether its insurance is in line with its business risks and
whether the developments in insurance policies are reflective of the changes in its business. See "Risk Factors - We may be

**Legal Proceedings**

In March 2015, the Bundeskartellamt, or German Federal Cartel Office (“FCO”), conducted unannounced inspections
of the premises of several metal packaging manufacturers, including one of the Group’s German subsidiaries. The local court
order authorizing the inspection cited FCO suspicions of anti-competitive agreements in the market for the supply of metal
packaging products. The Group conducted an internal investigation into the matter and discovered instances of inappropriate
conduct by certain employees of German subsidiaries of the Group. The Group cooperated with the FCO and submitted, in
September and October 2015, a leniency application with the FCO which disclosed the findings of its internal investigation to
date. In April 2018, the FCO discontinued its national investigation and referred the matter to the European Commission (the
“Commission”). Following the referral, Commission officials conducted unannounced inspections of the premises of several
metal packaging manufacturers, including Group subsidiaries in Germany, France and the United Kingdom.

The Commission’s investigation is ongoing and, to date, the Commission has not officially charged the Group or any
of its subsidiaries with violations of competition law. The Group is cooperating with the Commission and submitted a leniency
application in April 2018. This application may lead to the reduction of possible future penalties. At this stage of the
investigation the Group believes that a loss is probable but is unable to predict the ultimate outcome of the Commission’s


-----

investigation and is unable to estimate the loss or possible range of losses that could be incurred, and has therefore not recorded
a charge in connection with the actions by the Commission. If the Commission finds that the Group or any of its subsidiaries
violated competition law, fines levied by the Commission as well as third party damage claims by private enforcement, class
action or individual claims and any related costs and damages could be material to the Company’s operating results and cash
flows for the periods in which they are resolved or become reasonably estimable. In the Acquisition Agreement, Crown has
agreed to indemnify us for certain losses in connection with this investigation.

In March 2018, the French Competition Authority started a preliminary investigation regarding possible
infringements to French competition law with respect to the switch to bisphenol-A free cans in France which implemented
legislation restricting the use of bisphenol-A in all recipients as of 1 January 2015. The French Syndicat National des Fabricants
_de Boîtes, a trade association representing food can suppliers in France of which Titan Group is a member, received a_
questionnaire from the French Competition Authority asking for information regarding the trade association’s activities in
relation to the development of BPA-NI cans. The French Competition Authority opened formal proceedings regarding possible
infringements of competition law in relation to the switch to bisphenol-free cans in France in September 2019. In the context
of the formal proceedings, the French Competition Authority sent, in January and February 2020, two questionnaires to Titan
Group relating to its activities, internal organization and identification of its different entities and their respective turnovers. In
January 2021, Titan Group received a request from the French Competition Authority asking for the permission to declassify
documents previously provided by Titan Group in response to the questionnaires received and Titan Group gave the French
Competition Authority the permission to do so.

The French Competition Authority's investigation is ongoing and, to date, Titan Group has not received any further
requests nor questionnaires from the French Competition Authority. At this stage of the investigation, Titan Group is unable to
predict the ultimate outcome of the French Competition Authority's investigation and is unable to estimate the loss that it could
incur. Should the Board of the French Competition Authority finds that Titan Group or any of its subsidiary violated French
competition law, the fine levied by the French Competition Authority (the amount of which is determined on a case-by-case
basis depending notably on the seriousness of the infringement as well as its duration, but capped at 10% of the worldwide
turnover of the undertaking) could be material to Titan's Group's operating results and cash flows for the periods in which they
are resolved or become reasonably estimable, as well as third party damage claims by private enforcement. In the Acquisition
Agreement, Crown has agreed to indemnify Titan Group for certain losses in connection with this investigation.

In addition to the above legal matter, we are involved in certain other legal proceedings arising in the normal course
of our business. We believe none of these additional legal proceedings, either individually or in the aggregate, to have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial conditions, results of operations or cash flows. See “Titan Group is subject to an
_investigation by the European Commission relating to potential anti-competitive behavior and the outcome of this investigation_
_or future investigations could materially adversely affect Titan Group’s business, financial condition and results of operations.”_

**Related Party Transactions**

**_Shareholders’ Agreement_**

At the Completion Date, an entity affiliated with KPS and Crown will enter into a shareholders’ agreement with respect
to an indirect parent of the Issuer, which will set out the governance of the entity indirectly controlling the Issuer. The principal
terms of such shareholders’ agreement have been agreed in the Acquisition Agreement. KPS will control Titan Group and will
appoint the majority of the directors, with Crown to be granted customary protection for a minority shareholder (including a
consent right over changes to the nature of the business conducted by Titan Group and certain related party transactions). The
shareholders’ agreement will contain restrictions on the transfer of shares, tag-along, first refusal, pre-emptive and other rights
commensurate with KPS’s majority and Crown’s minority shareholdings. Other than customary non-solicit, non-hire and
confidentiality restrictions, the shareholders’ agreement will also contain a non-compete covenant by Crown pursuant to which
Crown, subject to customary conditions, shall not compete with the Business as conducted by Titan Group as at the Completion
Date.

**_Transitional Services Agreement_**

At the Completion Date, Bidco and Crown will enter into the Transitional Services Agreement, pursuant to which the
Crown and its affiliates (the “Crown Group”) and Bidco and its affiliates (the “Titan Group”) will provide services to each
other (the “Services”). The Services will generally relate to the following:

    - The Titan Group, will provide Crown with (i) master data and address book management and processing, (ii)
support on manufacturing accounting and shared service centre activities (e.g. IT, data management, accounting),
and (iii) legal, finance and human resources-related support services, including payroll support, based on Crown's
needs in certain European jurisdictions.

     - The Crown Group will provide the Titan Group with (i) support in shared service centre activities (e.g. IT, data
management, accounting) until the Business becomes autonomous, and (ii) legal, finance and human resourcesrelated support services, including payroll support, in the United Kingdom.

Certain facilities leased by the Titan Group and the Crown Group will be cost-shared in connection with the provision
of Services, with appropriate segregations in place between the Titan Group, on the one hand, and the Crown Group on the other
hand. The parties to the Transitional Services Agreement will also use commercially reasonable efforts to procure that the terms
and associated costs upon which the third party provides the Services are substantially equivalent to the terms and associated
costs enjoyed by the supplier prior to commencement of the Transitional Services Agreement (as adjusted for ordinary inflation
and/or current fluctuations in relation to third party inputs, to the extent applicable). Each party will retain all rights, title and
interest in the intellectual property for the Service it provides, provided that data or other intellectual property will be the property
of the party receiving such Service to the extent it is exclusively used in the receiving party’s business, and subject to certain
exceptions, the parties will license to one another, on a non-exclusive basis, the intellectual property needed to satisfy their
obligations under the Transitional Services Agreement.


-----

The Services will be provided by the parties at a fixed price exclusive of reasonable and documented out of pocket
expenses of the supplier party, which amounts (without mark-up) shall be borne by the recipient party. Proposed changes to the
costs of the Services shall be subject to the recipient party’s written approval (which shall not be unreasonably withheld).

The Transitional Services Agreement will terminate on the earlier of (i) the date on which all Services have expired,
(ii) either the Transitional Services Agreement or all Services to be provided are terminated in accordance with the terms of the
Transitional Services Agreement, or (iii) a certain number of months from the Completion Date (such number to be agreed
between the parties prior to the Completion Date). The Transitional Services Agreement provides for the potential extension of
any Service, the requested extension shall be considered by “Service Managers” nominated by both parties in good faith but
the supplier party shall be under no obligation to accept any requested change to the Services. Any Service may be terminated
by the party receiving such Service by providing a written notice of termination in a timely manner and subject to applicable
law.

**_Post-Completion Braunstone Agreement_**

As at the Completion Date, Macsco 20.11 Limited, a subsidiary of Titan, will enter into the Post-Completion
Braunstone Agreement, pursuant to which Crown Packaging Manufacturing UK Limited will supply Macsco 20.11 Limited
with tinplate food can products manufactured at the Braunstone manufacturing facility for a transitional period.

This facility currently manufactures products which relate to both the purchased business (i.e. food cans) and the
retained business (i.e. beverage cans). In order to allow Crown time to move the beverage elements of the Braunstone business
to a new facility, Crown will retain ownership of that business for a transitional period following Completion. During this
period the Post-Completion Braunstone Agreement will provide Macsco 20.11 Limited with the product it requires from the
Braunstone facility.

The Braunstone transaction will complete (and the Post-Completion Braunstone Agreement will terminate) once
Crown has moved the beverage business into a new facility, subject to a longstop date of three years.

**_Braunstone APA_**

Crown Packaging Manufacturing UK Limited and Macsco 20.11 Limited entered into the Asset Purchase Agreement
on April 8, 2021 pursuant to which Macsco 20.11 Limited has agreed to purchase the tinplate steel packaging business
conducted by Crown Packaging Manufacturing UK Limited at the Braunstone manufacturing facility. The transfer of the
